column1: Cooking Pleasures magazine is the magazine produced by the Cooking Club of America. I very happily joined Cooking Club of America
column2: and began receiving this magazine quite a while ago. The Club offers so much to its subscribers
column3: but as time wore on
column4: I could see that the Marketing Department was a tad too aggressive for my taste.  The Cooking Club of America offers their potential members numerous items to entice them to join. Members can take part in member-only contests where kitchen products and gift baskets are some of the prizes. They can be sent food items or kitchen products to review. They can also receive a cheese grater for joining!   There are some nice photographs in this publication. The recipes are not complicated either
column5: although they do require some unusual ingredients and some that are very expensive that many people would find hard to locate. I
column6: personally
column7: had to forego some recipes
column8: and others; I had to order a couple of ingredients online
column9: because of the reasons given.  The cheese grater sent to you is a nice idea
column10: but being it is a rotary grater
column11: you have to squeeze very hard to get the cheese to grate. Also
column12: the grater is made of plastic and eventually snaps in half after using it only a handful of times.  The Club also offers you a Culinary Resource Directory. The information contained in this directory is not difficult to find in a basic Internet search. You can also receive standard sized blank recipe cards. Unfortunately
column13: due to the size of recipe cards
column14: I do not believe anyone can even write the ingredients onto them without running out of space.   Also
column15: part of the member benefits is to sample products for review. Potential members can see photographs of blenders
column16: ice cream makers and much more. While a member there for three years
column17: I did have the opportunity to review quick rise yeast and a chipotle spice. Both were nice products. They were not the glamorous photos of kitchen appliances
column18: but it was something!  Currently
column19: they are offering a VISA credit card with their logo. With this card
column20: not only can you use the card like any other credit card
column21: but also you can receive club discounts. If this is something that appeals to you
column22: see the Club for details.  Approximately 3 months after you renew your own subscription
column23: they start mailing you about how you should renew your membership for the following year now
column24: so that you can help them keep club costs down. After just paying for the current year
column25: I was not interested in paying for another year already. An idea may be to NOT contact members so soon after they just paid their subscriptions. That may save the club some money.  I have Caller ID
column26: and I utilize it all the time
column27: screening my calls to specifically avoid telemarketing calls. Imagine my surprise when I pick up a call and it was a representative for Cooking Club of America. I was
column28: actually
column29: pleasantly surprised
column30: thinking I was about to embark on another benefit of being a member. I was most disappointed to hear the mono-toned voice on the other end of the line
column31: reading the script
column32: suggesting I become a Lifetime Member now. When I tell them I am not interested
column33: they have a "new" deal for me. When I still tell them I am not interested
column34: they have yet another deal. The calls continued after this conversation for another couple of months.   At this point
column35: my subscription has expired. I was relieved as the telemarketing phone call really turned me off. You should have been there to see me receive my credit card statement. Cooking Club of America automatically charged my credit card with my next subscription without my permission. It was three months after my original subscription expired! As you can imagine
column36: this was extremely upsetting.  Upon doing my research for this article
column37: I have come to find that others have had similar experiences with this magazine. It's a shame too
column38: as this magazine has plenty of potential. Unfortunately
column39: their marketing department could utilize different tactics in maintaining their current membership.  Despite this magazine being very affordable
column40: I recommend that you save your money on this one and try Fine Cooking
column41: Cuisine at Home or Cook's Illustrated. Not only do these magazines provide better recipes
column42: more professional tips
column43: they also do not call you daily to get your money

column1: this book is nice and it helps me a lot to my economics course
I was really looking forward to this book--I've read RMB since Rubyfruit Jungle and I love mysteries--but my anticipation came to a screeching halt on page 4
column2: where Ms. Brown produced this piece of pandering: "The whole point of the ban [on English foxhunting] was to punish those suspected of wealth or title from (sic) enjoying themselves... It was perfectly fine with [those who passed the ban] if the farmers shot the beautiful creatures... Better yet
column3: Americans did not hunt to kill the fox."  No.  It isn't all about the seedy underclasses hating the wealthy (though given the centuries of class privilege in England
column4: it might be understandable if that were the case).  It's not to punish those with wealth or title for enjoying themselves... though I'm sure those with wealth and titles were equally annoyed when droit du seigneur was abolished.  The whole point of that ban was to put an end to the bloody and horrible way in which English hunts conclude--the painful
column5: terrifying death of the fox.  You see
column6: I'm one of those ignorant Yankees who signed one of the many petitions to Parliament to try to bring an end to the bloody business of British-style foxhunting.   I don't recall the English foxhunters ever offering to compromise--to merely hunt the fox
column7: and not allow the dogs to tear it to pieces when it's cornered. It's one thing to shoot an animal that's endangering one's poultry--at least it's quick and relatively merciful.  A British fox-hunt is anything but.  Ms. Brown tosses off the very important difference between US and English hunts as though the death of the fox
column8: and the manner of its death
column9: does not matter.  It matters to me--as I am sure it matters to the fox.  The English hunt begins early
column10: with gamekeepers going around to where the foxes live and stopping their dens--blocking their means of escape.  Not very "sporting!" - but if the fox were allowed to escape
column11: the ladies and gentlemen of the hunt would be denied the pleasure of the kill
column12: and that would be such a disappointment!  Let's look at it from the fox's point of view
column13: as Ms Brown does in her books.  What would happen to her beloved foxes--what if Target or Comet were unfortunate enough to live in Merrie England?  What about sweet
column14: intelligent little Inky?  How would the story go...  "Panting
column15: exhausted
column16: Inky dashed through the creek
column17: backtracked to muddle her trail.  She ran along a fallen log
column18: cut through a thicket
column19: and dove for her escape hole.  It was blocked by a stone
column20: too big to move
column21: too deeply wedged to move around.   She gasped
column22: whirled--but it was too late. The hounds closed in
column23: snarling.  Inky screamed in agony as her hind leg was torn off
column24: but her adrenaline-charged heart was pumping so fast that she bled to death in seconds.    The whipper-in beat off the dogs and pulled out the bleeding stump of what had been her beautiful
column25: luxuriant tail.  He took the still-warm trophy of their victory over to the youngest member of the hunt
column26: an eight-year-old old boy
column27: and smeared Inky's blood across the child's face.  The boy fought back nausea.  This was the glory of the hunt--his father
column28: his mother expected him to be a man!  So he did his best
column29: and smiled
column30: and wished he were a million miles away."  I used to buy Rita Mae Brown's books in hardcover.  When her misplaced modifiers and brand placement got too irritating--her last Sneaky Pie book read like an ifomercial for the Virginia wine industry--I started reading the hardcover at the library and buying the paperback.     At this point... I don't even know if I'm going to finish this book.   The disconnect of making her foxes such interesting
column31: lovable people (her animals have always been more interesting than her humans) while kissing up to the savage brutality of English foxhunting is just more hypocrisy than I want to deal with in recreational reading.  I don't care if Ms Brown or anyone else wants to chase foxes till they're blue in the face; I'm sure it's great exercise.  But I draw the line at being told what to believe when it comes to humane treatment of animals.  It's sheer nonsense to pretend there's no difference between the US and UK style of fox-hunting or wax indignant over how those of us who think British foxhunting is barbaric are trying to punish the poor hunters. I'm sure Ms. Brown's fox-hunting friends were hugging themselves with glee over her polemic on page 4
column32: but it's just lost her a reader.

column1: The Summary (short version)  The characters...  Go to restaurants and drink.  Go to bars and drink.  Go home and drink.  Go to bullfights and drink.  Insult each other and drink.  P!ss and drink.  Go to sleep
column2: wake up and drink.  Take baths and drink.  Have sex and drink.  I became an alcoholic just by reading The Sun Also Rises.  Summary (the long version) Several expatriates lick their emotional wounds and cavort around spending money left by their rich parents. The protagonist
column3: Jake Barnes
column4: is a reporter left impotent by a war wound. He and Uncle Toby from Tristram Shandy could have had a ball together (if you've read Tristram Shandy by Laurence Sterne
column5: you'll get the joke). He's in love with the beautiful Brett Ashley
column6: but his impotence makes it impossible for their relationship to have much substance. She falls in and out of love with other men while he stands around watching and feeling jealous. A little bullfighting and violence and drinking later
column7: they're right back where they started: in limbo.  I've never cared for Ernest Hemingway's writing style. It's like he made sure you knew you were reading a story from a REAL man: very macho in tone and style.  And this coupled with the boringness of the story makes The Sun Also Rises a dreadful read

column1: Got this camera for my wife - a digital novice - during Christmas 2005. Camera is easy to use and takes good pictures. Easily interfaces with PC through USB. However
column2: I also (as did another reviewer) started having problems after about 11 months. Camera would not take pictures as the CCD went bad. Luckily I had an extended service contract and it was repaired. Unfortunately
column3: it just quit working again (April 2007) and the service contract company says they "...won't bother fixing it again..." and is refunding my purchase price. Gracious but a hassle doing without a camera for a second time. Good camera but if you buy one make sure you get the service contract

column1: I am being generous in giving this film two stars. I saw a trailer for it
column2: and while it looked intriguing
column3: looks can be deceiving
column4: much like the bulk of this would-be psychological potboiler. I think the photography work and acting deserve a minimum of two stars as both were excellent; the general storyline
column5: however
column6: was drivel.   Many reviewers have noted how the film fundamentally makes no sense
column7: and there are parts where I agree wholeheartedly. I don't mind thought-provoking films that leave you wondering what actually happened
column8: but this was mostly in the shallow end from the standpoint of plot construction. It is inconceivable to me how the two female leads (Charlotte Rampling
column9: and Ludivine Sagnier) could tolerate one another; further
column10: it is incomprehensible why Rampling didn't merely leave France when Sagnier started making her life miserable. To believe that Rampling would actually help Sagnier conceal murder is impossible. Yes
column11: I know that the entire character of the daughter is ambiguous by the end
column12: but inasmuch as the character was constructed in Rampling's mind to be a murderess negates charges of cinematic intellectual superiority and holds Rampling's judgment suspect.  The entire movie is filled with characters that are excruciating to watch
column13: and the only real reason for a two star rating is that the actors do an outstanding job in their roles. I considered briefly watching the film a second time to make sure I understood all the nuances
column14: but I just hated it too much the first time to give it a second chance. This is one film that looks positively great as a two minute theatrical trailer
column15: but looks positively awful in the light of day as a hulking 103 minute feature.   I am very open-minded to unusual
column16: imported

column3: it started smoking and the coils in the back flared up and caught on fire. (There were actual flames -- although they quickly burned out)  I took the dryer back to Sephora and I was quickly given a replacement.  While I had dryer #2
column4: I noticed that it took 15-20 minutes to dry my hair
column5: when it usually takes 20-30. However
column6: I have the full size T3 at home and it takes about 10 minutes when I use that one.  I was expecting this to offer the same power as the other T3.  The bottom line is that I didn't notice a big difference between the travel T3 and the hotel hairdryers that are built into the bathrooms.   After 6 months
column7: the handle broke on the 2nd hairdryer making it rather challenging to use.   If you want a great hairdryer
column8: buy a full size T3
column9: Elchim or Chi Pro -- if you need something to travel with
column10: you're better off with finding space for the full size model.

column1: I was appalled by the poor editing of this book. The author is from the neighborhood where the story is set..rural North Carolina.  The basic plot is fine
column2: being about a black man in 1947 being accused of attempted rape by a white lady because he didn't get off the sidewalk when she passed by.  This is supposed to be based on a true event where said black man is arrested
column3: hauled out of jail by the Klan to be lynched
column4: but escapes to the swamps and then to the North.     However the 12-year-old main character interejects her own stream of consciousness into the first person present tense story.  These are the problems I had:  She says when her mother gets mad at her
column5: Mother hits her with a plastic spoon.   She says that if she isn't good
column6: she doesn't get to go to grandmother's house to watch RV.  She says Grandmother gets a phone and it's YELLOW
column7: and that the phone number is 919-555-1919.   I remember the 50's pretty well and this story takes place before that.  No one had a TV in 1947
column8: much less a poor black family who had electricity but still had an outhouse in the back.  No one had plastic spoons...they would have been wooden or maybe metal.  Phones didn't come in color until the end of the 50's and then they cost more each month.  And it was the 60's when prefixes came into play.  Before that
column9: it would have been KE 8-1919 or TR 7-5616.   So
column10: the author is interjecting her own memories into this story
column11: and the editor was too young to know the difference.  This is too bad
column12: because
column13: while the children reading this may not notice any one of these anachronisms
column14: having done the research on the time and place would have lent a lot of authenticity.

column1: This book struck me as a boring little nugget stuffed in a pretentious and dandied up little wrapper.  We get to watch Arthur dress up in a little skirt and prance around the East Villiage; seemingly to show off his knowledge of the local geography.  You begin to wonder how his unemployed protagonist can afford all of this coffee and clubbing and then you begin to relize that it's all just an device for Arthur to show just how well travelled in New York he is and how many local landmarks he can rattle off.  His portrayal of a woman feels like a stuffed bra and a strip of duct tape. There are places where I felt genuinely embarrassed for him
column2: and felt like he was influencing his character's behavior in order to keep them out of uncomfortable situations and to keep his panties from being too closely scrutinized. My biggest gripe with this book is that it lacks the energy and dimension of many of Nersesian's other books and feels like a trip to a quick advance from MTV Books. Waste your time in a less painful way.

column1: This book focuses on Amanda Starkey
column2: a young nurse who has suffered a breakdown and was sent home by her boss so she could get her act together. Amanda returns to her family home in Wisconsin to live with her sister
column3: Mattie
column4: and Mattie's daughter
column5: Ruth. Mattie's husband
column6: Carl
column7: is off fighting in France during WWI.  The sisters are very close
column8: and so Mattie is of course thrilled to have her sister back in her life on a daily basis again. They begin to embark on a new aspect of their life together
column9: while Mattie anxiously waits for her husband's return from the war.  Then
column10: one winter night
column11: tragedy strikes
column12: and Mattie ends up drowning in the nearby lake. Her young daughter
column13: Ruth
column14: almost ends up drowning as well
column15: but is rescued in the nick of time.   Not long after Mattie's death
column16: Carl returns from the war
column17: wounded. He is eager to see his wife
column18: not realizing that she has died.   Amanda
column19: who has never liked Carl
column20: hopes that he will decide to leave again almost as soon as he'd returned home. She figures him for the sort to not want to raise a child alone
column21: and each day waits for him to leave
column22: thereby making her Ruth's sole caretaker. Yet much to her annoyance
column23: he manages to get his bearings again and remains a fixture in both hers and Ruth's life.  At the same time
column24: Amanda struggles with inner demons
column25: both because of what happened to her sister
column26: and because of what happened in her life prior to returning home
column27: which you eventually learn about. She is then sent to a sanatorium and Carl is left to care for his daughter on his own. However
column28: he founders
column29: and ends up relying on a second cousin (Hilda) for her grudging help.   This new upheaval causes Ruth to regress a great deal
column30: and she stops talking and acts out by breaking things in the house and being impossible to toilet train and deal with overall. In a funny turn of events
column31: Ruth manages to embarrass Hilda enough so that she leaves. Carl
column32: in an act of desperation
column33: takes Ruth with him on one of his many visits to see Amanda
column34: in the hope that it will spark a desire in her to get well once and for all. It works
column35: and a year after having been committed
column36: Amanda returns home.  The rest of the story vacillates between what really happened the night Mattie drowned
column37: and what is happening in Amanda and Ruth's life afterwards. In the first part of the book
column38: Ruth ages from about 3-5. When the second part begins
column39: she is already 11. I felt that was somewhat abrupt
column40: and it took me a few pages to realize how much time had passed
column41: as there wasn't anything to indicate that this had happened.   The book continued to bounce around a lot from this point on
column42: between reminiscences of the past and what was actually happening to the characters months or years down the line. It got a little annoying at times to have to figure out where exactly the next installation was starting out. Also
column43: the book jacket said the story was told from several of the main character's points of view
column44: but the only ones you really hear from are Ruth and Amanda.   I was pretty disappointed by the end of the story. The book starts out intriguing and makes you wonder if Amanda literally went off the deep end after all and killed her sister
column45: or if it was in fact an accidental drowning. But by about halfway through
column46: the facts become clear and are easy to interpret. Still
column47: I hoped maybe I was wrong and the ending would surprise me after all. It didn't.  Carl also disappears about halfway through the book. It's due to a job he takes
column48: but it felt like he was written out of the story because the author ran out of use for him
column49: or wasn't sure what to do with him after a certain point. She spent a lot of time focusing on Carl's desire to learn about the truth of his wife's death.   As it was
column50: he only found out part of the truth
column51: and that was according to what Amanda got him to believe. Nevertheless
column52: Carl accepted it at face value and after that he accepted his wife's fate. He was then written out of the story. I didn't really like that aspect of things and didn't think it meshed with everything else that was happening. Even though he wasn't a strong character in general
column53: he's one of the characters I actually liked. Amanda wasn't that likeable at all
column54: and was a pretty cold person who was obsessed with Ruth and still obsessed with the past. Ruth was somewhat pliable and easily molded to her aunt's bidding
column55: even though she made some feeble attempts to be her own person.  I don't know if I'd read this author again. But I managed to find this book for $1.. and would say it was worth it and I'm glad I didn't pay full price for it
column56: either on here or in a bookstore

column1: First of all
column2: I can't believe Trace got better reviews than Predator.  Predator was 1000 times better
column3: but that's still not saying much.  Trace was just awful.  The worst in the series.  I can say with the certainty of the Great Scarpetta
column4: that Patricia Cornwell did not write this book. One of her ghostwriters
column5: who probably hates Scarpetta
column6: wrote it.    This book is incomprehensible.  The story lines are disjointed
column7: disconnected--just plain bad.  There is no follow through; the reader doesn't get the satisfaction of having everything tied together at the end.  What happened to Pogue?  Dr. Paulsson?  Mrs. Paulsson?  Dr. Marcus?  And what about Fielding? All of a sudden Fielding has a horrible skin condition and he's no longer in great shape and good looking.  Is this all because the Great Scarpetta was fired and moved away and the stress of life without her has ruined his physical appearance?  That's pretty riduculous. And the motivation of the killer is so weak and SOOOOO absurdly stupid
column8: that I can't believe that Patricia Cornwell approved this awful imitation.   I'm so SICK to death of Lucy and her bad relationships
column9: and I just can't stand Rudy. Also
column10: in this book Lucy's father is now Cuban
column11: instead of Brazilian
column12: like he has been in the 12 previous books.  This ghostwriter has obviously never read any of Cornwell's Scarpetta novels.  Cuba and Brazil are two totally different countries and cultures!  To me

column16: unfulfilling relationship.  Do they even like each other?  There's such tension and animosity between them.  Especially since Benton was never really dead; he was just undercover.  That whole story line was never explored in this horrible book. Even more evidence of poor ghostwriting--that was the greatest oversight. There's no hashing out of feelings and talking things through. All we're left with is Benton's five sentence explanation in Blow Fly. And Marino...I was horrified and acutally felt embarrassed when I read the part of Scarpetta taking pictures of Marino's injuries.  I don't want to give it away

column1: John Harris is not shy about his feelings for DSotM.  The back cover of this book states "Pink Floyd's 'Dark Side of the Moon' (1973) is one of the most beloved albums of all time.  A sonically stunning exploration into dark themes...  Besides being perhaps the most fully realized and elegant concept album ever recorded
column2: 'The Dark Side of the Moon' [sic] was also one of the most technologically advanced LPs of its day."    Yeah
column3: right.  Questionable hyperbole aside
column4: Harris starts the book with the by-now familiar story of The Pink Floyd Sound
column5: Syd Barrett
column6: early psychedelia
column7: quick success
column8: Syd's decline and the band's decision to carry on without him.  It's an interesting story
column9: and many books and articles have mined it for dramatic appeal.  For me
column10: what happened next is the most interesting part -- the band throws out the pop song format and begins turning music inside out
column11: experimenting with long drones
column12: alternate playing techniques
column13: and new music structures never before seen on this planet.  Their incredible inventiveness creates a whole new style of music
column14: with a ripple effect on everything that follows.  Unfortunately
column15: Harris is less enamored of "Saucerful
column16: More
column17: Ummagumma
column18: Atom Heart
column19: Meddle" and "Obscured" than I am
column20: dismissing them rather cavalierly as "poorly realized
column21: loose-ended stuff" that "sought
column22: in their own ill-advised way
column23: to test both their audience's expectations and the limits of musical orthodoxy."  Apparently musical orthodoxy is very important to author Harris
column24: because he gets all gushy when he gets to Chapter 3 and starts relating stories of the creation of DSotM.  For those of us who LOVED the unorthodoxy and limits-testing
column25: DSotM was a huge disappointment from day one
column26: the episode where Pink Floyd "jumped the shark" (to use a TV metaphor)
column27: sold out and started playing to the lowest common denominator.  It was also the undeniable beginning of the end
column28: where PF got so famous that they became prisoners of their own success.  Instead of musicians
column29: they became commodities.  They all went off and bought mansions and were miserable.  To Harris this is all fine.  DSotM is his favorite album in the whole world and he gathers all available material about the creation of this album.  It's a fine story as far as it goes; and Harris does a credible job of telling it; and Floyd fans will enjoy the retelling.  I just wish John Harris knew the Pink Floyd I knew and loved.

column1: I read a lot of books and have been doing a number of reviews and this is one of the only books that I couldn't finish. If the book did focus on one thing in particular then it was details of the types of personalities some of the men around Jackson had
column2: which I am not sure how one could be so familar with that not knowing any of the people personally. Sure you can learn something about personalities from letters but the detail about personality types was too much. Spending too much time on small detail does not make for great reading nor does it help one to see the big picture behind the story. So if what you like in a book is learning about personality types you will love this book.   The book also seemed to be written by a some what biased point of view by the author. The title should have been something like Politics in the early 1800's. This book will NOT keep your attention from one page to another. If you want to know more about Andrew Jackson spend your money on something else!

column1: Perhaps in the first time in the publishing industry
column2: a former president had to refund a portion of the advance for his memoirs due to its falling short of expectations of the publisher. That is all that needs to be said about A Time To Heal.  Gerald R. Ford stumbled into the presidency in the same way comic Chevy Chase panned him in skits on SNL. Embattled Pres. Richard Nixon needed a mark to make sure he could shuffle out of the Oval Office without the threat of being prosecuted for crimes & misdemeanors
column3: and Ford was the man.  The book is short on detailed facts concerning the issue of the pardon and staggers through the key points of the times - the fall of Saigon and the 1976 Republican primary that basically undid his presidency - like a running back on a soggy field and wearing the wrong cleats for proper traction.  Ford should have had the courage to take a pen in hand and truly write a major piece on the tumolt that defined his brief presidency. The book publisher certainly expected more. But I guess that sketches short on facts are what should have been expected from an individual who truly defined the term
column4: "Beltway Insider."

column1: Andrew Weill is perhaps the most well-known of these type of practioners.  Unfortunately
column2: some of what he has to say has been clinical disproven. For example
column3: in study after study
column4: large amnounts of Vitamin C given orally do absolutely nothing more than a   placebo for cancer patient.  Yet he still preaches this.  Given intravenously
column5: actually
column6: there is some evidence that it may work for some people..but it does not work by stimulating your immune system..it works in a different way.  The book How To treat and Prevent Cancer with Natural Medicine is far superios in my opinion
column7: even though it was written by four naturopaths in 2002.  Even then they admitted that clinical studies were showing that there was no advantage of taking Vitamin C orally over a placebo
column8: and the authors freely admitted it. But much of what the discussed in that book..Eight Magic supplements to take when you have cancer..has actually been proven. I am a cancer patient with myeloma.  Maitake D fraction
column9: curcumin (it must be taken w/bioperine an hour before meals)
column10: selenium
column11: and some other things they mention have all been proven in clinical studies or are being worked on.  They do not promise that they have a cure of anything..they only say it may help in the context of complimentary medicine. They do not claim an organic diet will cure cancer or that medical science would hide it if they have a cure.  The book by Quiallan I think claims that an organic diet will cure you
column12: and there is post after post that this has actually worked.  Maybe it has..but as a myeloma patient..my immune system is overstimulated
column13: so I cannot take most immune system supplements..and some like Vitamin C are actually antagonistic In Vitro to myeloma treatments..this usually translates to the same thing in the body..unlike positive in studies that often do not pan out.  Anyway
column14: I am not saying Dr. Weill is all wrong
column15: but do not pretend he has a cure.  I have known secondhand two people who have been cured by long fasts of only carrot juice
column16: another two by healers (I  am not religious)
column17: and one who claims that barley juice and lowering his PH totally got rid of his cancer.  I believe these people all may have gotten rid of their LOCALIZED tumors this way. For blood cancers
column18: such as leukemia and myeloma (a cancer of blood produced in the marrow)
column19: we do not exactly have localized tumors.  But with the addition of supplements mentioned in Dr. Murray et al's book
column20: my response to medications has been phenomenal and I have went into remission. Unfortunately
column21: at this time
column22: myeloma always comes back from remission. There is new understanding why this may be so..that just came out December 2005.  There is even a drug available..but it will not be available to myeloma patients for a long while

column1: I beg to differ with other reviewers of this book. Although the book may have been regarded as a classic in its time
column2: it cannot be recommended as a source for either self-study or as a reference book on set theory by present-day standards for mathematical writing. Its style varies from too concise to too verbose in an erratic manner. It attempts to combine rigor and lack of rigor
column3: and does so inconsistently. There are no references to other works. Finally
column4: I was particularly turned off by the last sentence of the Preface
column5: the pompous and patronizing "read it
column6: absorb it
column7: and forget it." Those who are interested in elementary set theory are advised to consult the books by Robert Stoll and Patrick Suppes. Besides being much better written and more comprehensive
column8: they are also cheaper.

column1: In his recently published history
column2: The Whiskey Rebellion
column3: William Hogeland attempts create a revisionist history of the late eighteenth century Whiskey Rebellion in Western Pennsylvania. What Hogeland accomplishes is less history and more diatribe in the vein of Howard Zinn. He has an axe to grind
column4: and by the end Alexander Hamilton is the devil incarnate
column5: and those who openly contemplated secession and committed acts of violence against property and people were just trying to bring the American Revolution to its necessary conclusion.  The accusation that Hogeland comes back to again and again is that Hamilton incited the rebellion. The argument is that because Hamilton's patently unfair whiskey tax was the impetus behind the frontiersmen's resistance
column6: and his unreasonableness in enforcing the tax and issuing writs for the arrest of those who refused to pay the tax caused the rebellion.  The problem with Hogeland's argument is his scholarship
column7: or lack there of. He almost never offers a direct quote
column8: especially when accusing Hamilton of malfeasance. Instead
column9: Hogeland offers his summary of primary documents with nary a footnote. The reader is expected to accept on faith the author's interpretation at face value with no way to check the facts except a ridiculously useless bibliographic essay at the end. Not all of this is Hogeland's fault. The new trend in historical works intended for the popular market eschews scholarly footnoting
column10: opting instead for endnotes that provide little more than an opportunity to name drop. Even Doris Kearns Goodwin
column11: a legitimate scholar
column12: is guilty of the succumbing to this new endnote craze.  Ultimately
column13: this is the main problem with William Hogeland: he is not a scholar. He is a magazine writer with an agenda
column14: and no scholarly background to legitimize his preposterous conclusions. To read some radical agenda into the actions of the Pennsylvania farmers is the very worst revisionist history
column15: because there is no basis in reality.

column1: Years of trusting Chicago Cutlery went down the drain with this purchase. How the company could risk its reputation for quality by putting out such a poor product is beyond me.   The wood knife holder is fine.  The handles are smooth and well finished. The knife blades are a complete and total disaster.  The so-called "STAINLESS" steel is really a poor quality carbon steel.  I have the distinct feeling that my set was unfinished
column2: as the serrated edges were so rough that slicing meats or even a tomato ended up with a tearing of the food.  I finally used a sharpener to take the unfinished edges down a little.  That worked
column3: but seems dumb that they came out of the factory unfinished. The blades are very heavy whch may seem like a feature
column4: but because the serrations are only on one side
column5: when you try to cut
column6: the angle of the blade edge causes the blade to turn
column7: and prevents even cuts. The worst part
column8: is the rust.  I note that after I bought the item
column9: the term "hand wash" was added to the descriptive copy.  Even hand washing and drying did not prevent rust
column10: and then of course
column11: if the rust is allowed to remain for any time... pitting takes place. My wife bought the set at Christmas from Kmart... supposedly a $59.95 value for $29.95.  Hey... I was happy... a set of Chicago
column12: at a great price.  Not to be... I have thrown away the original box
column13: but don't recall anything on the box or the descriptive card that was included that said the set was imported from China.  Usually
column14: when this is the case
column15: the words "made in China" are imbedded in the blade.  Not so.  The blade has only the embossed "Chicago" brand. I used to work near the Chicago headquarters
column16: and knew some of the workers
column17: who had pride in their product. That was then
column18: this is now...   They say you get what you pay for.  In this case
column19: I must tell you that I bought a similar set for our cabin
column20: with a few less steak knives
column21: but the same basic carving knives... no wood knife holder but a nice wood cutting board.  The set doesn't rust
column22: cuts better
column23: and the best part is that it had a day in
column24: day out price of a flat $8.00.  The stamped brand was "Gourmet Traditions"
column25: and the "made in China" stamp WAS on the blade.  We gave our "Classic" set away to Goodwill
column26: with a warning that it wasn't worth more than $5-8.00  "Chicago Cutlery" made an enemy of me...  You can only trade on a magnificent reputation 'til your old customers catch on.

column1: I recently saw Danielle Steel interviewed and was impressed that she had raised 9 children
column2: lost a son to suicide
column3: and did so much humanitarian work.  I'm not a fan of this type of novel but thought I would give it a try since I was so impressed with her in the interview.  There were two things that drove me nuts about this book
column4: the most annoying of which was her repetition of words and phrases
column5: often right on the same page.  "He was going to ask Carole" and then in the next paragraph
column6: "He had decided to ask Carole."  The second most annoying thing was all the cliches.  It isn't often that I roll my eyes while reading a book.  I also think she spends way too much time with her superficial descriptions of places and people and not enough time having them do things.  I like the way other authors develop their characters by showing us how they behave
column7: react and what they say in different situations.  I think having a character kick a dog (3 words) tells you a whole lot more about them than 50 pages of superficial drivel
column8: which this book is full of.  I think Danielle Steel is a remarkable woman
column9: but as an author
column10: at least of this particular book
column11: I don't see the magic or talent I expected from a person who has been called
column12: "the world's most popular author."  447 pages.  Two days.  That's time I could have used elsewhere
column13: feeding the hungry or ministering to the poor or sick.  OK
column14: probably just reading another book

column1: I am a big fan of John Bingham
column2: and credit his book "The Courage to Start" as a major inspiration to me to begin running and making it a part of my life.  Even better (if you choose only one of his books) is "No Need for Speed" which covers many of the themes but is a more complete beginner's guide to running. column3: I found his training log disappointing. Essentially you have a some running tips from John and Jenny (which are very good
column4: but all are found in his books) and the same single page (the weekly log) copied 52 times and spiral bound.  If this is what you are looking for
column5: it's fine.  I prefer tracking my running and races on an Xcel spreadsheet. Even a regular notebook would do about the same.  The bottom line for me is that if you don't own both of his books
column6: either would be a better purchase.

column1: Paul Johnson generally gets short shrift and quick dismissal as that most dreaded of ink-stained commentators - the "popular historian." Suffering from two fatal defects - he suffers from having his books actually purchased and read in significant quantity
column2: and unencumbered by footnotes or academic cant - Johnson is
column3: three dozen books or so later
column4: nonplussed
column5: and certainly undeterred. Instead
column6: Johnson soldiers on in his crusade of churning out crisp
column7: readable and even trenchant history. Generally he hits the mark more often than he misses. A HISTORY OF CHRISTIANITY
column8: unfortunately
column9: is largely one of the occasional misses
column10: a misfired product of his youth written (1976) in what must be considered one of the most demoralized and cynical decades in Christianity's history. The resulting book is one very much of its day.   How cynical is A HISTORY OF CHRISTIANITY? Johnson
column11: in his preface
column12: has the avowed goal of a history of Christianity with "the requisite degree of historical detachment." At no point does Johnson spell out what this degree is or if it is even measurable. Nonetheless
column13: he certainly believed it to be attainable. Johnson
column14: an avowed Catholic
column15: achieves it by a searching and relentless hermeneutic of suspicion towards nearly all comers
column16: but most especially his own church. "Nearly all" - but there are exceptions
column17: for Johnson's narrative leaves no doubt who its heroes are and who resides in the rogue's gallery. And it is in both classifications that the reader gathers a clear sense of Johnson's brand of Christianity - and an uneven (at best) historical detachment. That brand is
column18: inescapably
column19: Erasmian.  In this regard it is worth noting that while Erasmus does not make his appearance until the opening of Chapter 5 ("The Third Force
column20: devoted to the Renaissance and the Reformation), he provides not only only the glue for the entire chapter but the entire work. Johnson's sympathies are not only evident in the disproportionate treatment given to the Dutch humanist - over a dozen continuous pages, to contrast with, say, the two given to Calvin, the few sentences given to Athanasius, Anselm, Aquinas or Zwingli, and the lack of any mention at all of Kierkegaard, Unamuno, or Bunyan - but in the effusive manner in which Erasmian themes come to dominate analyses of crucial episodes throughout Christian history. An Erasmian theology reduced to the bare minimum" finds little to praise in "the constant and depressing inflation in the vocabulary of invective" (p. 51) of the Church Fathers; the "parasitical" unproductivity of monasticism; the scholasticism
column21: high
column22: midddle or low of the High Middle Ages; the "confident dogmatism" of Calvin and Luther and their successors; but plenty for Pelagius in his doomed battle with Augustine - apparently the chief of Johnson's villains - and John Locke's religious minimalism. Locke and Erasmus
column23: Johnson says
column24: get to "the heart of the problem. What matters is not so much what a man believes as what he does. Christianity is about morals
column25: not dogma" (p.338). From this premise most of Johnson work flows
column26: and only in passing does Johnson hint at the possible vulnerabilities of this approach - Christianity at risk
column27: he faintly concedes
column28: to easily lose its Christian character completely "and topple over into mere deism" (p. 340). Passe Leo Strauss (or at least his popular caricature)
column29: Johnson's ideal Christianity is one that makes for well-behaved and productive citizens. "It helps to cage the beast
column30: Johnson avers (p. 517). Which is to say, very Lockean of him.  Such a narrative requires a certain selectivity in treatment, but Johnson's story leaves surprisingly large swaths of Christianity untouched or barely grazed. The virtually nonexistent attention given to Christian history in the developing world is bad enough if tolerable given its marginality to the core of the faith's identity during much of its development. Less escusable is the scanty treatment given to the critical role of the Eastern Churches, which more or less disappear from view even well before the Great Schism. Likewise striking are the large gaps in Protestant history, especially of evangelical movements in the U.S. Johnson's is less a History of Christianity than A History of West European Christianity.   Nevertheless, there are glimmers of the old Johnson fire which no doubt form much of the attraction the book has had over the last three decades. Crackling, even astute observations pepper the work. Not the least of which is the concluding paragraph, which for all its Erasmian language is inescapably skeptical of the alternative: Certainly
column31: mankind without Christianity conjures up a dismal prospect. The record of mankind *with* Christianity is daunting enough...In the last generation
column32: with public Christianity in headlong retreat
column33: we have caught our first
column34: distant view of a de-Christianized world
column35: and it is not encouraging." While it is likely that A HISTORY OF CHRISTIANITY would be a different work if Johnson wrote it today
column36: three decades of de-Christianization in Western Europe have lent an undeniable force to Johnson's observation

column1: First off
column2: I am a member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.  Secondly
column3: I have not actually read the book.  However
column4: I have studied many religions including other Christian religions
column5: Islam
column6: Judaism
column7: and Buddhism.  Also I have read the excerpts from this book provided on the main website.  That gave me enough information to know that most of the information is false or has been twisted to provide a pejorative view point on the church.  As far as I can tell the book doesn't mention the fact that the children are being taught strong moral values like honesty and chastity.  These are attributes that seem to be lost in most of the world today.  Now this does not mean that members of the church are perfect and that they don't make mistakes but at least they are trying.  Moreover
column8: there is no sign
column9: in the excerpts
column10: that all of the humanitarian work that the members of the church and the church itself does every year is ever mentioned.  Well of course not we wouldn't dare paint a real picture of the church if it makes it look better than what he may believe it is.    Here is a quote from the excerpts "Over sixty thousand fully-trained
column11: adequately financed and prepared Mormon missionaries are serving in all parts of the United States and in over 124 countries around the world."  I was one of these supposedly "fully-trained" and "adequately financed" and "prepared" missionaries.  I don't know what the author considers "fully-trained" and "prepared" but I know that I would not have considered myself fully-trained.  I served as a missionary in Mexico.  I arrived there after 8 weeks of language and teaching training.  Being a linguist I also know that 8 weeks is hardly enough time to learn a foreign language let alone teaching skills.  And the reason that the missionaries are "adequately financed" is because many of them save up money for years or their parents provide the money for the missionary.  In cases where the family is not able to provide the money for the missionary to serve then members of the local congregation also can choose to help.  So what this really comes down to is if you want to know about any religious group or any other organization why do you go to someone who is obviously biased against it.  For example
column12: when I wanted to know about Catholicism I went to my Catholic friends.  Same thing with Lutherans
column13: Jehovah's Witnesses
column14: Muslims and Jews.  If you want to know the truth about something go to those people that actually know.    If you want to know about Mormonism talk to a Mormon.  You shouldn't feel any pressure to become a member of the church yourself.  But you can learn and decide for yourself if the church is a good thing or a bad thing.  As a final note I know that many people who are not members of the LDS church are happy when their children make friends with kids who are members of the LDS church.  Because more often than not those children have higher moral values than many other kids in this day and time

column1: Summary:  Do not read businessThink
column2: unless you want to learn how to write hundreds of pages of common knowledge and hype it as revolutionary thinking. The book does contain useful thoughts but they are definitely not new and are wrapped in disgusting self-propaganda for the businessThink "methodology". The authors do not demonstrate any significant knowledge of business best practices or the relevant literature
column3: consequently the examples used to underline the points are far from enlightening.   Details: Normally I stop reading such books before the end of the introduction
column4: but being on holiday and the weather being rainy
column5: I got as far as the beginning of Chapter 5. Then I decided that businessThink was not even worth the $6 bargain price I paid for it.   I do not expect every business book to contain breakthrough ideas (for instance
column6: I enjoyed reading "Thinking Inside the Box" even if it claimed to contain only the old
column7: commonsense rules of business). However
column8: what Marcum and Smith did in this book; pasting together trite from business literature
column9: calling it "revolutionary" on every second page of the book
column10: lacing it with irrelevant or imprecise examples
column11: and using a conceited and patronizing style in the meantime is way too much for me.   Being mostly a compilation of common business knowledge
column12: businessThink does give you some good general advice
column13: but much better business books exist
column14: with more relevant and practical examples and written by more modest authors.   Let me share with you what I have read in the first four chapters and then you can decide whether you are interested in the rest. (My comments are in parentheses.)  Foreword by Stephen R. Covey: Powerful breakthroughs need a paradigm change
column15: not just a change in attitudes. He believes that businessThink "presents a provocative
column16: principle-centered paradigm shift for rethinking the way we do business". This book is "every person's MBA for the real world". And this goes on for 8 pages... (By the way
column17: if I hear or read "paradigm change" or "paradigm shift" I get immediately suspicious. This is one of the favorite phrases of empty-headed corporate parrots.)  Introduction: Despite of an "innovation explosion" and a confidence among entrepreneurs
column18: most businesses fail. This is because most businesspeople just "do" business and not think about it. (This is the first of many not-so-solid conclusions of the authors. A business can fail for many reasons
column19: inadequate thinking being just one important aspect.)  But do not worry
column20: all you feeble-minded
column21: unable-to-think-coherently businesspeople around the globe
column22: because here we are to help you out with our eight rules that "will be the seeds of a much-needed revolution in business". We offer a complete
column23: fail-proof solution to the "dysfunction of the real business world". Live by these rules and "you will develop a business instinct or seventh sense". If you learn how to think correctly - that is
column24: if you adopt businessThink - then it will be better for both you and for your company. Since you may find this idea difficult to comprehend
column25: let us elaborate the upsides of thinking versus not thinking. (And they actually list the advantages of using your brain at work! This is probably necessary because the moronic reader has not learnt businessThink yet. By the end of the book
column26: he might be able to assemble such a list himself
column27: but for the time being he surely needs instruction by the bright authors on this point.)  Chapter 1: Today thinking is the most important activity of businesses. But most decisions fail
column28: while decision confidence is high. (The authors cite research results
column29: some of them without proper reference.)  Let us see an example of a company making bad decisions - Webvan. (A verbatim quote from Fortune magazine follows
column30: with what I believe to be a rather shallow analysis of Webvan's failure. Surfing on the Net
column31: I found a better article on the topic in 5 minutes. If Marcum and Smith could not come up with an original example
column32: at least they should have chosen their quote wisely.) In today's business white-collar productivity is all-important. Thinking is everybody's job. (I believe
column33: I've also heard this before...) Currently in most businesses "there is no common approach or common criteria for making decisions". But here are the Eight Rules of businessThink listed and shortly explained. Neither EQ
column34: nor IQ is enough for proper application of businessThink
column35: you need a fusion of the two.   Chapters 2 and 3: The first rule is "Check Your Ego at the Door". That is
column36: listen to others
column37: do not be overconfident
column38: show humility etc. (Of course
column39: this rule is only applicable in business decisions but you can forget about it when you write business books - at least that's what Marcum and Smith seem to think...) Some of the revolutionary ideas regarding the first rule include:  - Don't think black and white
column40: but consider other options. - Beware the absolutes like all
column41: never etc. For your convenience
column42: these rules are also demonstrated in business scenarios
column43: comparing the "old school" thinking with businessThink.  (Many of these thoughts are meaningful. The only problem is that the "old school" does not exist. At least I have never read any business book or methodology that would recommend that on a company meeting you should say things like "The idiots. I totally agree with you..." instead of "What kind of information could we get together...?". Of course in practice you will meet stupid reactions
column44: but this is not because of some pervasive "old school". Smart people have avoided thinking black and white for centuries
column45: while dumb people will continue to react stupidly. So it is a ridiculous claim of the authors that businessThink provides the reader with a completely new approach.)  Chapter 4: The second rule is "Create curiosity". Ask questions
column46: refresh your beliefs and forget about hierarchy and titles. (This is of course not bad advice
column47: but the examples cited range from the inaccurate - Grace Murray Hopper inventing the COBOL language - to the unproven in practice - the company IDEO reinventing the shopping cart in a TV show -
column48: indicating a lack of serious knowledge or adequate research by Marcum and Smith on this topic. This shallowness of the authors is also evident from other parts of the book
column49: e.g. in the beginning of Chapter 5 they cite a research result but instead of referencing the original publication they refer to another book. I would expect that if you make an experiment a starting point of a chapter in your book
column50: you would actually read the original report in full
column51: not just some interpretation of it.)  Enough said... If you are really in need all these ideas then I doubt that you will profit from any book
column52: including this one. I give two stars for the glitters of humor and for the honesty of the authors' own failure stories.

column1: The Last Samurai is a re-do of the 1990 borefest Dances With Wolves.  Once again
column2: a formerly evil American U.S. Army officer comes to the aid of an indigenous people who are threatened by evil predatory U.S. imperialism.  At least that is what the filmmakers would like you to believe.    Actually
column3: the Japanese samurai were an oppressor class in their own right.  The samurai preyed on the peasants.  Eventually
column4: as reformers took hold in 19th Century Japan
column5: a new national army based on the peasantry was formed.  When the samurai rose in revolt against the reform government and attempted to restore their traditional privileges. the national army defeated them.    The Last Samurai fails as both movie and history.  Avoid it like the plague.

column1: They have made several changes - some good
column2: most bad -  since I bought my last Sony handicam in 8/2003.  First of all
column3: there is no carrying strap.  This is very inconvenient if you plan to use your hand for anything else except for holding your camera.  I managed to jury rig one but it is a royal pain. The docking station is just one more thing to have to carry and when you want to upload your mini cassettes to your computer
column4: you have to take the camera off the docking station to change cassettes. This messes up my editing program.  Fortunately I still have my old camera.  The ability to take still shots is better - more megapixels - but not good enough to zoom in or enlarge.   While I was told most people prefer to use the LED screen (I don't knoiw why as it eats up more power and you can't see clearly in bright sun) I like to use the viewfinder.  It no longer has a tilt up feature so I end up mashing the battery into my cheek.  This last complaint is about the batteries. Sony LIED about the amount of time that a battery will hold.  The 5 hour battery only charges to 194 minutes on my camera. That's slightly more than 3 hours; It is nowhere near 5 hours.  The 7 hour battery does not get anywhere near 7 hours either. Their packages should be accurate.   All in all
column5: It is not as good as the older product.  There also should be a setting to stop it from running if the rec. button is not being pushed.   THIS WILL BE MY LAST SONY UNLESS THEY MAKE MAJOR IMPROVEMENTS

column1: The sub-header to this book could very well be: "All Work & no Play makes Jack a Dull Boy".   Basically
column2: Tom Stanley's scholarly treatise on American wealth comes down to this mind-ripping
column3: continent-blasting conclusion:   Millionaires
column4: you see:   1) Save more than they spend;   2) Don't spend anything.   That's it. Page after page
column5: chart after chart
column6: graph after graph
column7: anecdote piling up on anecdote
column8: all of it boiling down to the same conclusion: don't spend more than you save. Clip coupons. Hang on to your wife `til Death you do Part. Buy a rambler for 80 grand
column9: and cling to it like a rat clutching a Big Mac in a hurricane.   To wit: if you're a good little Bob Cratchit
column10: and burrow down in your suburban Dacha
column11: drive the Civic
column12: eat Top Ramen
column13: and take your vacations at the State Museum of Knitting & the Fine Arts
column14: you'll die loaded!Sound like fun?   Didn't think so. Look: you've got one life
column15: and after death all bets are off. Sure
column16: you could be hauled up by the angels to Paradise
column17: or it could just be one plate of linguini too many
column18: a nasty flatline and one vast inky void of non-consciousness. Either way
column19: you're looking at one single trip on this not-so-flat Earth
column20: so you might as well live large.   It's true

column22: Wall Street tycoon
column23: Railroad baron
column24: small-town librarian
column25: legal eagle defender of the Criminally Insane
column26: whatever. And you can always outspend it. That is the source of endless tragedy and Dickensian woe throughout the ages

column28: used to be a bank Vice President and got bought out because he was a dingus. Total skinflint. Miser. Goes on his own hunting trips and brings back venison
column29: deer meat
column30: which he forces his family of---jesus
column31: I think 12---to eat for months. Lives in a shacky little rambler
column32: buys used Crown Vics from the local police department and bargain basement prices.   The guy
column33: no doubt
column34: is high net worth. But he's also a loser.   This is a guy who didn't want to cough up a few hundred bucks to help build a joint fence between our properties---so there's a fence
column35: even a fence that abuts his property---but beyond my house and demesne
column36: he elected not to build a fence. Instead
column37: he got a plastic Jersey Barricade (orange and white) and went with that. Is that any way to live? Is that really what it means to be a `millionaire'?  I think not. Half the glory of the Age of Great American Consumption is buying stuff you don't need

column39: work at something you're good at
column40: that you have a real passion for

column43: if not to indulge yourself?   Sure

column46: ate catfood out of a tin

column48: then was found rigid and cold in the urine-stiff sheets of her dirty bed

column1: This is truly a strange book.  I'm not going to argue about definitions of the Enlightenment.  As long as the term is used to refer to rationalism in one's approach to questions of science and society as well as some sort of political liberalism
column2: I'll accept it.  And Bronner surely treats the Enlightenment in such a manner.  The author starts by explaining that both those on the political right and those on the political left have been attacking Enlightenment values.  He says that "human rights is often used as an ideological excuse for the exercise of arbitrary power."  I agree.    He also points out some traditional conservative arguments against the Enlightenment: its supposed nihilism and its "assault on communal life
column3: religious faith
column4: social privilege
column5: and traditional authority."  As a supporter of the Enlightenment
column6: I'm proud to oppose religious tyranny and social inequity.  And I think this book tends to support such a position.  I think that opposition to rationalism
column7: such as what we might find in the misleading arguments of the Creationists
column8: is a good example of anti-Enlightenment attitudes.  Bronner does not bring this up (although I have no reason to think he would disagree with me on this)
column9: but instead delves into opposition to social justice.    There is an interesting question here: what do racism
column10: anti-Semitism
column11: chauvinism
column12: and other forms of illiberal oppression have to do with the Enlightenment?  Bronner identifies all this as part of the Counter-Enlightenment
column13: and I agree.  But I also feel that there is a strong anti-rational attitude of some of the oppressors which one can see clearly in their responses to any challenges of their biases.  Bronner does point out that National Socialism in Germany succeeded in part because of its popularity in universities there.  And that various intellectuals did offer their support to some very oppressive leaders.  I think he then makes the same mistake.  Given the author's concern about anti-Semitism
column14: I'm not surprised that he comes up with this: "a half-wit prime minister of Malaysia
column15: who opposes the introduction of democracy into the non-western world
column16: rants about the power of world Jewry."  But I am surprised at the following: "Outside of the Middle East
column17: where hatred of Jews is fueled by the imperialist policies of the Israeli state
column18: anti-Semitism has become detached from any party or mass movement genuinely competing for political power."    I suggest that he look at the politics in
column19: say
column20: the UN General Assembly.  And more important
column21: why is he appearing to stipulate to a wild accusation against the Jews by calling Arab demands to obliterate human rights for Jews a mere reaction to Israeli policies?   His praise of Noam Chomsky and Ed Said
column22: with no mention of their antirational and arbitrary opposition to Israel
column23: appears to fit right in with this very anti-Enlightenment view.  Bronner encourages us not to discard the contributions of various Enlightenment intellectuals merely on the grounds that they sometimes had some reactionary social views.  But I'm not so sure I want to offer him the same charity.  Given his concern about anti-Semitism
column24: he ought to be very wary of supporting this sort of antirational and antisocial behavior.    I think this is no small error on Bronner's part.  Those who read his more recent book
column25: "Blood in the Sand
column26:
may discover why I consider it to be an anti-Enlightenment work.  If the problem were merely a rational belief in excessive rights of the Majority, I would at least understand how this could be reasonably consistent with Enlightenment views in some other areas.  But I think the problem is deeper than that, and that Bronner has no use for rationalism when he discusses Israel.  In any case, I feel that two stars is plenty for what is otherwise a very interesting study.

column1: In the preface of his book
column2: Kousoulas states "the traditional approach to writing history and biography is to tell about what happened
column3: rather than to describe what actually did happen
column4: as a novelist might-in effect to tell a story. Moving away from the traditionalist approach in order "to tell a story" has been my guiding principle." This is the main problem with Kousoulas' book.   I suppose the book is accessible to the masses (no footnotes or endnotes)
column5: but if you are actually interested in history and don't mind scholarly works
column6: this is probably not the book for you. At times
column7: Kousoulas' writing style had me cringing. By trying to tell Constantine's story as if he were writing a novel
column8: Kousoulas runs into many problems. He tells us what Constantine did
column9: but I felt like he never offered enough explanation as to why. He seems to take many of Constantine's decisions for granted
column10: including his decision to promote Christianity. When I finished the book
column11: I felt that I knew about Kousoulas' character of Constantine
column12: but I wouldn't feel comfortable discussing the actual
column13: historical Constantine with someone who knew something about him.   Kousoulas also deals with the problems in the church that were emerging at this time
column14: but once again
column15: it is a very vapid treatment. He tells about the arguments between the Arians and the Orthodox
column16: but he never goes into what the importance of these arguments was on the larger scale.   Also
column17: I wish he had provided a better conclusion. He goes up to Constantine's death and then ends after providing a brief sketch of what his sons did. It would have been nice if he had provided a final analysis of Constantine and his achievements.  I'm not saying this is a terrible book; I only gave it one star because I wanted to drop its perfect 5 star score. However
column18: I would be careful about drawing conclusions on Constantine and Christianity from this book. It is far from objective and it really only deals with the surface issues. Seeing as how this is one of the only recent pieces of biography on Constantine
column19: it is a shame that Kousoulas did not want to produce a more scholarly work

column1: Imagine your proudest moment
column2: your claim to fame
column3: your greatest accomplishment and personal glory rejected and censored almost immediately after achieved.  Author Linda Lawrence Hunt revives the almost forgotten story of an amazing female immigrant living in western America in 1896 in her book
column4: Bold Spirit. Life before the Norwegian immigrant Helga Estby's greatest victory was noteworthy enough as she battled the restrictions on women defined by society in Victorian America and the hardships and expenses of the struggling prairie life.  Enticed by a $10
column5: 000 dollar reward
column6: Helga boldly accepted a challenge to walk across America. 	When Hunt
column7: an English professor from Spokane
column8: Washington
column9: stumbled across this vague but intriguing story through a student's essay
column10: she felt she had to honor its significance to a greater potential. She could not pass up an opportunity to explain the gravity of Helga's journey across fourteen states on foot with only $5
column11: few possessions
column12: her daughter as a companion
column13: and determination to battle fears
column14: fatigue
column15: and danger.  Hunt's curiosity about this amazing woman led her to research endlessly through newspapers
column16: periodicals
column17: maps
column18: museums
column19: and witnesses' stories to recount the courageous journey that had been censored for so long.  With no journals
column20: diaries
column21: or personal documentation of the experience and very few corresponding letters with the family
column22: Hunt uses only fact-based and historically accounted information to retrace the journey from a third-person point of view.  However
column23: the facts prove insufficient in portraying Helga's true inner struggle.  	The geographical and historical research of the retold story is evident in every page of Hunt's work.  However
column24: the constant factual repudiation of the cities
column25: locales
column26: mountain ranges
column27: rivers
column28: and coal mines that Helga and her daughter Clara encountered are often distracting from the purpose of the novel.  The abundance of facts
column29: becoming monotonous at times
column30: occasionally seems as though they are meant to divert the attention from the multitudes of unknowns that encompass the Estbys' journey.  Understanding the difficulty in comprehending the route taken by the two Estbys
column31: Hunt assists readers with maps and pictures throughout the book that are very helpful.   Nonetheless
column32: the fact-driven book is so impersonal that it's comparable to a history book. 	The lack of journals
column33: personal entries
column34: and letters to the family make it difficult to fully connect with the protagonist.  Her obvious hardships on the farm and on the road can be assumed
column35: but the reader never really gets a glance at the genuine thoughts or emotions that occupied Helga's heart and mind.  Because any indication of fears or fatigue were recorded through news reports and articles keeping track of the journey
column36: the book only offers insight to the background of the story
column37: not to the emotions and thoughts of Helga.  The amazing story of Helga Estby's journey would be more powerful and effective told through historical fiction allowing Helga to have a sense of personality and capturing her inner conflicts.   	Hunt recognizes and clearly emphasizes the extremity of a Victorian woman's trek across the country.  Lacking personality
column38: her book nonetheless reinforces the respect felt for this courageous person and captures the significance of a woman risking her honor
column39: her health and ultimately her life to save the family farm.  The perfectly chosen title reflects the only way to describe Helga Estby: a bold spirit.

column1: I learned to make cheese with this book
column2: so it couldn't be all bad
column3: but I found myself going to the internet to check out proportions that looked wrong
column4: going to another recipe in the book when the one I was using said
column5: "Add salt
column6:
but there had been no salt in the ingredients list (I assumed that I could use the amount listed in another 2-gallon recipe), and making Muenster with no starter culture since it was not listed in the ingredients or referred to in the process description.  I got cheese, but it sure wasn't like any other Meunster I ever ate.  Wasn't too good, and an experienced cheese maker told me you have to use a starter culture in Meunster.  The book gave equivalents in some recipes (rennet tablets vs. liquid rennet / powdered starter cultures vs. fresh cultures), in others it gave only one and in some it didn't tell you which it was listing.  If anyone made the Colby first and put in three ounces of powdered starter culture, you would have an expensive cheese to say the least.  Also, I checked with my supplier and found out the 1/2 tsp. mesophilic starter culture the author lists in two-gallon recipes was twice what is necessary, which cranks up the cost a good bit.  But now I know and I'm buying only half as much starter culture.  I am puzzled when I read these good reviews.  Did they just do a batch of chevre or cottage cheese and call it quits?  If you follow these recipes exactly, you will have many failures

column1: I enjoyed everything else I have read from Harry Harrison
column2: and am fascinated by alternative history
column3: so I expected to like this book. I didn't.  I think it does credit to the American reviewers who have criticised this book that it went down nearly as badly with them as it did with Brits. They have demonstrated that one comment by a British reviewer - that this book provides an insight into the American mind - is unfair to most Americans.  The starting premise - Britain blundering into war with the North in the American civil war - is horrifying plausible
column4: which is not surprising as this very nearly happened. The first part of the book
column5: up to that stage
column6: is well done.  However
column7: the author then abandons any attempt at either a realistic attempt to work through what might have happened
column8: or to look sympathically at how the situation might have developed from the viewpoint of all sides. Instead
column9: looking for a way to turn both the USA and CSA into heroes
column10: he casts the Brits as utterly incompetent and evil cretins who both sides can unite against.  Although it isn't a positive for me to read a book in which my country is shown in a bad light
column11: this doesn't usually make it impossible for me to enjoy a work of fiction. Heaven only knows Britain has had it's share of reverses and like every other country in the world has been responsible for some stupid or wicked mistakes. However
column12: the increasingly implausible idiocy through which this book has the British blundering into war against both parties in the American civil war is way over the top. The idea that a Commander in Chief of any civilised nation could simultaneously be moronic enough to commit the acts attributed to the Duke of Cambridge in this book
column13: and clever enough to prevent his own government finding out what he had done and sacking him
column14: is  ludicrous beyond belief.  Harry Harrison is almost the last writer on earth I would have expected to prostitute his enormous talents with such chauvinistic rubbish. One-sided nationalism is not usually his style at all
column15: and he has written another book about a set of events which might have changed the course of the US Civil War/War between the States - "Rebel in Time" - which is far  superior to this.  The market for this book is people who like America
column16: hate the   British
column17: and are not too bothered about historical plausibility. So it may sell some copies in the USA
column18: and probably a few in Ireland (though as I'm married to an Irish catholic girl I think I'm qualified to say that not everyone in Ireland falls into these categories.) In the rest of the world most of those who don't like the Brits don't like the USA either
column19: and would be even less sympathetic to the CSA.   For anyone who is looking for a good account of how the American Civil war might have gone wrong
column20: try Harry Turtledove's "The Guns of the South
column21: or How Few Remain" and the "Great War" and "American Empire" trilogies which follow it. Or indeed Harry Harrison's "Rebel in Time"

column1: If you think that a newly-married couple with virtually no experience dealing with family-planning issues is the best source for advice on family planning
column2: you just might be willing to take a risk with this book.  It's chock-full of abstract theorizing and starry-eyed notions about the "blessing" of pregnancy -- it's virtually bereft of factual realities
column3: like the unreliability and burden of following "natural" family planning (if you call daily mucuous-membrane measurements and temperature-taking 'natural')
column4: and the dread of finding out that
column5: once again
column6: you're pregnant but can barely make ends meet to support the children you already have.    In other words
column7: it's one thing to talk about how great it is to 'trust God' when you only have one child -- it's quite another to try to pretend that failure to use reliable birth control is so wonderful when it results in 5 kids under the age of 8.  I've seen far too many couples wax poetic about natural family planning when they first get married -- only to hear them say "What were we thinking?" five years later when they realize the consequences that come from taking such a passive role in their own family planning.    Upshot:  you can take an active or passive role in planning your family.  If you take the passive route
column8: make sure you understand exactly what that means -- and talk to those who have a more experienced perspective than just a couple of years.
