column1: I completely disagree that eating a diet rich in a lot of fat and protein through animal sources is the healthiest diet.  While following the recipes and outline of the book would be a better choice than the standard processed "fast food" diet of today
column2: it is not at all superior to a plant based diet.  The China Study is an excellent and thorough book detailing years and years of research on how a high protein and high fat animal diet directly correlates to many diseases and ailments.  While I agree with the author's premise that refined
column3: processed and packaged foods are substandard
column4: I also disagree that ANY kind of oil or pure fat is not health promoting (she encourages the use of butter
column5: coconut and olive oil).  All oils are processed foods
column6: but even if they are cold pressed they are still a refined PURE fat.    Appropriate fats occur naturally in ALL fruits and vegetables.   Too much fat floating around in the blood stream will inhibit many body processes.   It also can be a recipe for disaster for those with sugar-related problems
column7: as fat in the blood stream mixed with natural plant sugars (in fruit) can slow down in the digestion process
column8: causing sugars to harmfully rise and contribute to candida or diabetes
column9: for those who have weaknesses in those areas.  Many individuals with hereditary problems between high cholesterol and heart attacks should take caution with eating more cholesterol.  Why put more cholesterol in a body that already overproduces?   My personal experience of having my own father and many relatives with my same genetic problem drop dead from heart attacks made me really take control of my own health.   I have dropped my own levels by over 100 points on a high-raw
column10: low-fat plant based diet
column11: without the use of dangerous statin drugs.     So
column12: although many cholesterol issues are dietary based
column13: there are those with special circumstances that the author failed to address
column14: who would not do well at all on her diet.   It would be a dangerous prescription to give someone
column15: with possible arterial damage or even heart disease
column16: a high protein and high fat animal diet.  There are very little recipes for fresh
column17: raw plant food
column18: and even the recipes such as salads contain dressings rich with animal products.   Most of the other plant based recipes are cooked in butter or egg bases. Many of the recipes are fried in butter or olive oil.  Fresh food is the healthiest food on the planet.   Cooked food
column19: plant or animal based has been denatured so you are not getting the full structure of the nutrient that your body needs.

column1: Why does Franken have to continually "borrow" names from those who are politically opposed to get himself some attention? The premise behind this book is that by following the techniques advocated by the "Fools
column2: you can pick stocks on your own and do better than the market as a whole and better than most professional mutual fund managers.  Think about it.  If this premise were true, then most of the professional mutual fund managers would be out of a job, replaced by anyone that could follow the Fools" advice.  The book is principally a big advertisement for the Motley Fool's web-site (www.fool.com) and much of the content it references isn't even there any more.  For instance
column3: the book references real world stock portfolios called the Rule-Breaker and Rule-Maker which you can supposedly see and follow for free on their web-site.  If you search google
column4: you'll find a page on their web-site announcing that both have been discontinued.  I'm guessing it wasn't because of their stellar performance.  Fortunately
column5: you can still *buy* the Motley Fool Rule Breakers Newsletter for $199.00 per year.  Whew!  The book also announces the creation of a new stock index
column6: which the book calls the "NOW 50
column7: but which the Fools renamed Fool 50" after the book was published.  Today
column8: if you go www.fool.com's stock index section
column9: you'll find no reference to the index.  You can still find links to the old pages if you search google (fool.com "fool 50")
column10: but not if you search on fool.com.  An index that lasted no more than 3 years!  Amazing!  Perhaps the best critique of the Fools is in Investing for Dummies (Fourth Edition) on pages 382-383:  "[O]nly one of their seven portfolios has actually performed better than the market averages--two of their portfolios were shuttered after poor performance (one of which plunged 50 percent during its short six-month existence)."  Fools indeed!  By the way:  "Investing for Dummies" is a great book full of sound investment advice.  Make sure you get the latest editions (the Fourth was just released and the Third is still on many store shelves) The companion title "Personal Finance for Dummies" is also full of advice worth hundreds of times its cover price.

column2: expecting that it'd be the last umbrella I ever needed. Wow

So I e-mailed the company because I remembered that it had a "lifetime guarantee." They told me that I'd have to ship it back to them (which is perfectly fine)
column4: but I'd also have to pay them $10 for their trouble. What kind of lifetime guarantee is that? For $10 or less I could buy another umbrella locally. Their product has proven that it's NOT superior and it DOESN'T live up to the claims they make for it.  Don't spend all this extra money on a GustBuster because you think it'll work better. It won't. Go out and buy a normal umbrella for 1/3 or 1/4 the price of a GustBuster -- you'll probably get the same amount of use out of the normal umbrella
column5: and you won't be paying an outrageous price for something that doesn't work the way their marketing claims

column1: I read the Heart of Christianity because my pastor said that many people had found it helpful.   That might be true.    However
column2: the people most likely to find this book "helpful" are those who are uncomfortable with traditional Christianity and
column3: like Thomas Jefferson
column4: want to cut out all the parts of Christian teaching they don't like.    Borg's  "emerging paradigm" challenges how we view God
column5: Jesus and the Bible.   Unfortunately
column6: his slender book is more interested in setting out a new belief structure than persuading anyone not already in his camp.        The Heart of Christianity sets out to explain an "emerging paradigm" which appeals to "millions" of mainline Protestants in North America.   Borg does not explain why this faction has so much greater insight than the majority of Christians both today and throughout history who have subscribed to what he describes as the "earlier paradigm.".    It is enough for him that some people find his formulation to be an acceptable reconciliation of the conflict between faith and intellect.    Borg is very up front about the fact that his book reflects a conflict between "two comprehensive ways of seeing Christianity as a whole."     While Borg claims to reclaim the "heart" of Christianity
column7: this is definitely not the faith of our fathers.    Instead
column8: he embraces what can be viewed as Christianity lite.    Much
column9: if not most
column10: of the supernatural is rejected.    What is retained is social activism based on the non-supernatural teachings of Jesus combined with a vague sense of spirituality.    The new paradigm is best illustrated through its approach to the Bible
column11: Jesus and God.      *	For adherents to the "earlier" paradigm
column12: the Bible is "a divine product with divine authority."    For Borg
column13: the Bible is a human response to God.    By implication therefore
column14: our response to God is just as valid as that which is contained in the Bible.     If certain teachings are uncomfortable or difficult
column15: we can simply decide that we have moved on to a more mature Christianity and disregard them. *	Jesus is central to both paradigms.    However
column16: Borg rejects the Jesus of the creeds who died for our sins and was resurrected on the third day.    Instead
column17: Jesus was a mystic and social teacher in the Jewish tradition and was executed because he threatened the power structures of his day.   His death
column18: like that of other social reformers such as Martin Luther King
column19: Jr. and Mahatma Gandhi
column20: was not a good thing in and of itself (it was certainly not part of God's plan to redeem the world)
column21: but was used for good by his followers.      *	Our relationship to God is also central to Borg.   However
column22: Borg rejects "supernatural theism" which envisions God as a personlike being.    Instead
column23: Borg embraces panentheism.    God is the "More" of existence.   He is an encompassing Spirit who is part of the created world.    He is somehow more personal than "the force" but less personal than God the Father.    Because God is so general
column24: no single religion is the sole path to enlightenment.   Instead
column25: all religions have a piece of the truth.  Borg does not really attempt to persuade the reader or defend his elegant construct.    As a result
column26: there are many questions left unanswered by the book.    For example
column27: Borg dismisses C. S. Lewis's assertion that based on the statements attributed to Jesus
column28: that he was either a lunatic or the son of God.    According to Borg
column29: Jesus never claimed to be the messiah or the Son of God.   Instead
column30: these were statements of faith inserted into the gospels by the early Christian community.   It seems rather presumptuous that a 21st Century academic claims to know more about Jesus than the early church.    However
column31: if you accept Borg's logic
column32: why believe anything written in the gospels?   Borg chips away at historical Christianity to leave the "heart" which he believes is important.   However
column33: using the same logic
column34: it is possible to continue chipping away until nothing is left.       This book presents only the tip of the iceberg of Borg's thought.   Therefore
column35: it is dangerous to make overgeneralizations.    However
column36: Borg appears to be the perfect prophet for the narcissistic baby boomer generation.    Borg jettisons those supernatural beliefs which no longer fit our more enlightened age.    The bold proclamations of ultimate truth contained in scripture become metaphors to be reinterpreted by each age.     Whether he does so intentionally or not
column37: Borg leaves us free to create God in our own image.     While he does not completely abandon the possibility of ultimate reality
column38: he makes that reality dependent upon our perception of it.    It is difficult to see the future of Borg's emerging paradigm.    If new generations take his message to heart
column39: there will be little reason to retain even the fa?ade of Christianity.  When all belief is subject to being reinterpreted according to more recent sensibilities
column40: then the very concept of belief collapses under the weight of personal subjectivity.    Borg may have thought of a way around this.    However
column41: it is not apparent in The Heart of Christianity.     The book is not all bad.   In some respects
column42: Parts One and Two are like separate books.   Part One sets out the "emerging paradigm" while Part Two contains much more orthodox views on living the Christian life.  Part Two emphasizes the liberal aspects of Christianity.   However
column43: its liberalism is much more deeply grounded in biblical Christianity.   There are some genuinely useful insights in Part Two.  However
column44: they are useful precisely because they are biblically grounded rather than the product of man's imagination.

and the best work of the late Jack Olsen. I wouldn't take too many points off for pedestrian writing.   But this terrible story at least deserved careful research, didn't it? Jones really falls down on that job, offering no substantive background on either the Aryan Brotherhood or (my particular field) dog behavior. San Francisco is home to some of the world's best dog behaviorists, and Jones even cites one of them (Jean Donaldson) in her acknowledgments, yet she winds up unable to offer any informed insight into what went wrong in these animals' breeding, training and handling. Given the notoriety of this case and the horror of Diane Whipple's death, Jones has really squandered an opportunity. If the quality of her dog-related information reflects the quality of the rest of her information, you won't find too many facts in this book.   
 Well, Sufjan Stevens has done it again, that's the really sad part. In his quest to bring a uniquely angst-besotted perspective to all 50 states, Stevens has neatly sliced notch #2 into his belt.  Personally, I'm looking forward to Rhode Island.

column1: I am always interested in the intellectual history of science
column2: particularly the Faustian dilemma.  Often we want to sell our souls to the devil for an article or a grant.  For scientists in Nazi Germany
column3: the Faustian dilemma was to sacrifice their Jewish friends and colleagues on the altar of Nazism. Hundreds of careers were made this way.  Overall
column4: I was very disappointed with this book.  First
column5: to fill the first hundred pages
column6: Cornwell spends way too much time discussing WWI without any real connection to the ideological development on Nazi science and the danger of scientists who embraced Nazism fully.    Second
column7: Cornwell deals rather efficiently
column8: without finesse or surprises for that matter
column9: with the usual array of popularized accomplishments of Nazi science during the war.  The book reads as a companion guide to a documentary on the History channel.  Stories of V1 and V2
column10: zyklon B
column11: radio navigation
column12: and the A-bomb have been told better before.    Third
column13: the book avoids the "big" moral and scientific dilemma in Nazi science: Lebensraum.  When the Third Reich occupied Poland
column14: it relied heavily on economic analysis on the economic viability of the occupation.  Economists and sociologists walked hand in hand to analyze the most efficient way to occupy that country and to extract its human
column15: capital
column16: industrial
column17: and agricultural resources.  Cornwell mentions the economic analysis of the viability of concentration camps
column18: but that is only a small proportion on how social sciences supported the Nazi ideology.   Fourth
column19: it was hardly surprised then that genetic experiments in the concentration camps are glossed over in the book.  Benno Muller-Hill is reduced to being a reference.    Fifth
column20: the most glaring omission is the role of social sciences
column21: which I tangentially mentioned earlier.  During the 1930s an entire generation of new academic social scientists were "manufactured" to benefit
column22: polish
column23: improve
column24: and offer scientific backing to the emerging Nazi ideology.  In less than 15 years
column25: history
column26: sociology
column27: economics
column28: linguistics
column29: geography
column30: and political science were rewritten and reanalyzed by this committed cadre of bright
column31: young Nazis.  Following the end of the war
column32: these still young academics were not removed.  Although many of them wholeheartedly embraced Nazism
column33: they were able to keep their academic appointments
column34: except for a few of the older guard.  They sold their soul as much as the younger group; few of them were removed and some became marginalized not because they were Nazis.  Those who kept their academic positions served as teachers
column35: professors
column36: and advisors to a new class of students. Few of these academics retired before the 1970s and they dominated the German intellectual contribution in social sciences for over 50 years from Nazism to social democracy.

column3: I think I was a little surprised by how awesomely bad it was.  The writing was completely repetitive and superficial
column4: and I rather felt that I was reading a treatment for a novel rather than the novel itself.  It read like a poor book report:  "...and then he did this
column5: and then he did this
column6: and after that he did this
column7: and then he laughed."  We are TOLD that the bachelors -- who struck me as commitment-phobic
column8: a little neurotic
column9: and fairly immature despite their (middle) age
column10: but not necessarily toxic -- are decent
column11: likable guys
column12: but we never really see too much proof of that.  When the "proof" does come
column13: it's so ham-handed as to be laughable:  Charlie's eyes well up with tears when he meets a young girl who was abused by her mother
column14: and so we know that he truly does have a loving and compassionate soul and untold complexities to his character.  Yeahsurerightwhatever.  Most of the story is told through narration
column15: with little bits and pieces of ho-hum dialogue.  The author adopted a third-person point of view
column16: but there's certainly nothing omniscient about it
column17: and the reader is never sucked into the head of one of these characters.  Throughout the book they remain about as interesting and dimensional as paper dolls
column18: and their interactions with one another always struck me as being fairly unbelievable.  THIS is how men behave and relate to one another?  I find that hard to believe
column19: considering that none of the men I know run around telling each other how much they love one another and how important they are to each other.    I liked the female characters of the book initially.  They all seemed to be strong

column1: With a title like "Apologies to Thucydides
column2:
what I was expecting was a more anthropological view on Thucydides' material. What I got what Sahlin's shaky justification for his tenuous and, dare I say, boring thesis.   Within the first few pages I knew this book wasn't going to be what I was hoping for, but I stuck with it, only to be thoroughly confused at the random trains of thought expressed. It seems to me that Sahlins had a list of things to tie the Pelopennesian War to before he wrote the book, and just did whatever he could to connect them. The purpose behind this is dubious and isn't explained in a satisfying manner at all.  I just fail to see the value in this book. My recommendation: don't waste your time. The book I was looking for, as far as I'm concerned, hasn't come out yet

column1: I have read several "Powerful Profits" books by Victor H. Royer
column2: and I can truly say he is one of the biggest phonies I've ever come across. I am in a state of shock that Midwest Gaming & Travel magazine could have hired this idiot. I am at an even further loss for words that Larry Grossman would invite Mr. Royer on his show
column3: and seems to think he is a Gambling God.  Amazon.com has plenty of other books on Craps that are of a much higher caliber. (Especially the ones by Mr. Scoblete)  The problem with Mr. Royer is he has no understanding of even basic mathematics. In the back of his craps book he has a chapter entitled "The Big Secret"
column4: in which he attempts to prove that craps can be beaten by betting an intermediate progression on all 4 hardways bets. He lists 2 charts -- the first which shows the rolls of the sequence
column5: the second which shows the size of the winning progression for each hardways bet
column6: as well as the total amount won/lost for the sequence.  The problem is: his numbers don't add up.  Here's a quick example:  Let's say your betting $10 to win on hard 6. When EASY 6 comes in
column7: you lose and now you press your bet to $11. Later in the sequence
column8: easy 6 comes in again and you press your bet to $12. Now you craps out and the SEQUENCE ENDS.  When computing total loss for the sequence
column9: Royer will include the $12
column10: but will forget to include the $10 loss or the $11 loss.  And Royer screws this up for his entire chart
column11: making the chart invalid
column12: and the total loss $$$ invalid.  The hardways bets are truly the worst bets in craps
column13: but leave it to Royer to convince novices to hand away thier hard earned money.  Does Royer really believe he has the answer to turning a negaive expectation game into a positive one?

column1: I recommend you not buy this book or cd.  I listened to the CD and it was too elementary
I'd been hearing about the wonderful writing of John Le Carre for quite some time
column2: so I picked up The Constant Gardener for a fun read . . . and it was anything but.  And while I don't know if this is typical of the LeCarre spy novels
column3: I certainly hope not.  The plot is basically a single man versus international conspiracy.  It's a plot that would normally catch my attention early and have my sympathy from the start. Further
column4: it's a commentary on the abuses of power wrought by corporations (in this case
column5: Pharmaceutical) that are more powerful than governments.  Again
column6: a device that immediately evokes common interests with me
column7: an unabashed liberal.  Unfortunately that's where the book and I part ways.  Justin
column8: the minor diplomat in Nairobi is thrown into an unfortunate series of discoveries when questioning the circumstances of his wife's rape and murder.  Tessa differed from Justin in that she was engaged in pursuing change in the world as a human rights activist
column9: while he was content to follow orders
column10: but say and believe the right things sans effort.  This
column11: I believe is the theme of the work
column12: that culpability lies mostly with inaction and that movements can overcome abuses of power.  Good theme
column13: but . . .  The execution was poor.  Pages and pages devoted to characterization fell short when actions didn't meet the set-up.  As well
column14: Justin's investigation took him around the world to look at a paper trail
column15: not the most interesting tools of the thriller game.  But we
column16: as well as the character
column17: examined the words and trail meticulously to the point where it became a joke how quickly the volume would put me to sleep.  Justin is such a luddite that we
column18: as the reader
column19: are forced to learn about computers
column20: emails
column21: and the myriad electronic communication pathways along with the protagonist . . . LeCarre would have been well-suited to find a heartless editor
column22: because the plot that does exist is not much more substantial than what a novella would handle nicely.  Bureaucracy can be handled in a paragraph where the author wants the reader as frustrated as his bureaucrat protagonist
column23: an interesting irony done uninterestingly.  This isn't to say that LeCarre is a poor writer - his sentence construction is strong and his mastery of the craft evident.  I'm going to try another of his novels just because I believe this was an aberration caused by an author with an axe to grind and no right way to do it.  Another problem was that he telegraphed the plot.  The only one stupid enough not to see who was behind the murder and conspiracy was Justin himself.  While this can work
column24: showing the reader what the protagonist can't see (see Fight Club)
column25: in this case it's just painful to have to slough through the machinations of bumbling intrigue with a dull and plodding man.   In summary
column26: I didn't care about characters and I lost interest in the plot and the theme seemed contrived.  I can't recommend it.  - CV Ric

column6: along three different threads. At first

column7: and it's this that you are expected to use to move yourself around. Now
column8: if you try holding the gun in a standard "aiming" style
column9: you'll soon realise that your fingers are in nowhere near the right position to be able to reach it. You could just hold the gun wrongly and reach it

column12: sorry

column1: I'm sure this won't win me any popular votes but
column2: this musical is one that I feel I have to comment on. What has happened to Broadway? Why has London's West End taking over the musical theatre industry? Well
column3: when Broadway produces musicals such as "Little Women."  As a fan of the book I had high hopes for the show expecting it to be as beautiful as "The Secret Garden" or "Jane Eyre." But
column4: this musical does not enhance the book in fact it morphs it into some kind of mindless garbage.  The songs are mindless garbage with no feeling
column5: depth
column6: or emotion and listening to the CD is what one Broadway fan might consider torture. There are a few exceptions "Take A Chance On Me" and "Small Umbrella In The Rain" somehow manage to stand out but
column7: are not enough to save this show from a slow death on Broadway.   The cast is dim witted and has little to no connection to the actual characters they are meant to play... Susan Foster who is well known as Millie does a decent job as Joe but
column8: misses that magic sparkle and tom-boy nature that one would expect from the character Joe. Danny Gurwin- however makes a breakthrough apperance as Laurie seeming to be just about perfect and should have recieved a Tony nomination ... I can only hope he makes a few CDs after this show.  It's obvious why when you listen to "Little Women"- how it came to die slowly and painfully on Broadway- the songs and the script lack the sentiments in the book- with no real love story... or perfect ending this musical is a truly tragic loss.  Made for the sole purpose of becoming a money maker knowing that fans of the book would stand by the show- the producers seemed to hope to make a quick buck. But
column9: I will not stand by this show- their is something in the story that could be turned into a musical that fans could enjoy. All in all Broadway needs something more and fans need something else..

column1: This is not a serious examination of the "Paul is Dead" clues and should not be mistaken for one. The credibility of the book is nil because it is full of obvious factual errors such as...        Pg 14: Glen Campbell spells his name with one "n" not two. It's Bruce Johnston with a "t". Page 65: Though an early working title for the Stones lp was possibly Her Satanic Majesty's Request
column2: the actual title of the final release was Their Satanic Majesties' Request.  (Neither title makes a whole helluva lotta sense)        Pg 21: Robert Fraser is misidentified as a "photographer
column3: when in fact he was Paul's heroin-addicted gallery owner friend, a business partner with the actual photographer for the Sgt Pepper sessions, Michael Cooper. All this is detailed in the book, Paul McCartney: Many Years From Now by Barry Miles, released after Patterson's book, but Cooper is clearly noted as photographer on the back cover of Sgt Pepper!       Pg 27: Though Lennon may've said that Paul's major contribution to A Day in the Life" was the "I'd love to turn you on" bit
column4: surely his major contribution is the well-known middle eight
column5: the "woke up
column6: fell out of bed" bit. Paul wrote that exclusive of John and Paul sings it.             Pg 40: The assertion that it "took a full night" to record the "inner groove" is wrong. It was a fairly quick effort on Friday 21 April
column7: part of a session that also included mono mixing for "Only a Northern Song." Surely the mixing took up most of the time. Why
column8: when Patterson's own bibliography lists the Lewisohn book
column9: The Beatles Recording Sessions (univerally admired for its accuracy)
column10: did he go to the suspect Dowlding for the lowdown on this issue? (See page 109 of Lewisohn).       Pgs 99-100: The Question and Answer session described as a "press conference" is no such thing. Those questions and the answers were authored by Paul McCartney as part of a promotional insert given away with some early copies of the McCartney lp. There was no real press conference
column11: just a self-serving fake one by a recently solo Beatle.   There's too much reliance here on bad secondary and tertiary sources
column12: and no fact checking. It's just plain awful. This odd pop culture phenomenon deserves  better treatment. (Comments are based on an earlier edition by Dowling Press

column9: which has to be judged on its own analytic terms
column10: but it is a plea for fairness in making distinctions between the contested terms analytic and continental..

column1: This is a copy of the review on Amazon.com for Van Zant's Get Right With The Man which is another Sony corrupted title.  "This CD secretly installs DRM (digital rights management) software on your PC without your permission. Not only does it do this
column2: but the software then hides itself by installing as a "root kit."  As per WikiPedia
column3: -- Root kit From Wikipedia
column4: the free encyclopedia. A root kit is a set of tools used by an intruder after cracking a computer system. These tools can help the attacker maintain his or her access to the system and use it for malicious purposes. Root kits are known to exist for a variety of operating systems such as Linux
column5: Solaris and versions of Microsoft Windows.  A rootkit typically hides logins
column6: processes
column7: files
column8: and logs and may include software to intercept data from terminals
column9: network connections
column10: and the keyboard. In many sources
column11: rootkits are counted as trojan horses. --  In this instance
column12: Sony installs DRM software to copy protect their CD
column13: and prevent it from being copied to various devices
column14: all the while not telling you
column15: the user
column16: or letting you uninstall it because it hides itself from the user and Windows. Manually trying to uninstall it like some people have done
column17: results in their CD-Rom drives disappearing entirely from Windows
column18: as Sony installs their own custom CD-Rom drivers onto the system.  DO NOT SUPPORT THIS WRECKLESS KIND OF COPY PROTECTION. SHOW THE MUSIC BUSINESS THIS IS *YOUR* MUSIC. *YOU* PURCHASED IT
column19: AND THEY SHOULD *NOT* BE ABLE TO DICTATE HOW YOU CAN USE IT.  Do not buy this CD. "  A list of affected titles can be found here:  http://www.eff.org/deeplinks/archives/004144.php  And another part of an Amazon.com review for the Van Zant CD  "Amazon rocks. column1: Anyone with the name Luke Timothy and a background as a Benedictine monk (called "black" monks and with a history dating back 1500 years) surely can't be impartial when looking at the historical Jesus. And true to form
column2: Luke Timothy Johnson engages in Christian apologetics rather than historical analysis in his 1996 book "The Real Jesus." Almost the entire book is spent criticizing other people's work
column3: from the Jesus Seminar to Barbara Theiring
column4: Bishop Spong
column5: Burton Mack
column6: John Dominic Crossan
column7: A.N. Wilson
column8: Stephen Mitchell
column9: Marcus Borg
column10: etc. In each case Johnson seems to begrudge the authors their financial success and 15 minutes of fame. Personally I find little value in  books that are critical of other people's work. I much prefer to let an author state his own case. This Johnson doesn't do
column11: apart from a few cursory pages at the end of the book.  If you're looking for Christian apologetic criticism of historical Jesus works from 1980 to 1995
column12: then this book is for you. Otherwise
column13: give it a pass

column1: I bought this book thinking that it would be fascinating!  I read online reviews that made it seem credible.  Unfortunately
column2: many of these reviewers did not have a background in psychology but I do. I was disappointed with this author's ludicrous claims and sloppy scholarship.  Some claims are loosely supported by actual studies with some validity while other claims have no valid or reliable experiments/studies to back them up.  For example
column3: Verny claims that babies that are induced are more prone to sexual sadism and masochistic behavior!  He cites no study to back up this ridiculous claim!  Also
column4: Verny equates emotional health with the personality traits of openness and extroversion.  To suggest that a child who is shy and introverted is maladjusted is bad psychology. Personality theory has proven that these can be innate and inborn traits.  My complaints go on... PLEASE
column5: DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY ON THIS BOOK.  It's muddy...some valid claims mixed with very stupid ones.  It's an example of how someone with "M.D" at the end of his/her name can sell a book that the layperson believes due to the author's credentials.  However
column6: I can assure you that my graduate school professors would have given this research writer a D

column1: Though this book discussed and touches on many different performance modifications it lacks ANY true technical information and is merely a good read for those interested in history and development more so than how to get true performance gains. Most of the technical information is severely outdated (late 80's and early 90's) and supports methodology which has been proven as a performance LOSS in this day and age (such as mirror finish port polishing!)  Is a nostalgic rag to be read but not a guide to go by...

I have to say I truly hated this book. The premise sounded interesting so I decided to give it a try.  I've read all her other books in the series and found the characters to be quirky.  This time I found her usual friends and co-workers to be boring and self involved caricatures. The groundwork was there for an interesting serial killer with complex motivation but it never developed that way. The constant head hopping was annoying and the ending came out of nowhere.  Cromwell has obviously gotten bored with her characters and it shows.  This is my last Cromwell

column1: I bought this book because I was intrigued by the title. I expected a book that considered words used with criminal intent
column2: in general.   I am disappointed that pornography is the only crime considered here. I wish the author had examined other kinds of cases--not to mention many many more specific examples. There is probably a wealth of legal material on such crimes
column3: if only the author had broadened her horizons.  While I agree that pornography can be a crime
column4: I find the author's arguments used to ban it fundamentally flawed. As other reviewers have noted
column5: this book is argued poorly
column6: uses a shoddy set of examples
column7: and definitely runs afoul of logic.   Had I been interested in an anti-pornography book
column8: I would have preferred one showing practical means to legally limit its damage.   This book does not argue cogently that the first and 14th amendments are NOT considered equally in cases of criminal use of words.  Neither does it effectively show that words can be criminal
column9: or suggest means to prosecute such crimes. A pity.  --Alyssa A. Lappe

column1: Purchased this TV December 10 after much research. Unfortunately for me the TV was defective on arrival! When it is working it is a very nice TV
column2: but the customer support from both Olevia and Target leave a lot to be desired. Target will not replace the item... the corporate policy I am told is the item must be returned via shipping... you are responsible for packing the item and putting it outside for the shipping company to pick up... and once target receives the TV back and it is processed thru receiving a credit will be issued... they say within 30 days... my credit card company AE says it will take 6 - 12 weeks... All this time with no TV
column3: paying interest on the credit card or paying the balance and not be able to purchase another one until everything clears... I don't know about you but that is pretty steep! Now Olevia... though it is under warranty I again must pack up the TV in the original box
column4: ship it back to Olevia and when they receive it back they will ship another one to me... the TV weighs 100lbs packing it up is not easy and again I am without TV for a month or more while the transaction takes place. If I want a TV at the time the defective one is shipped I must give Olevia a $1600 credit card hold while they process the transaction.  EITHER WAY THE CONSUMER GETS SCREWED!! The television has a one year warranty
column5: I purchased the extended warranty... What else could I have done!?! I am told by both TARGET and OLEVIA this policy falls under the "other terms and conditions" ... I wonder why they don't actually say that?  BUYER BEWARE OF TARGET AND OLEVIA!!!

It is a shame that American film classics ( like L and H)  get more attention and love outside of the US than in it. I just bought the Universal Laurel and Hardy 21 Volume Box set which is only available in Europe from Amazon UK (region 2). This set is EVERYTHING people are saying it is. It is a complete film history of the boys which starts with the boys early silent films ( some solo efferts) and goes though the Hal Roach Features. All the prints are restored and of pristine quality. A truly beautiful set and a worthy tribute to the boys. There are some missing films ( I assume for copyright reasons) such as Babes in Toyland
column2: The Devils Brother
column3: Bonnie Scotland and Flying Deuces.   To acomadate these DVDs I bought a region free DVD player off Amazon
column4: which is the only way to go if you really want to collect. The DVD player was very cheap. plays beautfully and  is well worth the investment. As a side note if you have a region free player all the DVDs in the Universal Box set are also availble as single dics
column5: in case you don't want to spend all the money at once or just want a few of the films. If you love Laurel and Hardy this is the only way to go! Anything to screw Hallmark and the corperate monster!! Why did they buy these great films just to sit on them and distribute half-A prints!!!

column1: We have all had that experience as we grow older of being with a beloved elder who has reached an age when their view of the world just doesn't square with reality. It is heartrending to listen to them repeat their nostrums for a better world
column2: and know that they are sadly locked in a worldview that was of their time but clearly mistaken. This is the experience of reading "A People Adrift" if you are among those who came after the Boomers and suffered from that generation's social experiments.   There is nothing to test a worldview like having to suffer under the hand of it. Sadly
column3: the Boomers
column4: of which Mr. Steinfels is one
column5: unleashed a host of experiments into the Church which had more to do with "drugs
column6: sex and rock and roll" than authentic Catholic Faith.  The culture of experimentation and protest rallys led to a culture within the Church that agitated for change in doctrine and discipline. This began with the rejection of Humanae Vitae and has blossomed now into the "demand" for women's ordination
column7: the blessing of homosexuality
column8: the end to celibacy and the democratization of the Faith.   Mr. Steinfels book is a genuine attempt to come to terms with what appears as a crisis in the Catholic Church. But what is saddening is that Mr. Steinfels
column9: like that beloved uncle
column10: is locked in a worldview that imposes a blindness on him. A blindness that has him advocating that the Church take more  doses of the poison that got us sick in the first place!  Somewhere along the way
column11: many of the Boomers and Mr. Steinfels
column12: missed the fact that one chooses a Faith because it is True
column13: not because it should be changed. Politics is the sphere for agitation and change
column14: not Faith. Those Catholics who work at being authenticly Catholic
column15: do so because they recognize that the Faith is True and the more one is conformed to the Faith the more genuinely human they become. No one became more human by seeking to change the Faith!   What Mr. Steinfels and so many of his fellow travellers failed to learn since the 60's is that THEY are the crisis of the Roman Catholic Church because they have spent the last 45 years trying to change the Faith instead of allowing the Faith to change them.   This is why they argue about contraception
column16: they have been using it and have convinced themselves that God doesn't care. He does care
column17: and those who live by the Church's teachings understand the beauty of this teaching from the inside out (not to mention all the other un-PC teachings too).  What is lacking in Mr. Steinfels book is a sense of diverse perspective
column18: for example from those among "The New Faithful" who Colleen Carrol wrote about a few years back. If he had asked the New Faithful about these issues
column19: he might have discovered that the Spring Time in the Church that John Paul II foresaw is sprouting up all around us where Mr. Steinfels' sexual revolutionary worldview is keenly understood and rejected in favor of the Faith of the Apostles and the Saints of the Catholic Church.   Perhaps the greatest indication of the ossification of Mr. Steinfels worldview can be seen in his book's failure to even mention
column20: never mind deeply grapple with
column21: the "Theology of the Body." The closest he comes to it is in this paragraph:   "[T]he contraception debate has been affected by the pope's own extensive writings on sexual morality
column22: which have injected a very different set of terms and categories into the discussion
column23: drawn from his personal blending of traditional scholasticism and contemporary phenomenology. The sifting of profound insight from idealized "nonsense on stilts" has only begun
column24: not made any easier by the density and ambiguity of the pope's language." pg. 265   He doesn't go into the language or open this up at all except to conclude:   "To justify an absolute ban on contraception
column25: however
column26: these approaches always seem to be forced and tortured into supporting a foregone conclusion. The final links in the argument always seem to depend on stark assertions (for example
column27: contraception is 'hostile' or 'degrading' to the spouse; it ruins the 'spontaneity and depth' of the experience) or cloudy rhetoric (such as Pope John Paul's) that simply doesn't ring true to the lived experience of too many religiously serious and sensitive people." p. 265   Granted
column28: the Theology of the Body is not easy material - it is subtle and complex
column29: but it holds more than Mr. Steinfels seems willing to engage.   You have to wonder who the "religiously serious and sensitive people" he is referring to in this passage. Again it seems he is speaking of his cohort who broadly rejected Humanae Vitae
column30: used contraception and continued to recieve the Eucharist despite the mortal sin involved. These people are the ones who have numbed their conscience over contraception. How can he possibly describe them as "religiously serious and sensitive." He needs to attend a Couple to Couple League conference to get his bearings!  I would love to see Mr. Steinfels try to pass this off in front of a hall filled with twenty-somethings who have attended one of Christoper West's presentations on the Theology of the Body. He would be laughed out of the room for being out of touch.   What Communism and Socialism was to Eastern Europe
column31: the Sexual Revolution was to the West and America. The jury is still out as to which revolution cost more lives and devistated more people.   John Paul II brought down Socialism and Communism with his teaching. History will eventually tell how he brought down the Sexual Revolution of the west and restored authentic civilization through the Theology of the Body. For Mr. Steinfels to have missed a discussion of this in his book is very telling of how out of touch he is and how he is a card carring old guard member of the Sexual Revolutionaries.  There is a revolution happening at the grass roots
column32: but unfortunately Mr. Steinfels can't see it coming because unfortnately this beloved older uncle is simply showing his age.

column1: Thomas M. Disch approaches what should be an engaging topic to any SF lover with a holier-than-thou attitude that is both condescending and unappealing. I purchased this book believing it would study the impact of SF on American culture-as the title suggests. Instead
column2: Disch taints his diatribe with his own offensive bias.  Perhaps his sourest assertion is that of SF as the ultimate Boy's Club-run for and by the Men. Why
column3: Disch is so enamored of this male-dominated theory
column4: he proceeds to deny Mary Shelley as the true founder of the genre
column5: and instead raises Edgar Allen Poe to the pedestal instead. His weak reason? He asserts that fewer people read Shelley than Poe. Furthermore
column6: he credits Shelley's parents and husband as the reason behind her success at all. Because God forbid a woman might have laid the foundation for Disch's beloved genre.   The entire book is tainted with these sort of chauvinistic opinions. What I thought would be a dissertation on SF in American culture is little more than one man's attempts to inflict his bias on the public. Spare yourself the indignation of reading such arrogant and bigoted opinions as this
column7: you'll find nothing but rage at the ignorance of some folk

column4: romantic
column5: sexually and culturally exploitative fantasy of the mysterious ancient customs of the elusive far East.  Mr. Tosches would do well to read Edward Said's "Orientalism

column7: right down to his description of one of the people he meets as a "Graham Greene character."  What place do fictional characters have in this supposed journalism?  Furthermore
column8: Mr. Tosches completely avoids the subject of opium addiction and the harm it may bring to the addict and those close to him or her.  This book may be worth reading if you are looking for a contemporary example of exoticism or if you have any doubt that the West still desires to colonize the rest of the world and to use it as a setting in which to act out its fantasies

column1: I started this book the same way I started almost every Marquez book in the past - expecting to be mesmerized and taken away for a while from my world to one of the magical-real worlds of Marquez. The first few tens of pages of this book took off the way those in any other Marquez book do: slowly
column2: but promisingly creating a solid loom to weave a tale on. And then the next tens of pages continued in the same vein
column3: as did the next few chapters
column4: and so on and so forth.   Actually
column5: to be fair
column6: at least a part of the problem could be with my expectations. I was expecting another stunning piece of writing
column7: even if it was a recount of reality. But then
column8: how many readers of Marquez would hold that against me and expect differently of him? After all
column9: his books have been as much about his writing style as they have been about his vivid imagination
column10: haven't they? So that's primarily what I felt let down about in this book - the book just fails to grip. Marquez's writing seems weak like never before (except for the odd brilliant phrase here and there)
column11: and there aren't enough interesting tales to tell anyway. The book never moves beyond the context-setting; there is almost no dramatic arc
column12: and; there is hardly any climatic resolution.   To summarize quickly then
column13: I would recommend this book to very die-hard Marquez fans only. The only real value of this book lies in helping Marquez's readers undestand how he came to be the writer he did. If you are prepared to go through 500 pages of tedium for that
column14: go for it.

column1: I've just returned this unit. It doesn't play videos as advertised.  I was able to get it to properly play .avi files at 320 x 240 resolution...see other review below. But 320x240 gives a postage stamp size picture. At 640 x 480 the playback was full size but jerky and broken....more later.   I have now had 3 different brands of 8" photo frames in my possession: a Phillips
column2: a Pandigital
column3: and this Coby.  I have developed the following list of features in my "ideal" photo frame. First
column4: video playback: I've been taking a lot of video clips with my digital still camera...they come out well and the convenience of not having to lug my camcorder along
column5: and the ability to quickly transfer clip files within/between chips and my computer is attractive. I would like a frame which will play the format my camera is taking (.mov
column6: more later) I'd also like the frame to play a multi-media show...that is
column7: to play movie clips in show presentations
column8: intermixed with .jpg photo files.  Second feature is to play .wma music files
column9: in addition to MP3. This is because I have a non-Ipod personal music player. All my music is in .wma format because it is roughly half the file size of MP3. Third
column10: I would like a timer on my frame...set it to come on in the morning
column11: off at night
column12: for example. Fourth
column13: I'd like an audio or speaker out feature. None of these frames has home theater-like sound
column14: and I have an extra pair of computer speakers I'd probably hook up. Video out could come in handy too. Fifth
column15: I'd like to be able to rotate stills from within the frame's software
column16: manually or automatically. Yes
column17: you can rotate them in the computer
column18: but the frame may or may not preserve the rotation. (This may depend on which photo edit program you are using.) Sixth
column19: I'd like a folder hierarchy file management system in the frame's software. Especially with the huge chips now available
column20: I see an advantage to push a couple of buttons and change the picture set (folder)
column21: rather than switching out chips.  Here is where the 3 units I've had stack up
column22: followed by my next (fourth) unit.   I am keeping the Pandigital....which Costco has for $140. It plays .mov video files
column23: but not within a slideshow. It has no speaker out jack and the sound is tinny. It requires MP3 music files. It permits picture rotation.  No folder management system. No clock/timer. No ability to play stills/video intermixed. I think the Coby and Phillips picture quality is brighter but the Pandigital is ok.  The phillips didn't play video
column24: and since it also had a software glitch when I returned it I decided to look elsewhere. (no remote and no music with the philips either.)  The Coby won't play my videos
column25: even after I used my converter program to try about 10 different MP4 and AVI variations. The Coby plays .wma music files
column26: won't rotate stills
column27: has no folder system
column28: no clock/timer. It has a speaker out jack. It does not permit intermixing video and stills in one multimedia show. Picture quality is fully equal to Philips
column29: generally the recognized standard. If all you want is photos
column30: and never turn your camera sideways
column31: this unit will be a good value.  Another unit I'd like to get to play with would be the Image Moments model by Digitalfoci. I've exchanged emails with someone there who clearly knows what they are talking about and I believe this unit will intermix my photos and videos.

column1: Whatever felicity Edwards manages in this work
column2: do not credit the ideas represented to Edwards himself.  All of his central points on freedom are no more than a Christian appropriation of secular English philosophy in Hobbes
column3: somewhat in Locke
column4: and certainly of David Hume.  In the old philosophy
column5: choice is an illusion
column6: because in any course of action we are determined necessarily by our nature; Edwards agrees fully
column7: adding only that our nature gets some extra help from God when it comes to sanctification.      He advances the idea that in every snapshot of human life
column8: we make decisions in accordance with our nature and disposition.  Free will is compatabilist in that we have no autonomy other than to follow our greatest desire in any given instance.  Not only does this exposition rule out the chance for true virtue--some good thing we do which we might not have done--but Edwards also has a hard time explaining how God is not the author of evil
column9: given that human decisions are consistently determined according to a divine decree

column1: So the truth was stated finally by William Dembski in this popular account explaining the origins and principles of "Intelligent Design"; in which he admits that there is  indeed a religious link to what he claims is primarily a scientific hypothesis (But a scientific hypothesis proposed originally by William Paley hundreds of years ago
column2: which was rejected soundly by leading scientists afterwards.). There is nothing in this book which explains how science works
column3: by careful observation and rigorous testing of ideas (hypotheses). Those ideas which are accepted through this rigorous scientific method are either incorporated within longstanding scientific theories
column4: or may themselves be the incipient idea(s) of a new scientific theory which replaces an outmoded one (Most notably
column5: in exactly the same manner that Einstein's Theory of General Relativy and the Theory of Quantum Mechanics replaced Newton's theories of physics
column6: known now as classical mechanics; the latter are now subsumed within the two 20th Century theories forming the core of modern physics.). Dembski clearly doesn't understand how modern science works; he pretends to have such understanding via sloppy logic and intellectually dishonest statements which occur frequently throughout this book.  Intelligent Design is not scientific since it does not adhere to any of the long-established tenets about science itself (Intelligent Design has been judged correctly as the latest flavor of creationism enjoying some popularity amongst fundamentalist Protestant Christians; one notable biologist has referred to it as "reborn creationism".). It can not be tested
column7: simply because it does not generate any testable hypotheses. Moreover
column8: despite claims to the contrary
column9: I have yet to see any peer-reviewed articles testing Intelligent Design; instead
column10: every single book and article published in praise of this idea is merely an attack on the Modern Synthesis Theory of Evolution; this evolutionary theory is itself the central underlying theory for contemporary biology as much as General Relativity and Quantum Mechanics are for contemporary physics (Any current scientific controversies about the Modern Synthesis are related to understanding the tempo and mode of evolution as seen from the fossil record and the relative importance of random genetic drift as the primary means of causing evolutionary change; they
column11: themselves
column12: do not mean that the Modern Synthesis is in trouble as the successful unifying theory it has been for nearly a century in explaining biological phenomena.). And Intelligent Design is not a new idea at odds with mainstream science
column13: but rather the latest incarnation of an idea dating from the 17th Century regarding a "Great Chain of Being" which was subsequently tested - and rejected - by Enlightenment and later scientists
column14: most notably naturalists
column15: leading up to of course Darwin and Wallace
column16: who almost simultaneously came up with the Theory of Evolution via Natural Selection (The Modern Synthesis Theory is its direct descendant
column17: and includes its principles
column18: as well as evidence from biological sciences as diverse as genetics
column19: molecular biology and developmental biology
column20: which were unknown to both Darwin and Wallace.).   The arguments presented by Dembski are not only intellectually dishonest
column21: but now
column22: irrelevant
column23: as determined by Republican Federal Judge John Jones in his landmark
column24: historic decision for the Kitzmiller vs. Dover Board of Education trial; Jones concluded that intelligent design is a religious doctrine masquerading as science (His decision is posted online at: htttp://www2.ncseweb.org/kvd/all_legal/2005-12-20_kitzmiller_decision.pdf). Furthermore
column25: thoughtful
column26: reasonable conservatives like Charles Krauthammer and George Will have written lucid
column27: brilliant columns praising the theory of evolution via natural selection
column28: and condemning intelligent design for being an unscientific
column29: religious doctrine.   There are other
column30: more important - and intellectually sound - books available on the so-called "creation vs. evolution" controversy
column31: which I regard as more worthy than any of Dembski's self-serving defenses of Intelligent Design. Philosopher Robert Pennock's "Tower of Babel" is a splendid historical overview and philosophical deconstruction of creationism
column32: including the best written rebuke of "Intelligent Design" which I've come across (He also covers Dembski's "explanatory filter"
column33: and demolishes it too from a philosophical perspective.). Philip Kitcher
column34: another philosopher
column35: published "Abusing Science: The Case Against Creationism" back in the early 1980s
column36: but his arguments are still quite valid today. My friend Ken Miller's "Finding Darwin's God" has an eloquent critique of Intelligent Design
column37: focusing on Michael Behe's mousetrap model of irreducible complexity which claims to bestow validity on Intelligent Design. Distinguished American Museum of Natural History (AMNH) invertebrate paleobiologist Niles Eldredge offers yet another brilliant critique of Intelligent Design in his book "Darwin: Discovering the Tree of Life"
column38: the elegant companion volume to the AMNH Darwin exhibition which he curated
column39: soon to embark on a tour taking it to many of North America's and Great Britain's finest science museums. And last
column40: but not least
column41: Eugenie Scott
column42: Executive Director
column43: National Center for Science Education (www.ncseweb.org)
column44: has written a fine textbook on this issue
column45: "Evolution vs. Creationism". All of these books are more desirable than Dembski's "Intelligent Design:The Bridge Between Science & Theology". Otherwise
column46: if you insist on purchasing this book
column47: then perhaps you might choose to acquire instead a splendid text devoted to Klingon cosmology (Neither Klingon cosmology nor "Intelligent Design" can be regarded as scientific
column48: since both depend on faith
column49: not reason
column50: to validate their principles.).

We received our Kinyo UV-230C 2-way VHS rewinder/cleaner yesterday and tried it out today. The very first tape that we rewound (a much-loved Disney video) slammed against the beginning of the tape so hard that when we pulled the tape out it was hanging out of the cassette housing
column2: crinkled. I'm afraid that repeated rewindings of a given tape could break the tape.  I had a blank T-120 tape so I put that in and fast-forwarded to the other end to see if it would happen in that direction. It did. I rewound that tape to the beginning and this time it ended properly
column3: so this problem is not consistent.   The tape that was rewound initially was not a full 120-minute tape (the movie is 77 minutes long). I suspect that the sensors on the unit are calibrated for 120-minute tapes and will not necessarily treat shorter tapes as gently. (More tape = more weight = slower overall motor speed?) But I'm not going to experiment with tapes we want to keep! This unit will be returned ASAP. I may exchange it for another in hopes that this particular unit is out of whack.

I do not propose that I am an expert on Zen or even Buddhism in general but I have read a few books on Buddhism by Thich Nhat Hanh

column7: but unfortunately he comes as an arrogant
column8: elitist
column9: full of prejudices. He does not miss any opportunity to put down other religions or even other sects of Buddhism. Only Zen as practiced by the Rinzai sect is pure
column10: strong and generally worthy of pursuit. Any form of spiritualism from the West is of course hopeless since the western mind cannot escape the conditioning of logical thinking.  Any spiritualism from India is complex
column11: ceremonial and not practical. Other sects of Buddhism generally do not have true comprehension
column12: lost their way focusing on non-essentials etc. He reserves his most disparaging remarks for Indian religions and monks (and does his best to show that though Buddhism originated in India
column13: it is really the Chinese and Japanese due to their practical nature made something of it).  Is this just the standard fundamentalism/ misplaced racism?  I will definitely read other books on Zen and go beyond this author.

column1: When my husband developed acid reflux
column2: it was recommended that he lower his carb intake. As long time lacto vegetarians (no fish
column3: meat or eggs
column4: yes to dairy)
column5: this sounded particularly challenging.  I bought 3 different low carb cookbooks from Amazon a month ago: "Low-carb Vegetarian" by Celia Brooks Brown
column6: "Carb Conscious Vegetarian: 150 Delicious Recipes For Healthy Lifestyle" by Robin Robertson and "The New Glucose Revolution Low GI Vegetarian Cookbook: 80 Delicious Vegetarian and Vegan Recipes Made Easy with the Glycemic Index" by Dr. Jennie Brand-Miller   After a month of consistent cooking I have rarely used Brown's "Low-carb Vegetarian" which is laden with ~50% recipes that use eggs.  There are some great recipes in there if you eat eggs though.  On the other hand
column7: my copy of "Carb Conscious Vegetarian: 150 Delicious Recipes For Healthy Lifestyle" by Robin Robertson is a bit dog-eared already.  Delicious
column8: innovative recipes with new ways to use foods common to the vegetarian and wonderful exploring of unusual but easily available new veggies and protein options.  "The New Glucose Revolution Low GI Vegetarian Cookbook"  by Dr. Jennie Brand-Miller was rich with information and great recipes.  It taught me a lot.   But by far Robertson's "Carb Conscious Vegetarian" is the best.  I will say that I don't know either of these authors and am doing this to help a buyer who may be wondering which one to get...  By the way
column9: a low carb/lower acid diet has really eased the acid reflux my husband suffers from. We eat a main meal during the day and a protein drink at night
column10: even if working: switched when consuming. And I am starting to lose weight...  Hope this helps!

column1: A neighbor gave me this book to read.  I have read the DaVinci Code and I thought it was good fiction mixed with some fact.  Of Course Dan Brown strings together many unrelated truths half truths and fabrications to make his story interesting
column2: so it is quite easy to write an expose showing where he stepped over the line.  This critique of The DaVinci Code goes too far the other way trying to spin "Orthodox" Christianity as the only true religion and the "Orthodox" point of view the only "true" history of the last 2000 years.  The authors have dumbed down the subject matter
column3: omitted information and scholarship contrary to their point of view
column4: and created a book that borders on propaganda.  One part of the book that I found very annoying was the failure to address the historical excesses of institutional or "Orthodox" Christianity.  The Authors criticise Brown for writing that the Church (both Catholic and Protestant) Burned or otherwise murdered "Millions" of heretics.  The authors concede that the number is closer to 50 or 60 thousand.  So which is worse?  Making a mistake concerning the number of heretics murdered?  Or defending the institution that actually murdered thousands of people?  (And I would assume if we add in the Crusades both against the Muslims and the "heretics" we'd probably get a lot closer to the million than thousand figure.)  Another spin made by the authors actually caused me to laugh out loud.  You should read how these "Orthodox" scholars are spinning the female responsibility for the fall/oppression of females nexus.  Here's what they say.  The original sin in the Bible was Adam not working hard enough to spiritually protect his family.  This is a very "unorthodox" and "unbiblical spin designed to distract you from the fact that Judaism
column5: Islam and Christianity have for centuries oppressed women because Eve ate the Fruit First.  What does Brother Paul say about it     11 Let the woman learn in silence with all subjection.  12 But I suffer not a woman to teach
column6: nor to usurp* authority over the man
column7: but to be in silence*.  13 For Adam was first formed
column8: then Eve.  14 And Adam was not deceived
column9: but the woman being deceived was in the transgression.  15 Notwithstanding she* shall be saved in childbearing
column10: if they continue in faith and charity and holiness with sobriety   I think Paul would be very angry reading the Author's attempt to put a "new age" spin the scripture to fit a more modern interpretation of the story.  This spin also flies in the face of Christian History.  And I do not feel any better about it even though the Authors point out that pagan cultures have abused women as well.  So what?  Do two wrongs make a right? If Orthodox Christianity is "true" why did it take the institution almost 2000 years to figure out that men and women were equal and figure out that the story in Genesis and Paul's exposition of it were wrong?   Ultimately this book fails because it is plain dishonest.  Yes it points out some issues where Dan Brown obviously inflates the truth
column11: or even creates it out of nothing.  Brown's book has historical errors and it does have a point of view and an agenda.  However
column12: this does not excuse the propaganda and misdirection contained in "Cracking Da Vinci's Code."

column1: Mr. Lord could have written a good book.  He has the tools and the know-how
column2: and he did his research.  He made one fatal error
column3: however.  Actually he made not one
column4: but two mistakes.  The first mistake is that his starting point is wrong.  As a trained journalist
column5: he does as a journalist does - he keeps trying to find "dirt"
column6: or rather manufacture dirt - all in order to give us a "balanced view".  One can't help feeling
column7: as one reads interview after interview
column8: that Mr. Lord has somehow picked only the disgruntled
column9: caustic and jealous remarks to print.  The second mistake was in underestimating "James Herriot"'s fans
column10: and familys goodwill towards him.  He treats his subject manner as just another subject
column11: as routine grist for the gossip mill
column12: but Alf Wight was not that kind of person. He was a person totally out of Mr. Lord's scope and understanding.  He underestimated Mr. Wight's fans and family's tolerance for having his name besmearched
column13: and
column14: indeed
column15: his son wrote another book in response
column16: a beautiful book about his father
column17: and in it he easily refutes all Mr. Lord's accusations - and turns Mr. Lord into a laughingstock.  Because anybody who has read the two books side by side - which I just did - would realize that Mr. Lord has indeed made a laughingstock of himself.  While there are some good parts to the book
column18: they are very much overshadowed by the other parts.  There are two good chapters - in the middle - which were written factually - the chapters dealing with the content of James Herriot's first books
column19: and the publishing history.  There is a good reason why this is so - Mr. Lord was indeed part of the publishing business and would have been privy to that sort of information.    But much of the book is exactly what he accuses James Herriot of writing - pure fiction.  It would take too long to point out every one of Mr. Lord's mistakes
column20: but I would like to simply write just a few of the many mistakes Mr. Lord makes.  The rest
column21: if you still want to read this book
column22: you could find out for yourself.  The first accusation Mr. Lord makes about James Herriot is that Alf Wight did not write a semi-autobiography
column23: but rather pure fiction.  He maintains that even if this were so
column24: it would not matter
column25: because the books are still entertaining.  With that salve to his conscience
column26: he methodically starts to take apart many stories in an effort to prove them fiction.    His first assertion - that it would not matter if it were actually fiction
column27: is simply not true.  It would matter
column28: and matter a lot
column29: to both his fans and friends and family.  His son says as much in his book- that it would matter a lot if his books are fiction.  Fortunately for us
column30: Mr. Lord does not bring a single proof that could stand up to scrutiny.  His method seems to be - I don't think this story is true
column31: so it's probably not.  That's it.  Not one single proof.  For instance
column32: he says that Alf Wight's memoirs of his war years are fiction - because the dates are wrong.  He says that Alf Wight joined the army in March
column34: and was discharged two years later
column35: and therefore his story that he was called up to the RAF while his wife was expecting their first child is a fictional story.  His son
column36: in his book "The Real James Herriot" explains that he enlisted in the RAF in March
column37: but was NOT CALLED UP until 15 months later
column38: in November 1942
column39: when his wife was indeed
column40: expecting their first child.  Is it possible his son and wife might know when he joined the RAF better than Mr. Lord?  Especially since Mr. Lord actually admits that he is going from hearsay - since the RAF would not give Mr. Lord access to their records
column41: claiming that they were still classified?  This should be enough of a blooper to discredit Mr. Lord; however
column42: there are many
column43: many more - so many that it would be funny if it were not also very
column44: very sad that someone could so easily print a book full of lies and get away with it (by prefacing all his explanations with "perhaps" he covers himself from libel
column45: I suppose).  Another example of Mr. Lord's innuendos -  he quotes from one of Mr. Herriot's books that James Herriot was taken aback by the red (and squished) face of his newborn son
column46: and asked the nurse if there was something wrong with the child.  Mr. Lord asks how can this story be true if he is a vet?  Just so
column47: explains his son
column48: animals are born much more fully formed than humans are.  (A horse is born already able to walk as soon as he is born).  Mr. Lord falls flat in the mud.  Mr. Lord quotes James Herriot as saying that 90% of his stories are based on real life.  Mr. Lord asks how that can  be - when the Herriot books say that he joined Seigfried's practice in 1937
column49: when he actually started working there in 1941?  Mr. Lord
column50: I think we are ready for a lesson in English.  Do you know what the words "based on true life" means?  "Based" means "based"
column51: not "actually
column52: exactly
column53: fact".  When he first started writing
column54: he was hoping to remain anonymous
column55: and therefore disguised his stories so that the people he was writing about would not recognize themselves.  He changed the location of his practice to the Dales
column56: he changed the dates
column57: he even changed the characters - some from a man to a woman
column58: for example.  He put two stories into one
column59: etc. etc.  This all falls under the heading of "based on real life".   There are many
column60: many more examples of this in his book - where he "proves" that James Herriot was writing fiction - and he has no proof whatsoever.  Not even one single time.    If there is one person writing fiction
column61: that person is Mr. Lord.  Mr. Lord spends two entire chapters on a conjecture of how Alf's childhood might have been like - all based on the assumption that Alf had grown up in grinding poverty.  These chapters become almost a farce when we read his sons portrayal of his real childhood - although his parents were not rich they were certainly never poor
column62: and Alf had a very happy childhood.  He also explains the economics of why this was so.  Which puts Mr. Lord's two chapters of conjecture on how Alf's unhappy childhood might have been like in the category it deserves - pure fiction.  While the poverty of the under-class in Glasgow in the 1920's is certainly very sad
column63: it definitely does not belong in a biography of Alf Wight.  Another mistake that Mr. Lord makes is that he constantly contradicts himself.  For example
column64: in one chapter he spends many paragraphs conjecturing on why Alf was always poor
column65: when he should have had a thriving practice - and the fanciful castles he builds in the air are very elaborate indeed.  And yet in another chapter he quotes a neighbor as saying - "oh
column66: they claimed they didn't have any money but that wasn't true.  They had money for everthing - a tennis court
column68: etc."  This came across as a vitriolic statement
column69: but of course in contradiction to his earlier assumption that he was poor.  Mr. Lord
column70: you can't really have it both ways
column71: can you?  Another example - he constantly quotes Eddie Steanton throughout the book
column72: with all kinds of outrageous comments
column73: yet he himself quotes one of Eddie's colleagues "oh
column75: you can't believe everything he says".  And later in the book it comes out that Eddie had had a falling out with Alf Wight
column76: and I would assume that his "memories" might be somewhat tainted by those sentiments.  And yet Mr. Lord accepts Mr. Streaton as a fully credible source.  As matters stand now
column77: this book is laughable and barely deserving of a review - except for one thing:  if Mr. Wight's son would not have written his own biography
column78: Mr. Lord's fictious book would have remained as the factual biography of  Alf Wight.  He would have succeeded in besmirching Alf Wight's name with his book full of lies (oh
column80: fiction).  The fact that his son wrote his own biography
column81: and a beautiful and moving one at that
column82: has turned Mr. Lord's book into a joke
column83: a book that his fans would not touch with a ten-foot pole
column84: but Mr. Lord did not know that in advance.  He tried to change James Herriot's fans opinion of their idol
column85: by trying to find "dirt" on him
column86: and that was a very low thing.  The fact is that he fortunately did not succeed
column87: but that does not take away from what Mr. Lord tried to do.  Mr. Lord

column1: Since the end of the Cold War
column2: writers and political commentators have suggested that we have entered a new war - a war brought on by the "clash of civilizations". The theory
column3: as told by writers such as Samuel Huntington and Bernard Lewis
column4: amongst others
column5: suggests that "the west" is at war with Islam and that this global divide will replace the earlier Cold War acrimony. Not for any particular reason or circumstance is this war being waged against us
column6: they suggest
column7: but merely because of its violent nature and hatred of western civilization. It is the very essence of Islam
column8: a religion that does not share core values with ours which is the problem
column9: and the only way to contain its violence is to be merciless in our efforts to do so.     Aside from this rhetoric being advocated as "fact" by news organizations such as FOX cable news
column10: CNN
column11: and most newspapers
column12: this thesis has been regularly used by the powerful to justify wars. The U.S. used it to justify the war with Iraq and Afghanistan; Serbs and Croatians used it to justify ethnic cleansing of Bosnian and Kosovar Muslims; and it is used by Israel to justify their "war" with Palestinians.    The Clash of Civilization rhetoric suggests that the world will always be at war. As opposed to the Cold War with the Soviet Union (a country only in existence for less than a century)
column13: Islam is an old religion spread  throughout the world. The framework of the Cold war between the Communist "east" and the capitalist "west" did prove useful in making this theory. The new war is between the rational
column14: democratic
column15: secular
column16: and tolerant "west" and the irrational
column17: fundamentalist
column18: and violent "east". Orwell could have predicted this well: the new enemy created on the morning after the old enemies fell. It almost seems that for the "west"  to feel at home with itself
column19: it needs to be at constant war with some "other". Perhaps it provides some guidance to what we are and what we are not - we are simply not the "other". Perhaps Chomsky and others who have suggested that a major reason that states fight wars is for domestic reasons and for the disciplining of a nation's own population are right.     Not according to the "clash theorists" like Bernard Lewis
column20: who claim that the clash will continue as long as Islam exists. He believes that the radical Islamic militants are not deviants from Islam
column21: but actually have a more correct view of it. They will therefore likely become more influential over the years. But if such a clash really existed

column1: If you're looking for a book that will give you practical
column2: nuts and bolts
column3: down to brass tacks advice on how to make a quality
column4: professional looking DV movie on an ultra-low budget then "Digital Moviemaking" by Scott Billups is NOT the book you're looking for. This book was obviously written by a tech-nerd for other tech-nerds.  The majority of this book is technical information and history and should instead be entitled:"Hi-Definition Video Moviemaking" as this is what Billups spends the majority of the book discussing. There is precious little in this book that a low-budget filmmaker will find of use. Billups and co. are apparently of the opinion that it's a waste of time shooting on anything other than HD video or 35mm film and seem to have nothing but contempt for Independent
column5: low-budget filmmakers.  If you are an aspiring filmmaker who has a good movie idea and want to know how to shoot it on an ultra-low budget then don't waste your money buying this book. I recommend instead reading "Digital Filmmaking 101" by Dale Newton and John Gaspard which is a much better book that explains in layman's terms how to shoot a quality
column6: professional looking movie on digital video. It was written by 2 guys who have made good low-budget films and have a lot more respect for and understanding of independent
column7: low-budget filmmakers than Scott Billups.
