column1: Unfortunatley
column2: Ms. Ornstein's book is not based on actual research
column3: but rather on pre-established suppositions. The gender climate of a school is best evaluated by looking at two factors - student grades and disciplinary actions.  If male students have lower grades than female students
column4: and/or if more male students are disciplined than female students
column5: then it is clear that the school is anti-boy and is simply not trying to teach male students.  Fortunatley
column6: parents are waking up to this fact
column7: and there have been several lawsuits (most notably in Wisconsin) challenging public schools gender bias against male students.  The so called "gender-fair" class menitoned in this book wasn't - since not as many male as female students received "A's".    This book also does not evaluate issues outside of school.  For example
column8: the best measure of the status of a demographic group is to look at mortality rate.  The fact that male students in all demographic groups have a higher mortality rate than female students is not discussed.  This is particularly important since a major contributing factor to this trend is the fact that adolescent males have a higher suicide rate than adolescent females.  Orenstein also does not discuss this gender gap in arrest rate.  Again
column9: the "health" of a demographic group in school is easy to evaluate - simply look at grades and discipline.

column1: After reading the book Medicine Woman and the San Francisco Review of Books on the back which says this is an Autobiographical I have to question a few things.     I come from Manitoba and have lived there over 50 years.  I've never heard of a Crowley and the Cree First Nations in Manitoba that I was raised with would not be seeing a Kokopelli or a Kachina.  It's not part of their culture.  The last and final huge mistake is the fact that most of this story could not have taken place outside without huge huge bottles of mosquitoe repellant as anyone who lives in the bush in Manitoba knows especially those who may have a reason to go naked in the woods.  Perhaps Lynn shouldn't be peddling her strange brand of spiritualism as true when it's not.  There are enough charlatans in the world without one stealing someone's culture and calling it her own for the sake of the almight dollar.    Carol

(this review is of the Spyware edition) NIS takes 25Megs of ram - ok for an all-in-one (if you have <256Megs your lightweight CPU can't carry enough armor to make Windows really Zero-day Net safe IMHO)  NIS has most of the features I look for in a firewall/spyware/virus scanner/intrusion detector

column3: and some that do seem to fight every attempt to make them work.  Even after LiveUpdate this week
column4: One buggy automatic firewall rule autoloaded
column5: and port 80 was open listening half 'naked' on the Internet. I replaced it
column6: and at the first passing probe my rule was erased
column7: autoreplaced
column8: naked again. Only after I stumbled onto the secret trick (add a block all rule after the pass rules) did it close it. It took 11 clicks (!) just to add the block all rule - miserable! The log is a nightmare - pages of long sentences explaining "permitted once" 200 times
column9: no actual info 	until I click on one of them. What's worse is
column10: none of them I checked WERE "permitted once" IIRC.  NIS detected 2 trojan/spywares
column11: but could not remove either.  Enabling program component monitoring started an avalanche of popups
column12: all suggesting I block access

column14: totally useless even if you know the names of every evil dll not yet invented.  If you have more than 1 or 2 programs not in the automatic ruleset
column15: plan to either "permit all" or spend many hours actually writing the same set of 3 rules over and over for every autoupdating program you use - assuming you understand TCP vs UDP etc. Why no "permit all local + DNS + outbound port 80" choice? That would mean 1/10 the work! Jetico lets me pick "web browser" ruleset
column16: so its UI from Hell gets used once per category.  After spending all day and half the night getting it working
column17: I discover that it is not possible to save my precious rules - or to reload them. I would be less furious if I had a fresh install of windows
column18: but not much.  All good
column19: until a program autoupdates
column20: and 3 more rules to write. Too angry for words. Jetico lets me clone the old rules or edit them to update the program sig.  I would not use NIS if you paid me 10 times its price.

column1: Overall this series is quite good.  As a former Marine
column2: I've found that the authors do a bang-up job of recalling long-forgotten memories of service and sacrifice.  They've managed to combine snappy action and plotting with well-realized characters.  Characters (such as Charlie Bass) who's fate we deeply care about.  That being said
column3: "A World of Hurt
column4: the tenth and latest in the Starfist"  series is a distinct disappointment.  After the last two books in the series
column5: "Kingdom's Fury" and "Lazarus Rising
column6: we had the chance to really get to know several of the main characters: Charlie Bass, Lew Conorado, Brigadier Sturgeon, Cpl. Doyle, etc.  They really came alive and of course there was the entire subplot with the supposed death and disappearance of Bass on Kingdom.    This was a major story arc, with the Marines grieving terribly at his loss."  However
column7: his return from the dead is barely mentioned or explored in this novel.  His promotion to officer status was similarly glossed over.  It would have been quite interesting to have seen the reaction of the Marines to his return
column8: rather than the matter of fact acceptance of his miraculous
column9: "Lazarus" like revival.  Or failing that
column10: I would have enjoyed seeing the internal conflicts that Bass experienced as he assumed his new role of officer rather than enlisted man. They were hinted at in some of the throwaway lines in the book but nothing more. The Bass storyline is but one example of many that could have been fleshed out in this book.    Overall
column11: it seems that the authors simply phoned this one in.  Especially telling is the excruciating detail with which everyday activities are described.  For Heaven's sake!  If readers have been with the Marines of the 34th FIST to this point then they don't need to read the line "fast ride on a rough road" one more time.  Ugh.  Here's hoping that the next installment serves to advance the overall story rather than serving as a placeholder

column1: Coltman gives his work credibility by freely admitting two important truths: Castro enjoys the warm support of a majority of the Cuban people
column2: and Guevara and Castro were not at daggers drawn
column3: but remained comrades-in-arms to the very end of Guevara's life. But with every political event and turning-point in the revolution that he describes
column4: Coltman systematically distorts or omits the impact of popular mobilization by the Cuban people. He leaves out the milllions who marched in favour of socialism during the Mariel boat lifts in 1980. He says nothing of the hundreds of thousands who poured into voluntary work brigades during the fight against bureaucracy and stagnation in the late 1980s -- under the leadership of the Cuban Communist Party. He insists on seeing the revolution as the work of one talented megalomaniac
column5: leaving out the facts in order to bolster this view. In 1960
column6: for example
column7: the Cuban delegation to the UN in New York was greeted by enthusiastic crowds in Harlem when Malcolm X arranged for the Cubans to stay at Harlem's Hotel Theresa. The delegation had been subject to politically-motivated and racist harrassment in their Manhattan hotel. Coltman portrays the incident as a shameful foray into the realm of prostitutes and shabby digs. Completely missing the point. As does his whole book

column1: This book made me want to 'go viking' - in other words take a long trek away from it!  Why are people always so accepting of the 'fact' that men in early history 'must' have been cruel and stubborn
column2: coarse and violent therefore it's ok for hero's in books to behave so.  I don't actually agree with any of that. Historical fact shows that men
column3: then as now
column4: could be caring
column5: sharing beings who actually liked their wives and kids! William the Conqueror adored his wife as did John of Lancaster his Kathryn and Henry his Eleanor of Aquitaine.   So why did the hero here have to be so unsympathetic and the heroine so accepting of her treatment at his hands - human nature is diverse and being a Viking in the 8/9thC didn't make you any more liable to be a thug than living in the 21stC makes every man a saint does it?  I heartily agree with a lot of the other reviewers that for the author to subscribe to the idea that violent times create violent people and therefore 'Viking' must equate with thuggery is short-sighted and trite and boring to read

column1: I bought this book primarily for information regarding accounting and general ledger systems. I read all the great reviews here and thought this would be a great book.  I am very disappointed.  The entire section on accounting is only 40 pages and contains only a cursory overview of accounting systems and structures. They include a CD with the book which is supposed to contain actual SQL data structures but you have to pay them $350.00 to unlock the CD.  Given the depth of the book I would be reluctant to risk paying them that much for simple data structures which you can easily find elsewhere on the web for free.  In all honesty I have not studied this book fully but in my opinion it was a waste of money and I will try to return it to Amazon.

column1: The thesis of this book is that the 9-11-01 terrorist attacks wouldn't have happened if it weren't for Bill Clinton's mistakes. That is incorrect. The 9-11-01 terrorist attacks wouldn't have happened if it weren't for G.W. Bush's mistakes. 9-11 could have easily been prevented. The CIA and the FBI were giving Bush thorough warnings about how Bin Laden was a potential threat to the U.S. and the White House had documents that plainly stated "Bin Laden determined to attack in the U.S." Bush was on vacation the whole time that he could've been looking into that. Instead
column2: he decided he would rather be out golfing and fishing than preventing an assault on American soil. Condoleeza Rice
column3: the then national security advisor
column4: now Secretary of State
column5: committed perjury at the 9-11 Commission by saying under oath that the documents said that Bin Laden was not determined to attack in the U.S. When in fact the documents said the exact opposite.   I do not recommend this book.

column1: I have always been a loyal and devoted fan of Goldy and her cast of close knit friends and relatives
column2: but "Chopping Spree
column3: was a book I had to stop reading after the first 50 pages. I found it lacking considerably from her other books.  Arch turns into a demon of sorts, while his mother is trying to get hold of her caffeine/chocolate habit and .....where is poor Tom?  I expected him to ask for a divorce in this book, because he always seems there for Goldy, but she is never there for him in any way, except as people who share the same house.  I found Marla ...who I had dearly loved in the other books,....to be an annoying snob,...not in character for her.  Mott-Davidson focuses too much on her ex-husband in her books. I am beginning to think she might do with some psychiatric help that she should have gotten in the beginning. Enough is enough.  The Jerk" is in jail.  Her relationship with her present husband Tom needs to be more fine tuned.  Sometimes you forget she is even married
column4: but then someone has to nurse her back to health when she gets hit in the head
column5: etc.  Poor Tom.  I don't think I will read anymore of her books until I can see some positive reviews....more 5 stars.  I just looked at the reviews on her latest book and they were worse than this one. Maybe there is a time a writer should stop for a while and step back and re-evaluate her story character.  Diane?

column1: In Heresy
column2: Magic
column3: and Witchcraft in Early Modern Europe
column4: Gary K. Waite attempts to tie together the various persecutions that took place in Early Modern Europe.  Whether persecution was aimed against Christian heretics
column5: witches
column6: or Jews
column7: its purpose was always the same: reinforcing current orthodoxy against growing doubt.  Thus
column8: Waite claims that the more pluralistic the society
column9: the less fringe groups were persecuted. 	This book is flawed.  Waite argues his thesis tendentiously
column10: citing portions of scholarship on Early Modern Europe that support his claims and ignoring scholarship that would question them.  The book is a brief synthesis of other scholars' works
column11: and Waite's contribution consists of mere assertions that lack supporting evidence.  Waite does not engage the sources of Early Modern Europe; instead he trusts others to do the work of research for him.  When he quotes a primary source
column12: his citation is always from some secondary literature.  This form of "researching" may be fine for a survey of the historiography
column13: but Waite is attempting to argue a thesis. 	Not only is his methodology wanting
column14: but also his thesis is much too simplistic.  Waite argues as societies become more pluralistic
column15: persecution of the "Other" lessens.  He cites example after example of how the reigning orthodoxy persecuted the "Other" in order to strengthen its position in society.  Places like the Netherlands and Maria Theresa's Austria
column16: however
column17: did not persecute irrationally because of tolerance for a multiplicity of ideas.  This formulation is inadequate.  Waite fails to grapple with the religious situation in Spain in the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries.  Spain was the most ethnically and religiously diverse region in Europe
column18: and its variegated population managed a high level of cooperation for centuries.  Instead of peaceful toleration
column19: however
column20: this region led to some of the most intense persecution of the "Other." 	Waite's explanation of the Jewish situation in Early Modern Europe also has many problems.  He asserts
column21: "Jews ... were officially tolerated in the Christian west because they proved an extremely useful
column22: if unwitting
column23: ally in the campaign to expel religious doubt from the hearts of Christian believers" (19).  As a causal claim
column24: this statement is ludicrous.  Waite implies a conspiracy by the Church to use Jews to quench Christian doubt.  The evidence does not support this assertion.  (His reasons for the persecution of women during the witch-hunts similarly lack evidentiary substantiation.) 	Not only are Waite's methods and assertions suspect
column25: but he lacks a fundamental understanding of the subject that he is trying to address.  In the book's introduction
column26: Waite writes
column27: "Religion is always nonrational
column28: for its tenets cannot be proven by empirical testing" (3).  This statement belies a misunderstanding of rationalism
column29: religion
column30: or both.  As a system of knowledge
column31: rationalism is not dependent on evidence or empirical testing.  Rationalism relies on human reason.  Just as religion cannot be empirically tested
column32: neither can mathematics.  Rationalism and empiricism are competing systems of knowledge.  Waite's conflation of the two demonstrates a positivist bent
column33: and positivism is self-referentially absurd.  Thus
column34: Waite founds his philosophical approach to this subject upon a defective meta-narrative
column35: and readers should be skeptical of his claims

It's always discouraging when self-professed Christians lie
column2: and Dembski purposefully perpetuates a lie in order to further his ID claims.  The lie is that evolution by natural selection is "random."  Most famous is the analogy of a hurricane sweeping through a junkyard and creating a jumbo jet.  That's so ridiculously impossible that evolution must be impossible
column3: too.  Right?  But only the genetic mutations underlying evolution are random.  And being random
column4: most of them are in fact terrible failures
column5: frequently causing the fetus carrying them to spontaneously abort.    Only those mutations that do not harm the carrier can be passed on to future generations.  That is a non-random selection process.  In general
column6: only those mutations that actively benefit the carrier are likely to spread throughout the population.  That is a non-random selection process
column7: too. (That's a bit simplified
column8: but the general point holds--even harmful mutations that spread do so non-randomly.)  Dembski's claim that all non-randomness is evidence of design fails the simplest test of logic.  So his goal of mathematically proving design by finding complexity is a red herring.  His implicit claim that evolution by natural selection is randomness in action is a flat-out lie.    Don't be fooled by the ID claims of scientific oppression.  Dembski's work is unscientific not because he believes in God (many scientists believe in God and get published)
column9: but because it tries to prove the unprovable.  Karl Popper pointed out decades ago that you can't prove a negative.  Evolutionary biologists don't claim they have proven the non-existence of God because they understand Popper's principle.  But Dembski believes he can prove that evolution didn't cause something--he never actually tries to prove God
column10: he only tries to prove something else didn't happen
column11: then sticks God in place as the only explanation.  That is bad logic
column12: bad science
column13: and even bad theology

column1: Heinlein is a great author.  When he sits back and tells a story
column2: he's one of the best.  Glory Road and Citizen of the Galaxy are wonderful
column3: and The Moon Is a Harsh Mistress should be on the shelf of any science fiction fan.  This
column4: however
column5: is an awful book.  It's not merely one of Heinlein's worst.  It's one of the worst books I've ever had the misfortune to read.  The problem isn't that there's no action
column6: although there isn't.  The problem is that there isn't anything of substance to replace it.  There's lots of sex
column7: but not in enough detail to be titilating.  There isn't a love story either; you can't have romance or sexual tension when your characters will sleep with anyone and everyone for any reason.  The book just rambles aimlessly until it ends.  Maybe Heinlein was trying for an examination of gender roles and sexual identity
column8: but if so he failed miserably.  The characters in this book aren't just from a different culture; they aren't people at all.  They're too flat.  If you want to think about such things
column9: ponder them on your own or read a different book.  I suggest Left Hand Of Darkness by Ursula Le Guin.  I Will Fear No Evil reads like an old man's rambling personal fantasies.  Someone must like it
column10: but I can't recommend it even to the most devoted Heinlein fans.  If you're tempted
column11: do yourself a favor and re-read Stranger In A Strange Land instead

These three guys are amazing musicians in their own right but this album just doesn't work. From a theory and technical standpoint it's very good (some would say brillant). If you have a background in music theory you'll probably like it a lot. There is plenty of meat to chew on when it comes to breaking down the music and understanding what they are doing.   But if you have listened to The Police
column2: Phish and Primus and you are just a big music fan then this is probably a very hard listen. It sounds like a car wreak of those three band's music and there really is nothing new. Trey's guitar work sounds like the work he did with Phish; Stewart's drums are just like The Police (more of the old Police stuff); Clay's bass is right from any Primus song. It sounds like what they did was take those aspects of their styles that would sort of fit together and just laid it out on this album. That's fine
column3: but it's just hard not to think of Phish
column4: The Police and Primus while listening to it.   The highlight of the album IMO
column5: is Army's on Ecstasy. It opens up kind of slow and strange then picks up in a really nice jam frenzy for Trey's solo. That sort section of the ablum works really well together. For that section
column6: it sounds like something outside the relm of Phish
column7: Primus and The Police.

This antiquated textbook is still used at colleges and universities throughout the United States.  The first edition of this book was published in 1955 and
column2: after nine more editions
column3: appears largely unchanged in its mentality.  Specifically
column4: the textbook is written for a time when corporations had legions of industrial engineers who did nothing but detailed and tedious time and motion studies.  Unfortunately
column5: today's dynamic manufacturing environment renders many of the authors' techniques impractical or even financially hazardous.  For example
column6: it emphasizes the need to maximize machine utilization (even if the machine is not considered a bottleneck operation).  Practices like these lead to excessive inventory and sub-optimization of the collective manufacturing process.  In summary
column7: I believe this textbook does a great disservice to those manufacturing firms that have achieved dramatic productivity gains through the application of lean manufacturing techniques

column1: A century ago
column2: a man named Grant Allen wrote a book called "The evolution of the idea of God." G.K.Chesterton reviewed it by noting
column3: "It would have been more interesting if God had written about the evolution of the idea of Grant Allen." Armstrong's book is fascinating at times
column4: but two things hindered the story.  First
column5: she limits herself to the history of purely human ideas and ideologies
column6: or from a Christian perspective
column7: a history of idolatry. The book is like looking at the moon under the assumption that the light you see is native to that sphere. Second
column8: Armstrong ignores all evidence that God may be more than merely an idea
column9: may be a person who acts in history. (Such as the universe itself
column10: prophets
column11: and miracles.)  One aspect of that evidence of which most people are unaware
column12: and that relates to the theme of this book
column13: is the fact that monotheism is not solely a "western" concept. One finds an awareness of the Creator even in countries where all institutional and pedagogical institutions have been hostile to Him for hundreds of years
column14: and native religions appear to have no use for him
column15: such as Japan. This is as the Bible predicts: Paul said that in our hearts
column16: we know God is and that we are not Him
column17: but suppress that knowledge. The history of organized religion
column18: east and west
column19: is largely a history of men and women running from God. Armstrong's book is in a sense a well-written and gosippy history of that flight.  I suggest four books which give an aspect of the "history of God" Armstrong and her fellows routinely ignore: how the God of the Bible reveals Himself to non-Christian cultures. The first is Chesterton's Everlasting Man. The second is Eternity in Their Hearts
column20: by Don Richardson
column21: one of the most interesting books on religion published this century. The third is a book I wrote after reading Richardson's theories
column22: and finding out that they ring true: Jesus and the Religions of Man
column23: especially the chapter "The Non History of God
column24:
an in-depth response to this book. I also recommend the book God wrote on the evolution of the idea of Karen Armstrong, especially the first chapters of Romans

column1: I admire Nancy Campbell's attempts to counter the present-day view of children as burdens.  It is a tragedy that people sometimes view pregnancy as an evil
column2: or that children are not treated as central in marriage.  I also admire her for pointing out the potentially abortificient nature of some common methods of birth control
column3: including the Pill. This is information which should be available to all Christians.  However
column4: the means she uses to argue against birth control are not always logical or scripturally sound. She takes individual Bible verses out of context at times. Overall
column5: she has an unfortunate pattern of ignoring the cultural context of the Bible: she tries to map the cultural ways of ancient Hebrew culture onto the Church without seeming to realize that the Church
column6: though it is the People of God
column7: is not the SAME KIND of "people" that the nation of Israel was.  To give one prime example: the Hebrews were a hereditary group
column8: and the nation increased primarily through new births. Christianity is not hereditary
column9: however
column10: at least not in so direct a way. Not only do not all children of believers grow up to be Christians
column11: but Christians may come from other sources (evangelism
column12: conversions). Thus
column13: the Church is not dependant on procreation for its increase to the same degree that the nation of Israel was.  This is only one example: elsewhere she talks about economics and lineage as if these issues played out in the twenty-first century in the same way they did in Israel. They do not
column14: of course: in the past
column15: children were an economic gift to a family
column16: not a burden
column17: because they could earn money.  Would Campbell really argue that we should all put our children to work at an early age so that we reap the same economic benefits?  There are other problems with the books' use of Biblical texts
column18: as well. Some texts get repeated multiple times to bear out different points
column19: thus creating a repetitive effect that becomes annoying. Other texts are dropped into the page without any explanation of how they prove the point they are supposed to prove. Sometimes this is due to only a lack of adequate exposition; other times it may be due to her trying to put too much "weight" on a single verse.   Finally
column20: I have to agree with previous posters that Campbell does not really prove that contraception is immoral. All she manages to prove is that children are supposed to be viewed as one of the primary fruits of marriage.  As I said before
column21: this is a worthy goal and I applaud her for it
column22: but given the kinds of arguments she makes
column23: it might have been better if she had stayed with that point

column1: This is the worst
column2: most depressing piece of fiction I have ever read.  There is no real protoganist and not one singular character worthy of admiration--and after a while
column3: their actions just become inexplicable.  The author's soul must truly be an ugly one to have devoted so much time and energy to using his mind to generate so many casual acts of evil throughout the book.  It starts out promising but by the time you get to about halfway through the book or so you get a nagging sense that your very own soul might be sucked out of you and permanently stolen by the heart of Neil Gaiman's darkness or one of his minions.  Additionally
column4: the characters' motivations change like the shifting sands
column5: nothing they do makes any real sense except some inexplicable movement towards doing greater and more evil en masse like some sort of coagulating bacteria or disease.  What is so creepy about this book is the casualness of it all.  Unlike some of Stephen King's work (ie: The Stand)
column6: there is absolutely no redeeming thread here--no rallying or marshalling the troops to combat the emerging evil.  It's evil in evil vs. evil surrounded by evil.  All I can say is that this book is ugly
column7: ugly
column8: ugly.  At least writers like Joyce Carol Oats and Joseph Conrad's intentions when writing about such things is to effectively demonstrate the ill effects of such darkness
column9: but to make heroes of characters one should avoid is unconscionable.  The choices the supposed protoganist makes make no sense--and you do root for  him in the very beginning but you find he is just like one of them after all.  I suspended my doubt and disbelief as long as I could but finally became so incensed by the audacity of both the literary critics and the author to pass this off as excellence
column10: I literally stopped mid-sentence and chose to never read this author's work again.  It's a shame too because he has allied himself in other incarnations with a truly gifted artist
column11: Dave McKean
column12: who maybe hasn't completely gone over to the dark side like Neil has.  His association with Dave McKean is the only reason I even opened-up the book--and maybe a little because the title intrigued me.  But it's unfortunate that the industry rewards "clever" works such as Mr. Gaiman's with undue praise.  I've never so strongly disliked a book.  Have you ever found yourself getting angry because you felt robbed or duped by a book?  Well
column13: don't believe the hype
column14: this is the one to throw in the trash or disintegrate with X-men eyeball laserbeams before all your humanity is sucked out of you

column2: I enjoy Victorian adventure fiction as much as the next person -- in fact
column3: probably more than the next person
column4: since the average "next person" hasn't ever read any. Tales of derring-do
column5: adventures to unexplored distant lands
column6: lost civilizations
column7: great artifacts
column8: etc. -- that's all good stuff. What's not good is this book
column9: which is tedious in the extreme. On the surface of it
column10: Haggard's followup to his hugely successful (and infinitely better) "King Solomon's Mines" has all the elements: a dynamic duo of scholar-adventurers (one of whom is descended from pharaohs!)
column11: a mysterious message from the past delivered by a dying man
column12: an expedition to Africa
column13: and a supernatural being who knows the secret of eternal life.  However
column14: despite this promising laundry list
column15: Haggard's execution leaves a great deal to be desired. A friend described it rather aptly as "a book with a lot of story
column16: but not a lot of plot." Which is to say that in my edition
column17: some 320 pages are filled without much happening. There is the initial mysterious set-up
column18: the journey to dark Africa with the usual physical trials and tribulations
column19: the heroes' conveyance to the "lost city"
column20: and then... and then things kind of grind to a halt. Lengthy descriptive details
column21: lengthy internal ruminations
column22: lengthy rambling speeches
column23: lengthy everything -- but very little of consequence occurs until the very end
column24: when the heroes make a dangerous journey to find the eternal fire which grants nigh-everlasting life.  I suspect much of the problem stems from the book's origin as a long-running serial in the Gazette. As I understand it
column25: serial writers of the time were paid by the word or by the installment
column26: and thus
column27: it was to their advantage to spin their plots out as much possible -- hence the unhealthy ratio of action to words. Judicious editing could reduce the book to 1/3 of its size without any loss of note. Of course
column28: as another friend pointed out
column29: it's probably best to read the book is small chunks -- just as one would have done with installments. Spreading out one's reading of it over a period of time
column30: he suggests
column31: may serve to conceal the book's rambling nature. In any event
column32: there are some nice scenes here and there
column33: such as the moonlight battle between crocodile and lion and another involving human cadavers used as torches
column34: but those are about all I'm likely to recall from this book in a year.   Of course
column35: as is noted in the introduction to my edition
column36: Haggard lifted the main elements of the plot
column37: and even the the true name of "She-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named"
column38: from several earlier adventure novels by Edward Bulwer-Lytton
column39: so one can't even give him much credit for imagination. I suppose the book is worth reading by those interested in literary representations of the prevailing xenophobic sentiments of Victorian Englishmen: racism
column40: anti-Semeticism
column41: misogyny
column42: fear of miscegenation
column43: etc.
column44: but as entertainment for the modern reader
column45: it falls woefully short of the mark.

column1: They say that there is a thin line between genius and madness.   Unfortunately

column3: it's a very well-done film.   Ed Harris is fantastic as Pollock
column4: and one can tell he had a passion for this particular part.   Val Kilmer barely has a cameo and Jennifer Connelly is only in maybe 10% of the movie {sigh}.  The reason I slam this movie is because I'm not impressed by this artist or his work.   I would have found a biographical movie on Ed Harris himself to be much more profound than this guy's story.  In my family there are two artists:  my father and sister.  The artistic gene skipped over me entirely as I can barely draw a stick man.  That said
column5: I remain unconvinced that I can't do anything as well as this guy did.  Or
column6: to put it another way
column7: any kindergartner could have made random shapes like this guy & called it art.   When I think of art I think of Raphael
column8: not this guy.  So
column9: since I had such a low regard for Pollock's work
column10: I could not help but have little interest in this movie.    To me he was nothing but a cop out.  That said
column11: I'll be as fair as I can here:  if you happen to be a fan of Pollock's you're not going to find a better testimony of his life than this movie.   The problem is I'm simply not impressed by that

column1: Mukherjee is one of the lucky few hand picked by the critics in attempting to reform the classic canon.  In trying to provide a voice to an unrecognised minority - the literary critics have foisted this trash upon us - and the public say "pull the other one." Leaves the reader feeling quite angry at how an author could be so presumptuous.

column3: I know the story about Hal Jordan and Coast City and Parallax and the eventual handing of the Power Ring to Kyle Rayner.  I have no problem when a writer massages an origin or two to make the story work.  But this felt like he took what I knew of the Justice League and it's core and Green Lantern and the Oans and put them all into a food processor.  What we got out of it looked like chunky green pea sludge.  I won't pass all the details of the story along but I felt like the author took established events in the DCU and made them into bland
column4: trivial entries to justify the telling of his story.  The origin of the Justice League
column5: the characterization of it's members
column6: the use of Hal Jordan and "Di"
column7: the misrepresentation of the Oans and the Green Lantern Corps were a big pile of steaming ____.  I'm sorry

column9: the Kyle Rayner we see here is a whiner.  If I heard the story he told in this novel
column10: I'd strip him of the ring and give it to someone else.  The idea that only humans have artistic concepts which is why Kyle can do so well ... crap.  And Gandy?  Please.  Ganthet was a pretty key Oan in the scheme of things with the Guardians.  The author reduced him to a cardboard cutout with Ganthet's likeness.  I just find the novel contrived and ill-thought. column1: Steven Pinker lost me as a buyer of his thesis with the very second sentence of his book:   "For you and I belong to a species with a remarkable ability: we can shape events in other's brains with exquisite precision".  It you take that for granted
column2: Pinker's book will seem compelling and not especially controversial. Steven Pinker clearly takes it for granted
column3: perhaps because he can't conceive of how we could possibly communicate effectively and coherently if it were not true.   Consider the following
column4: which I think perfectly encapsulates the world view Pinker can't conceive of
column5: by Ogden Nash:  Caught in a mesh of living veins
column6: In cell of padded bone
column7: He loneliest is when he pretends That he is not alone.  We'd free the incarcerate race of man That such a doom endures Could only you unlock my skull
column8: Or I creep into yours.  To my way of thinking
column9: it is the very fact that we *can't* "shape events in other's brains with exquisite precision" - or with any reliable certainty at all
column10: that describes the human condition. The frisson created by precisely that ambiguity underpins all communication; it is the source of irony
column11: tragedy
column12: comedy
column13: invention and imagination. Any theory of language which denies that fundamental contingency of human communication (as this one does) is going to have to prove it
column14: and displacing that onus is a heavy task indeed.  Pinker's psycho-linguistics makes precisely that denial
column15: by holding that all human communication - every language - shares an inate
column16: evolutionary programmed Universal Grammar
column17: precisely because Pinker can't conceive how else human communication could be possible.  I'm no academic
column18: and certainly I have no background in linguistics. Given that this theory - which is from the same tradition as Noam Chomsky's - has been the ascendancy amongst academic linguistics for the best part of the last thirty years
column19: Steven Pinker being one of the leading "normal scientists" within the paradigm (if I should be so bold as to use that word)
column20: and that The Language Instinct is considered fairly widely to be his magnum opus
column21: I was expecting to have my naive relativistic assumptions carefully and systematically dissected
column22: then annihilated
column23: one by one.  So imagine my surprise to find that in the place of carefully drawn arguments and compelling statistical data
column24: one finds a tissue of anecdotal arguments carefully selected to fit the theory
column25: arguments from authority ("Chomsky is one of the ten most cited writers in all of the humanities")
column26: dubious suppositions in place of statistical data (the "it is difficult to imagine the following grammatical construction being used" sort of thing)
column27: begged questions
column28: non sequiturs
column29: and Roger Penrose-style irrelevant scientific waffle - especially as regards evolution - and a decided absence of any consideration of competing theories of linguistics - and straw men versions of those which do rate a mentioned.   In short
column30: Steven Pinker employs just about every illegitimate arguing technique in the book. His theory completely fails to account for metaphor (metaphor is barely mentioned in the book)
column31: nor the incremental development of language
column32: the evolution of different languages with different grammars and vocabularies. At times Pinker is forced to argue that the grammar of our language is sometimes different from the words we actually speak and write
column33: containing unspoken "inaudible symbols" representing a word or phrase which has been moved elsewhere in the sentence
column34: so the sentence "The car was put in the garage"
column35: according to Pinker's Universal Grammar should technically be rendered as: "was put the car in the garage"
column36: and the construction we use can only be explained by movement of "The car" and the insertion in its place of an inaudible "trace":  "[The car] was put [trace] in the garage".  Now
column37: again I am no technical linguist
column38: but this has all the hallmarks of pure bull manure to me.  Finally
column39: Pinker is at pains to point out that Universal Grammar is only ever applicable to oral language: written language didn't arise for centuries after oral grammar "evolved" as a phenotype.  But this hardly helps Pinker
column40: since (as he himself points out
column41: with reference to a transcript of the Watergate Tapes) when people talk in ordinary conversation they almost *never* use complete grammatical sentences: they interrupt themselves
column42: they rely on physical gestures
column43: they break off in mid stream and start a new thought
column44: they don't punctuate (there's no unequivocal punctuation in spoken English)
column45: all the time.   As is fashionable amongst the "reductivist" and "evolutionary" set these days (a set I would otherwise
column46: in general terms
column47: consider myself in agreement with)
column48: relativist arguments are scorned. But Pinker's paradigm implies that
column49: provided we are competent in constructing our own sentences
column50: we should all understand each other perfectly
column51: all the time: there should be no ambiguity; no room for miscontrual; no possibility for evolution in ideas or language. It is difficult to see how anyone could believe such a thing. But neither the structure of language and grammar nor its practical use needs to be perfect for effective communication *at some level* to be possible
column52: and surely that is all that is needed. The beauty of the contingent view of language
column53: which Pinker seems unable to appreciate
column54: is how it can account for the missed margin of communication which might explain the everyday cultural and interpretative problems we all face
column55: and the figurative and metaphorical power we all find at our disposal. Ogden Nash's dilemma is our dilemma
column56: however much Steven Pinker might wish it were otherwise.  An earlier reviewer has mentioned Geoffrey Sampson's "the Language Instinct Debate" as a compelling antidote to Pinker's world view. Having recently read it (on the strength of that recommendation)
column57: I would firmly agree. In perhaps an ill-advisedly grumpy tone
column58: Sampson - whose position at the University of Sussex inevitably means his academic profile is lower than Pinker's or Chomsky's - systematically and convincingly annihilates many of the arguments (such as they are) in Pinker's work.  Olly Buxton

column1: Rudolf Nureyev and Margot Fonteyn. No other ballet partnership is as legendary -- the fiery Russian defector and the graceful
column2: aging English ballerina formed a bond on and off the stage that for several years practically defined romantic ballet. Thus
column3: for this very reason
column4: hardcore balletomanes should get this dvd. Many of us (including me) were too young to have seen Nureyev and Fonteyn live
column5: so these videos are the only example to dissect the legendary partnership.  However
column6: caveat emptor: this is NOT a "typical" Swan Lake by any means. You can argue that there is no "typical" Swan Lake -- the original production in 1877 was a failure. Some of the music went missing. After Tchaikovksy's death
column7: the choreographers Marius Petipa and Lev Ivanov restaged Swan Lake
column8: and that version more or less is the Swan Lake audiences know today. There's lots of music
column9: so most versions of Swan Lake use the "traditional" pieces.   Nevertheless
column10: there are some different traditions of Swan Lake. In the Russian productions
column11: the outcome is usually "happy" -- Rothbart is killed
column12: and Siegfried and Odette are alive. In the productions used "everywhere else
column13: Odette and Siegfried leap into the lake, and are reunited in the otherworld. I prefer the second ending personally, because I think it better matches both the story (the happy ending was enforced by the Tsar, and seems tacked on), and the music as well.  Rudolf Nureyev's 1966 film, however, is unlike any other Swan Lake I've ever seen. First of all, from the opening closeup (of Siegfried in blue eyeshadow and red lipstick) you realize this film is not going to follow Balanchine (and classical ballet's) creed of ballet is woman." The first act is redesigned to incorporate a lot of solos and dance opportunities for Siegfried (Nureyev). The first act usually ends with Siegfried picking up his bow and arrow and going hunting with Benno. In this film
column14: there is a long elegiac solo for Siegfried (using music that's usually used in act 2).   Nureyev even dares to tinker with the famous Act II choreography by Lev Ivanov. In the famous Odette/Siegfried Adagio
column15: the melody is not repeated with the cello -- instead
column16: there's another solo for Siegfried. Margot Fonteyn was born in 1919 so it's possible that the emphasis on Nureyev is due to Fonteyn's technical limitations at the time. And one notices that Fonteyn
column17: as graceful and lovely as she is
column18: is at times unable to cope with the famously demanding Odette/Odile role. For instance
column19: Odette's solo in Act II usually ends with a series of turns and then Odette stands on pointe and holds a balance before going into the wings. Fonteyn doesn't attempt the feat
column20: but ends the series of turns in first position -- flat on her feet. Fonteyn by modern standards also lacks the athleticism
column21: bonelessness (her arms always look like arms
column22: not wings)
column23: flamboyance
column24: and flexibility
column25: that one usually associates with this role.  Act III's music choreography is pretty standard
column26: but the musical arrangements (and choreography) for the Black Swan Pas de deux are radically different. Fonteyn actually churns out the fouettes
column27: confirming something I've long suspected: that everyone looks at the fouettes
column28: but Odette/Odile's real challenges are the balances
column29: footwork
column30: and leaps
column31: and this is where you can see Fonteyn suffer.   Strangely
column32: Act IV (the act that is usually cut to shreds) is the most intact. And it's the best-danced act: it;s the reconciliation scene between Odette and Siegfried that one can catch glimmers of the genuine bond that existed between these dancers. Elsewhere
column33: the technical limitations of Fonteyn by this time and Nureyev's reworking of Swan Lake as a solo showpiece for Siegfried distracted me from simply enjoying their partnership. I particularly loved when Siegfried runs all over the stage
column34: turning up the head of each swan
column35: to find his Odette
column36: and when he finally finds Margot's head
column37: it's a truly beautiful moment. The ending of Nureyev's version follows the original Swan Lake
column38: and not the "usual" endings of the Swan Boat to heaven.  On a technical level
column39: there are problems. The ballet was filmed on a soundstage
column40: and seems way too small to fit a whole cpmpany corps. As a result
column41: the dancers often look haplessly cramped and as if they'll bump into each other. The close bunching also detracted from the natural geometric shapes that are so much a part of classical ballet. The Vienna State Ballet also looks woefully underreheased. Either that or they're just bad. Their legs are terribly uneven in arabesques
column42: their arms are a mess
column43: and they simply look like a corps that hasnt danced Swan Lake enough. The sets are also deliberately artificial and the costuming
column44: espeically for Nureyev and in the "color" acts
column45: is garish. Rothbart (Redbeard here) is a non-dancing role
column46: unlike in most productions when he's a smooth pimp-type in Act III.   For a traditional Swan Lake with a more modern Odette/Odile
column47: I'd suggest the Makarova/Dowell dvd with the Royal Ballet. Makarova was 41 at the time of filming
column48: but her long extensions
column49: boneless arms
column50: exquisite balances
column51: and still impressive technique make her Odette/Odile much more appealing to modern tastes. This Swan Lake is of great historical value
column52: and Fonteyn is undeniably lovely
column53: but overall I admit I wanted a more traditional Swan Lake
column54: and I certainly wouldnt recommend this dvd as anyone's first Swan Lake. Its just too unorthodox.

column1: Since God is Infinite Goodness

column3: we are too shallow-minded to realize that we need God.  Since God knows that He is the only thing that we really need

column5: such as the Jews
column6: try to love God without going through Christ

column9: or C. S. Lewis for that matter
column10: cannot adore God as much as He wants to be adored
column11: so He uses pain over and over again to "plant the flag of truth within their rebellious souls."      Where does this notion of an Infinitely Good God come from?  Given mankind's painful existence
column12: "an inference from the course of events in this world to the Goodness and Wisdom of the Creator would be preposterous."  God had to reveal Himself to mankind by Revelation; thus it is in the likes of Abraham and Moses
column13: who identified God as righteous
column14: that all peoples are blessed.  Lewis informs us that God expostulated with His own creatures on the basis of their own ethical conceptions - "What iniquity have your fathers found in me
column15: that they are gone far from me?"  One has to wonder if Lewis has ever actually read the Bible.  Can anyone really deny that if a leader of today did exactly the sorts of things that Abraham and Moses did that they would be decried by all of sane mankind as monsters?  I have never understood why
column16: or how
column17: I am supposed to pretend that this is not true.  Of course
column18: God is wiser than me
column19: so if I could only see it from God's viewpoint
column20: I would see that the butchery of whole populations
column21: including babies and animals
column22: was actually an act of love.  In MERE CHRISTIANITY Lewis condemns this line of reasoning in eastern religions as "damn nonsense."  Undoubtedly
column23: we get the impression of a just and loving God through the teachings of Christ
column24: but the conviction that God is Infinite Goodness
column25: Omniscience
column26: and Omnipotence did not come from biblical revelation; it was developed by medieval Christian philosophers by reasoning through extrapolation -- a process that Lewis
column27: rather inexplicably
column28: deems impossible.  Lewis's insistence that people have free will needs to be examined.  Even as he describes it
column29: since we are born in sin
column30: we cannot use free will to avoid sin
column31: and most people are blind to their sin.  Hence
column32: it logically follows that there can be no free will without the ability of self-perception.  The evidence suggests that incessant pain
column33: especially when inflicted upon children
column34: destroys this ability.  Abused children typically grow up to be abusers.  In my own case
column35: I adamantly insist it was the drug
column36: marijuana
column37: which first gave me introspective ability
column38: at the age of 23.  Prior to that moment
column39: God knows that I had no free will.  Free will is not a realized trait that we are born with
column40: but a potential ability that requires a great deal of effort to develop.  In most people it remains largely dormant.  Since free will is dependent on self-knowledge
column41: the role of religion needs to be the development of introspective ability.  Dogmatic adherence can only hinder this.  Lewis is at least honest enough to acknowledge evolution.  Unfortunately
column42: it is hardly possible to reconcile the notion of evolution of man from animals with his fairy-tale notion that animals only exist by destroying each other because they were corrupted by Satan before man's appearance on Earth.  Somehow
column43: the perfectly good "Paradisal Man" descended from animals already corrupted by Satan.  Lewis can be abominably silly sometimes.  Lewis is given to disjunctive
column44: either/or
column45: logic.  Either the common human experience of supernatural awe is a mere twist in the mind with no biological purpose
column46: or it is direct experience of the supernatural - a Revelation.  I would once have scoffed at this
column47: but a Numinous vision of Christ was the major turning point of my life.  The problem is that this Revelation was not at all consistent with Mere Christianity.  According to Lewis
column48: the purpose of pain is to break our will
column49: since it is our tarnished wills that keep us from God.  I had only recently come to realize that I had not had free will until my sense of self was awakened by an illegal drug.  I experienced Christ in the very moment that I was cursing Christ for demanding that I beg forgiveness for that which He was responsible.  Albeit
column50: at the time I was an atheist
column51: and was only cursing at what I had been taught about Christ.  I experienced Christ as the core of my being
column52: not as an entity completely separate from myself
column53: and as an awakening of will
column54: not a surrender.  Lewis assures me that the feeling of being one with God
column55: rather than a creature of God
column56: is Satan's ultimate deception.  But I have also experienced Satan within myself.  If Christ were not the core of my being
column57: I would never have survived Satan.  I know the difference.  I do not acknowledge that Christianity has the authority tell me what my experience of God must be.  I am a scientist by training
column58: not given to superstitious credulity
column59: however much like it what I have written above must sound.  In my attempt to make sense of my experience of Christ and Satan battling within my mind
column60: I have come up with the following myth:  It is
column62: not completely unreasonable to assume that consciousness is an inherent quality of existence.  This consciousness would first be in a primordial state
column63: probably in some way responsible for evolution
column64: though not by anything like intelligent design by direct control.  There could be no distinction between good and evil; in fact the terms could have no meaning
column65: until consciousness evolved to a complexity capable of self-awareness.  As self-awareness developed
column66: so did awareness of pain and terror
column67: and a rebellion against achieving a level of awareness capable of experiencing pain.  The human mind
column68: as the vessel of consciousness experiences these antagonistic trends and
column70: tends to personify them as God and Satan
column71: or their various cultural equivalents.  What makes the Christian God so detestable is His complete refusal to accept responsibility for anything.  Satan can therefore be described as "God's self-ignorance."  Buddhists are apparently able to put themselves into the conscious state of inanimate matter
column72: hence there insistence that good and evil are identical.  C. S. Lewis tells us that "it is not God's purpose that we should go back into that old identity."  I think I agree with him on this point.  Mankind's goal must be to attain free will be becoming conscious of what we really are. (Peter Payne

column1: I will admit that I too read this book cover-to-cover and was intrigued by its story. The problem is
column2: I became so engaged that I began doing subsequent research into the field of remote viewing and
column3: appropriately enough
column4: began to "see the truth." Psychic Warrior is a highly fictionalized
column5: exxagerated
column6: self-serving vehicle for its disgraced author to exploit his fleeting brush with the RV program for money.  David Morehouse had the shortest tenure of any of the Army's remote viewers who have gone on to make a living as "experts" on the technique. According to those fellow viewers
column7: most of the "exploits" in RV that Morehouse takes credit for in this book were actually accomplished by other people. The best example is his "Mars expedition
column8: which was in fact conducted by Joe McMoneagle. An actual transcript of Joe's session is available as a bonus with purchase of Skip Atwater's book Captain of My Ship
column9: Master of My Soul" and it more or less proves that Morehouse is trying to take credit for someone else's work. The Psychic Warrior book is full of events and accomplishments that Morehouse tries to take credit for
column10: most of which actually occured when Morehouse wasn't even in the program.  In fact
column11: most of the revered remote viewers (McMoneagle
column12: Ingo Swann
column13: Russell Targ
column14: Paul Smith) seem to consider Morehouse to be the RV community's "odd man out
column15: especially after he was forced out of the Army for having an affair with his enlisted driver's wife among other things. That part of the book is even more suspect; Morehouse continually makes excuses for himself and tries to paint himself as a victim of some sort of government plot as a result of his threat to expose the truth" about RV
column16: instead of taking accountability for his illegal and immoral actions.  But two facts must be considered here: First
column17: the Army itself declassified the program and released mountains of information about it; it is highly doubtful that they would make attempts on the lives of Morehouse's entire family over something they were already planning to open the lid on. Second
column18: practically every other significant member of both the SRI program and the military's program has gone on to write books
column19: author instructional materials and even teach courses in remote viewing
column20: and not a single other one has been "targeted" by higher powers as Morehouse claims to have been.  If anyone out there is interested in reading about remote viewing and its history within both the civilian science sector and the military/government
column21: I would highly recommend that you read Paul Smith's "Reading the Enemy's Mind" instead of Morehouse's fictionalized waste of time. Smith
column22: who acted as unit historian for the Army's program
column23: provides an infinitely more reliable
column24: intelligent and engaging account of the development and implementation of remote viewing. And if you would then be inclined to study the technique yourself
column25: I would suggest you examine Skip Atwater's course at the Monroe Institute in Virginia before plunking down the $1
column26: 000 + to study with Morehouse. After all
column27: Atwater spent years training most of the viewers in a program that Morehouse was kicked out of after only a brief time.  I wouldn't have had such a problem with Psychic Warrior if it had been marketed as a work of fiction. It is a shame that such a perversion of the truth ends up being many people's initial introduction to something as significant to humankind as remote viewing.

column1: I really wanted to like this film.  It hurts not to recommend it
column2: because the subject matter is extraordinary and compelling: a once-in-a-lifetime night in American theater that happened during the Great Depression.  And Tim Robbins' heart is in the right place.  But great intentions don't make a great film
column3: and unfortunately
column4: that's the case here.  Robbins tries to do a multiple-character loose plot that makes one think of Robert Altman.  In fact
column5: watching Cradle Will Rock
column6: you realize just how good Altman is
column7: because he makes this sort of thing look so effortless (so much so that detractors have often accused him of "not really directing" his pictures).  Well
column8: to quote the late senator Lloyd Bentsen: Tim Robbins
column9: you're no Bob Altman.  The film has an impressive cast list.  Unfortunately
column10: almost everyone overacts (or is overdirected by Robbins
column11: since these actors have turned in other fine performances).  Particular violators are Cary Ewles as John Houseman and Angus Macfadyen as Orson Welles.  Both seem to channel Nathan Lane in their over-the-top elocution and both as directed by Robbins turn every showbiz cliche in the book
column12: such as bickering pettily and then
column13: when they reach an agreement over something
column14: jumping up and down and shouting "Eureka!" while hugging.  Other hams include Ruben Blades as painter Diego Rivera and
column15: surprisingly
column16: the normally spot-on Susan Sarandon as Mussolini's art-living mistress.  (With her over-bearing accent she sounds more like Count Dracula's mistress.)  Other cliched characters include doe-eyed Emily Watson as a shy waif who never gets a break in life until
column17: of course
column18: the last scene.  There's also a strange sideplot involving Bill Murray (okay
column19: he does not overact; *can* Bill Murray overact?) as a washed-up ventriloquist.  This started off promising
column20: with him attending secret meetings sponsored by alienated conservatives who see the times changing in ways that make them uncomfortable
column21: but it really went nowhere in my opinion.  Conversly
column22: the third (third!) major plotline
column23: about Nelson Rockefeller commissioning Rivera to paint a mural in his new building
column24: went predictably where we'd expect
column25: and was way too drawn out in the film's ending.  Oddly
column26: for a screenplay that cried out for lots of oddball
column27: nonconformist characters
column28: no lines and little face time are given Corina Katt Ayala as Frida Kahlo--who in real life was quite a character who could have been put to better use here.  Also underused is the always-reliable Bob Balaban.  Hank Azaria is okay as the playwright
column29: but the whole surreal bits that happen whenever he has a scene to write or perform strike me as Robbins trying to be arty and "profound."  The one standout performance is by Cherry Jones
column30: wonderful as Hallie Flanagan.  Her warm and very natural performance just throws into high relief how forced and phony most of the rest of the cast is.  Even here
column31: though
column32: Robbins misses the point.  The high moment comes when Balaban shakes her into reality after the Congressional hearings and tells her "It's over."  That could have been the beginning of a big dramatic scene
column33: but Robbins glosses over it for a phony and smug mock-interrogation in the court chambers--preaching to us like we're third graders who can't be trusted to figure it out ourselves.  Similarly
column34: the walk down the street to the second theater that begins the climax could have been a big dramatic moment--what will be the fate of this controversial play
column35: and the actors who have rehearsed it for months?  Instead Robbins gives us a victory dance before the victory--a parade of jugglers
column36: acrobats and cha-cha dancers set to comical klezmer music that undermines what he's just set up.  We feel a satisfaction and--I hate to keep using this word but it's true--smugness
column37: before the big night even happens.  And I'll leave it to you to decide the effectiveness--and the ultimate meaning--of the very last shot.  I still haven't decided if it works
column38: but it was a bold idea.  Another big part of what sinks this movie is the hammy score.  It may seem piddling to talk about background music
column39: but it really breaks the movie.  The music was done by David Robbins--Tim's brother.  Nepotism rears its ugly head.  Robbins' music is usually inappropriate--slapstick and overly broad like the rest of the film's elements
column40: as though Robbins doesn't trust us to follow him and feels he has to drive home his message with power tools.  Yet despite the constant heavy-handedness
column41: Cradle Will Rock never finds its tone--part history lesson
column42: part "serious drama
column43: part broadsided comedy
column44:
it can't ultimately decide if it wants to hit you in the head with a hammer or in the face with a pie.  It tries both by the end, and neither works.  Ultimately, I felt like Robbins couldn't get a distance from his material.  He lectures us to the point that the word MESSAGE in bright red practically flashes on the screen.  Understatement is not in his bag of tricks.  It's not that I disagree with much of what he has to say, but he fairly hits you over the head with it, and acts as though he's the first one to show you upper-class hypocracy.  The one really interesting plot thread--about how the Hallie Flanagans of the world were called before the House UnAmerican Committee to defend their loyalty while the Hearsts of America appeased dictators by buying art from them (and thereby financing their fascism)--is the highlight of the film.  But even here Robbins stages a garish costume party to drive home the point and again whips out the power tools.  Tim, we get it.  Despite this negative review, the film might be interesting to see just for the fascinating history lesson that it is.  Or you could go online or to a library and find some nonfiction material on the subject matter.  I read somewhere that originally none other than Orson Welles himself was set to make this film, but the deal never got off the ground and then he died.  That's too bad.  I would like to have seen what he could have done with this material.  As it is, Robbins is too close to it--too loud, too preachy, too self-righteous--to pull it off.

column1: Why New Orleans Matters is a short
column2: small format book that attempts to make a case for why the New Orleans that was destroyed by Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath in September 2005
column3: should somehow be restored to author Tom Piazza's vision of the city.  The bulk of the book recounts places
column4: events
column5: customs and people that made Piazza's hometown of 11 years so special for him.  What he describes will be familiar to anyone whose knowledge of New Orleans extends beyond what is covered in a Gray Line tour.  Writing just weeks after Katrina blew away it was too soon to correct
column6: so Piazza repeats
column7: false or overblown media stories that  proved to be false.  Piazza's life
column8: house and possessions were as ruined as the city he loves and he recounts a brief trip to salvage his and a friend's remnant belongings.  He correctly
column9: appropriately and too briefly describes it and grieves for that loss.  That's the book's second theme.  The third theme is Piazza's demand that New Orleans be magically rebuilt to recreate the rare habitat he believes will draw back musicians
column10: street dancers
column11: workers and the underclass whose fragile spirit animates the true (i.e.
column12: Piazza's version of) New Orleans.  Unfortunately Piazza does not provide a single specific idea as to how this can be done.  But he clearly tells us it can NOT be done by property development types.  So who does Piazza think is up to the task?  Would it be the same local and state officials who
column13: along with federal agencies failed the city before
column14: during and after Katrina hit?  Piazza better hope so because New Orleans' mayor during the hurricane
column15: Ray Nagin
column16: was elected to another term in office after this book was written.  In his introduction Piazza asserts that New Orleans "inspires the kind of love very few other cities do.  Paris
column17: maybe Venice
column18: maybe San Francisco
column19: New York... the list is not much longer."  While overlooking Piazza's Western Eurocentric view as to what kinds of cities inspire love among the world's inhabitants
column20: somebody should tell Piazza that dozens of well-loved cities have essentially vanished without a trace throughout history
column21: although their residents' unique spirits didn't necessarily die.  Likewise
column22: New Orleans' spirit will animate other cities just as people who initially came from Africa
column23: Greece
column24: Italy
column25: the Middle East
column26: France
column27: Spain and England
column28: Ireland and elsewhere brought the spirit of those places and combined them to create New Orleans at the particular moment Piazza stumbled into the mix and pronounced it "good".  Already some New Orleans musicians are putting roots down elsewhere - several reportedly decided to stay
column29: of all places
column30: in Portland
column31: OR - and no doubt writers
column32: artists and other creative souls are doing the same.  And many of its disbursed former residents are discovering that the price they paid for New Orleans' colorful folk life was enduring schools
column33: police
column34: government services and economic opportunities that were far inferior to those available to them in other American cities.  Tom Piazza needs to wake up and smell the beignets.  Old New Orleans is forever gone.  New New Orleans will arise.  Le bon temps roulette

column2: in criticizing Kevin Giles' view of Trinitarian subordination
column3: Grudem does not take into account the thorough research or the exact quotations from the Creeds that Giles actually uses to make his point.  Giles believes that the Scripture can somtimes be read to support either subordination or insubordiation in the Trinity and thus turns toward church Tradition to see how others close to the time of the early church viewed it.  Grudem takes this investigation of Tradition to be a problem of "liberals."  Instead of dealing with Giles' arguments
column4: he dismisses his approach (looking at how other Christians have viewed controversial passages).  Grudem makes the reader believe that Grudem's way of reading the text and viewing an argument to be the only intelligent way.  Some positive notes in the book is how Grudem reveals how some theologians tinker with Scripture in order to force a certain egalitarian view on the text.  Some of his insights are pointed and worth considering.  For those points
column5: we can be grateful.  Other arguments he makes miss the point altogether.  For much of the book
column6: Grudem makes many straw-man cases that only those unfamiliar with the actual debate would swallow.  Grudem often accuses his opponents of being unaware of history.  Only to add to the frustration of this reader
column7: Grudem then claims that there has only been discrepancy on gender readings of the Biblical texts since the 1970's.  Yet
column8: this point itself is not historically aware.  It does not take into account these discrepancies in the 19th century nor how the Quakers viewed women and their roles as far back as the 1600's.  Grudem quotes Paul's letter to Timothy on multiple occasion asking the reader to see for herself that Paul says an elder must be "a husband of one wife."  It is only in a footnote that Grudem states this can be read to mean different things.  Yet in the text itself
column9: he says it is quite clear that a woman cannot be an elder.  What he fails to mention is that Jesus nor Paul could be elders either on Grudem's demanded reading of the text (since they had no wives).  Grudem's approach
column10: again
column11: is confusing and leads the non-discerning reader to think that anyone opposed to Grudem must be stupid.  Grudem also seems to place an inordinate amount of criticism on Sarah Sumner
column12: who is actually an does not come down on one side or another in the debate.  So why does Grudem give her much attention?  Perhaps because she was a previous student of his and found some of his views wanting.  That itself should make the average reader want to understand Sumner more than Grudem allows her to be heard.  In the second half of the book
column13: he discusses how certain verses are reinterpreted by egalitarians.  One example is the verse is I Cor 14:33-35.  He points out
column14: contrary to egalitarians
column15: that this verse does not deal with a particular circumstances but is an universal claim.  He does this in three ways: 1) he negates the Roman and Jewish culture at the time (both of which were in the churches) as being examples
column16: even though he admits Keener cites 26 examples of Roman and Jewish assemblies and their involvement with eomen.  2) He adds the previous line "as in all the churches" to the verse about women not speaking.  The more traditional translations
column17: such as the KJV and the NASB do not make such a move)
column18: yet Grudem is accusing egalitarians of twisting meanings.  3) Pauls use of the "Law" is explained egalitarians to probably mean the customs of the day
column19: in some sense.  Grudem criticizes this view for not having evidence.  Yet as that comes off his pen
column20: he follows it by saying it refers to Old Testament law of which there is also no evidence.  Grudem
column21: in trying to make a stronger case for his own view
column22: will
column23: to the discerning reader
column24: reveal that these interpreations are not as easy as they first seem.  In addition
column25: Grudem does not wrestle with contradictions to this so-called universal statement by explaining how women can prophesy (Acts 2) or teach Apollos (as Precilla and Aquilla did together).  The fatal flaws of the book are the assumptions Grudem brings to reading the text.  He assumes that an ordinary
column26: uncritical
column27: reader can discern most everything the New Testament is saying (a view this reader does not hold without qualification when it comes to ancient texts).  This is Grudem's criticism of William Webb who says we need to have a thorough historical template of the background of the New Testament in order to get at the author's intention.  Grudem not only criticizes Webb for taking some passages out of the hands of the ordinary reader
column28: but Grudem then plays hypocrite by explaining later in the passage that you need a historical understanding of 'slave' in order to understand Grudem's point!  Another assumption Grudem brings to the text is that the text alone is enough to interpret the text.  Solid hermeneutic skills are not encouraged in this book.  Rather the reader is encouraged to see verses out of their historical context placed under Grudem's own lens.  In addition
column29: Grudem's principle of application is that the Bible applies only in those areas that are similar.  On the issue of the 'church
column30: ' Grudem makes his readers assume that the current church is run the same as the ancient church.  His grounds:  it is considered similar enough if a church 'exists after the resurrection and before Christ's return.'  He completely avoids the sticky topic of cultural application and how a church in Corinth or Ephesus may have different cultural issues than those of today (and would evoke some of Paul's strong words on gender).  He also wrongly teaches the reader that understanding the Greco-Roman context into which Paul is speaking is irrelevant to the modern church.  This is poor handling of Scripture and can easily lead the reader to think that naïveté is the path toward preserving truth (something the Bible itself never teaches).  Grudem is concerned with "liberalism" which comes from "liberate" or "to set free."  It makes me wonder
column31: after reading Grudem
column32: if his brand of conservatism is the kind of theologizing that disallows Christ to set people free--especially women
column33: their image-bearing qualities of God
column34: and their gifts.  His rules and assumptions for the text is to read them out of historical context and devoid of the spirit in which they were written.  For anyone trying to get at the heart of the debate between patriarchy and egalitarianism
column35: this is difficult to sludge through to get a fair reading and understanding of those Grudem opposes.  At one point Grudem (in the introduction) asserts he is grateful for egalitarian's pointing out inconsistencies with the modern patriarchal view.  Yet he then turns about and says that the modern patriarchal view is the same as the early church (equal in value
column36: unequal in role).  If this was the 'obvious' view of the early church
column37: why did Grudem thank egalitarians for pointing out the inconsistencies?  (Those who know the debate know that this idea and term of 'equal in value
column38: different in roles' was understood only a few decades ago.  Historically
column39: women had different roles because women weren't as fully human as men.).  The staunch attitude of Grudem to put himself as the sole objective arbiter of Scripture makes him difficult to stomach.  Even if I wanted to change my view BACK to patriarchy
column40: I couldn't do it under Grudem's pretenses.  Grudem's book is a good read to understand the tone and approach of the leading spokesman for the patriarchal view.  The way he writes reminds me of one trying to rescue a sinking ship.  One of the disappointing aspects of this book is the endorsements.  It is endorsed by some well-respected evangelical leaders
column41: like Alister Begg.  Yet reading Grudem's text makes me wonder how much these leaders have really delved into both sides of the debate.  I would like to see the patriarchal movement encourage younger
column42: more gracious voices
column43: to the front to be more honest and forthright with a topic as important as this one.  A book challenging the assumptions of both sides of the debate would be far more helpful than this book which feels more like a ship passing another in the night.  For anyone wanting to read the egalitarian view Grudem is set against
column44: try "Discovering Biblical Equality: Complimentarity without Hierarchy."  This will give you a better representation of the ideas and persons involved on the other side
