column1: I'm about to write a review that makes me sad because I have really enjoyed other books by Huston Smith. I respect his willingness and ability to explore diverse religious traditions and practices. His book "The World's Religions" is THE classic introduction to the topic. In fact
column2: if you haven't read that book
column3: then please don't buy this one; click over to that one
column4: which is really a very good book.  This book
column5: on the other hand
column6: is very disappointing. We don't like to see our heros make big mistakes; but that's what this book is.  The essence of Smith's book is that religion matters because science alone cannot deliver meaning. Nor can material consumption
column7: nor purely secular scholarship. So far so good. I agree with Smith that scientific knowledge and material consumption alone are totally inadequate to form a meaningful approach to life. We also agree that extreme postmodernism--with the idea that all attempts to find or articulate knowledge about the world are ultimately mere power plays--is not always true.  But we disagree about the status of human values. Smith believes they have no value unless they exist externally from human psychology. But I
column8: with many others
column9: argue that on the contrary my values and experiences stand on their own as meaningful and real. We might be wrong
column10: but at least he should make that case rather than just stating his opinion.  Certainly the mainstream religious worldviews assume that the most important source of values is out there
column11: in the existence of gods or ancestors or something like that. But all the great mystical traditions of the world teach that the truth that matters
column12: the most important or most real truth
column13: is within us. It is not out there in the world
column14: and we do not need to look out there for anything. Whatever supernatural stuff out there exists or not doesn't matter: the great spiritual realities and truths that we need and enjoy are within us.   With that in mind
column15: the inability of science to find and measure ghosts
column16: gods or Platonic forms doesn't matter. In a very real sense
column17: science has done spirituality a favor by empirically freeing us from supernatural entanglements and confusion. Look no more out there!   But Smith (like many religious people
column18: unfortunately) cannot accept it. He cannot believe in his values unless they exist outside of himself
column19: unless they would exist even in the absense of humanity. I think this is not only a philosophical error
column20: but also a failure of courage. He cannot maintain the rationality of his values unless he shares them with rocks and the vacuum of space.   So
column21: he has a big beef with science. Science has failed to find any supernatural thing; and so far the world has been understood remarkably well with natural explanations. That is not what most religious people would have expected
column22: but as the mystical traditions knew
column23: it doesn't have to matter.  He keeps referring to us as
column24: for instance
column25: a "razor-thin veneer on the world of dead matter." This is certainly not the only response to science! In fact most scientists regard the universe as wonderful and fascinating (not just dead matter)
column26: and us as wonderful beings
column27: blessed with the ability to experience these marvels. He quotes a bunch of existentialists to support his pessimistic evaluation of science
column28: but ultimately the existentialists (like most scientists) came to the right conclusion:   Spirituality
column29: values
column30: hopes
column31: fears
column32: etc... don't matter to scientific theories! Who cares? They matter to me! And I assume they matter to you too! Well
column33: fine
column34: that's what we need.  He burns scientists such as Ursula Goodenough
column35: E. O. Wilson
column36: and Stephen Jay Gould for having this insight. No doubt he would trash many others if he knew about them. But Smith's inability or unwillingness to share in this humanistic nobility is his worst flaw.  His wrongful hatred of science leads to a mistake about the origins of modern materialism. In his mind
column37: "The line that runs from a materialistic wordlview to a materialistic philosophy of life is not a straight one
column38: but it exists all the same" (48). Most people today seem to believe that they can buy happiness
column39: if only they have enough money; but most of those people believe in God. And even when religion dominated politics and culture most people were materialistic (yes
column40: even in "the mystic East"). Modern marketing is not taking advantage of a new human nature
column41: but the same one that we've had since the neolithic (at least).  So he terribly misunderstands the nature of human values. Sadly
column42: although that is central to his case
column43: there are still more shortcomings.   He declares that what "religion
column44: and philosophy
column45: and art
column46: and common sense
column47: and our deepest intuitions
column48: and our practiced imaginations... have said about the Big Picture throughout human history has shaken down into a single
column49: wondrously clear and inspiring worldview." Wow
column50: that is remarkable. I'd like a description of this. I think there is a great deal of diversity.   But Smith maintains that the great tradition teaches the immortality of the soul as a source of human hope. Hmmm. Not in ancient Greece
column51: not in ancient Israel
column52: not in many other pre-agricultural societies
column53: and not in contemporary Judaism. For Hindus and Buddhists
column54: the immortality of the soul is the greatest spiritual problem: they are doing their best to stop being reincarnated. Many other differences like this could be enumerated. Although there are some basic features of human worldviews everywhere
column55: I don't see the agreement he promised. And neither do the overwhelming majority of the world's religious people.  And that brings me to a criticism I really hate to make
column56: because Smith has done more than perhaps anyone else to bring knowledge of the world's religions to the average person. Smith's worldview in this book is not some great universal human tradition
column57: but simply liberal monotheism; probably Christianity. He enriches it with a diverse sprinkling of other religions
column58: but he merely brings them all under the umbrella of an implicit Christianity
column59: not taking their traditions seriously. I've never seen him so negligent of other religions
column60: so loyal to Christianity. Now Christianity is a great religion
column61: but it's not the only worldview in human history
column62: and not even the primary one or necessarily the greatest one. If Smith titled the book "Why Christianity Matters" and was honest about his bias
column63: this wouldn't be a complaint. But he says the book is about all of humanity's traditions
column64: and that's what we would expect from Smith. But it's implicitly dismissive of Zen
column69: and many traditions of hunter-gatherer people.  I have one more criticism. A number of scholars in Smith's field have been accused of indifference to
column72: many religious people have stood up to such regimes bravely and fiercely; Bonhoeffer is just one of many examples.  Smith writes
column73: "If a two-year-old drops her ice-cream cone
column74: that tragedy is the end of the world for her. Her mother knows that this is not the case. Can there be an understanding of life so staggering in its immensity that
column76: even gulags and the Holocaust seem like dropped ice-cream cones?"  No. Because the human beings destroyed by those tragedies are inherently valuable
column78: while ice cream cones are not. Smith's failure to perceive that leads me to suspect he shares some of that indifference to human life. Who would compare the value of human beings to ice cream cones? Really
column79: when you think about who would
column80: Smith suddenly finds himself in some very scary company.  In Smith's defense
column82: and that perhaps a younger sharper Smith wouldn't have made a lot of these assumptions and comments. His only important and valuable point is that we have to look for fulfilment outside of materialistic possessions and experiences.   I conclude by emphasizing my original point: this book is worthless

 From what was a landmark study by ethnobiologist Wade Davis into the folk preparations in the creation of zombies and the belief system associated with Haitian voodoo came a Eurocentric mess of a movie with the same title that was originally released in 1988.  It was reported at the time that Davis only agreed to sell the rights of the book if Peter Weir was hired as the movie director and Mel Gibson would play the leading role (based on Davis). Neither person was ever involved in the movie project.   The DVD cover tells the story as presented by director Wes Craven; the movie strips the book of its exploration into the real history and customs of the religious practices unique to Haitian society and pounds away at the the evilness of voodoo and the destruction it can cause to the human psyche.  In the movie, the scientist is in search of a secret voodoo powder that places people in a simulated death. The setting is in a time of political revolution and the movie does touch upon authentic details of Haitian society. But the action degenerates into the overt racism of the horror genre that gets repeated over and over again; the darker the skin, the more evil the sin.   To save time and money, purchase the book and appreciate the solid research and writing by Davis & disregard the DVD.

 After many years, I decided to finally give Kathy Reichs' Temperance Brennan series a go.  So, where better to start than her debut novel 'Deja Dead' which introduces Reichs' heroine.  Temperance Brennan is an American forensic anthropologist working in Montreal for what I'm guessing is the French-Canadian equivalent of a Medical Examiner's office.  Of course our heroine is head strong, independent, and unlucky in love (aren't they all?).  Well, some murders start turning up and, amazingly enough, our intrepid anthropologist is the only person that links the crimes together.  Do the police believe her?  No, so she must investigate the crimes on her own.  And by doing so, the murderer then turns his attention to Brennan and her family and friends (don't all killers eventually do that?).  First off, the book is bloated.  The book (at least the paperback version) clocks in at about 530 pages.  Reichs' writes too much about menial tasks that her character, Brennan, does during her usual day.  Does anyone really want to hear repeatedly about what a character had for dinner or what paperwork she does at work?  I know I don't want to read it.  Now I'm a person who enjoys a nice, long book but 'Deja Dead' (where did she get that title anyway?) is about two hundred pages too long.  And it is a very slow read.    Secondly, her main character, Brennan, just isn't likeable.  In fact, I found her quite annoying.  The policemen in the novel are portrayed as incompetent, arrogant jerks who are too worried about being right than they are about doing the right thing.  When in fact I think that they just didn't want to deal with this overly nosy anthropologist who is obviously stepping on toes and irritating people who are just trying to do their jobs.  Reichs' tries to portray Brennan as a lone crusader fighting against all these odds to get to the criminal.  When in fact she is an irritating anthropologist who has no business investigating a murder.  She is, basically, a laboratory-based employee who should not be in the field.  So I don't blame the cops in the book that don't like her.  She's butting her nose in where it doesn't belong and, in a part I actually liked, she ends up bringing irreparable damage to her family and friends.  I thought it a just outcome.  Also, after about the twentieth time of Brennan looking at some cop's rear end and saying I like the way his butt looks...Oh

column2: it is absolutely impossible to get a clear understanding of what the Qur'an is really saying from Dawood's attempt to render the Qur'an into modern English.  He changed the traditional Sura order to the chronological Sura order (i.e. the Suras in the authentic Quran are not arranged in the order in which they were revealed). This indicative of his excessive license with the work

column4: Dawood excercises considerable self-aggrandizment with his claims that Jewish and Christian teachings influenced the Prophet. His mistakes of translation are beyond ridiculous: e.g. 'bani Adam" (correct translatied as 'children of Adam'; from al-Araf 7:31) is rendered as "children of Allah". In Al-Baqarah 2:191 'al fitnatu asyaddu minal qatl ("oppression is worse than slaughter")' is mistranslated as 'idolatry is worse than carnage". column2: Misquoting Jesus

column4: the present book compares unfavorably. Very unfavorably.  The idea is brilliant. Let's learn about the early Christians by studying what they said about Peter
column5: Paul
column6: and Mary. Rather than hope to extract some historical kernals
column7: Bart Ehrman seeks to learn how their tales
column8: regardless of how wacky they are

column10: on Peter
column11: he succeeds admirably. Then he appears to run out of steam

column14: and if so
column15: what role did they play in the events?" You can see he has completely forgotten his original premise of what the accounts tell us about the writers and listeners and is once more plowing the familiar field of "is it true or not?"  Worse still
column16: there is a lack of precision throughout the book which makes it practically impossible to read through without stopping and thinking: "Now why does he say that?" Here's a partial list of the errors in this book:  "For Mark
column17: Jesus was a suffering messiah..." (p. 17) Search as you will
column18: you won't find the word "messiah" in the Gospel of Mark.   "...when Jesus declares that Simon will be called Petras...[and] will build his church." (p. 22)  Ehrman
column19: more than anyone else
column20: knows this is a later addition since Jesus had no intentions of building his own "church".   "After Jesus' death
column21: his tiny band of followers..." (p. 23) Jesus' band consisted of thousands of people. It couldn't be described as "tiny"   "There's no archeological evidence to suggest any synagogue structure at all in Simon's day..." (p. 25)There is such evidence and scholars have debated whether or not this is a "public building" that was used as a synagogue or just a "public building". The issue is still debated
column22: so it's misleading to offer Ehrman's blanket statement.   "...there really wasn't much choice for someone living in a poor village such as Capernaum. There weren't any condominiums for rent..." (p. 26). No
column23: but there were many choices: houses
column24: communal living
column25: tents
column26: caves
column27: etc. The choice was not simply house or no house.    "...Jesus himself
column28: a lower-class peasant from the hinterland" (p. 30). There is no reason whatsoever to assume Jesus is a "lower-class peasant" It is some people's theory
column29: but there is little evidence that Jesus came from the lower classes. Indeed
column30: his extensive religious training indicates otherwise
column31: as does his familiarity with the issues confronting land owners and the wealthy. As does his presence at the wedding at Cana.  "By the time Jesus arrives at the house
column32: the girl [Jairus' daughter in the Gospel of Mark] has already died..." (p. 31) What Gospel of Mark is Ehrman reading? Here's the actual quote - "And when he was entered in
column33: he saith unto them
column34: Why make ye a tumult
column35: and weep? the child is not dead
column36: but sleepeth." (Mark 5:39) Does that sound dead to you?   "...taking with him only Peter
column37: James
column38: and John
column39: before whom he becomes greatly agnonized..." (p. 31) Again
column40: Ehrman must be reading from the Secret Secret Gospel of Mark. If you read Mark (14:33-41)
column41: you'll find that the disciples are asleep when Jesus becomes "greatly agonized"   "Has there ever been a Christian figure as controversial as the apostle Paul?" (p. 89). Duh. How about Judas? How about Mary Magdalene? Surely they are as controversial as Paul
column42: if not more so.  "...including those of Greek and Roman mythology
column43: such as Zeus
column44: Apollo
column45: and Athena..." (p. 103) All 3 of these Gods are Greek
column46: not Roman.   "We have only one surviving author...from among the Pharisees before...70 CE...it's the apostle Paul." (p. 105) Really? Did Ehrman ever hear of Josephus?   "...one woman is called Mary Magdalene (literally
column47: Mary of Magdala)." (p. 188) No
column48: not literally. Some authors believe that the name meant Mary "the Tower" (Starbird) or Mary "The Great" (Baigent). It's possible it did mean Mary of Magdala
column49: but it's certainly not the literal meaning.   "...this sinful woman who anoints Jesus in Luke 7 is not Mary Magdalene
column50: because Mary Magdalene is actually introduced by Luke in his very next story..." (p. 189). Ehrman knows as well as anyone that gospel pericopes were moved around
column51: so there can be no valid argument that her "introduction" in one verse precludes her appearance in a prior verse. Take Mark 3:21
column52: for example. Here the translation reads that the family is upset with Jesus and then the family shows up a few verses later. Yet if 3:21 is correct
column53: they are already there and can't possibly show up later (Mark 3:31). Pericopes do not offer chronological order
column54: and Ehrman should know better.  "Mary was a Galilean Jewish woman..." (p. 195). There is no evidence that Mary came from Galilee. She is mentioned as having traveled with Jesus along with other woman from Galilee (Mark 15:41)
column55: meaning only that she had been in Galilee (although
column56: strictly speaking
column57: one can interpret Mark as meaning that only Salome was from Galilee). There is absolutely nothing that implies Galilee is her home
column58: only that she travelled from there.   "Jesus
column60: abandoned his livelihood as a carpenter/woodworker..." (p. 198).  Of course NOT. There are many definitions of tekton
column61: only one of which is carpenter. He could have been a builder
column65: etc.   "...it's virtually impossible to explain the rather troubling circumstance that he chose 12 male disciples to be his closest followers." (p. 200) Ehrman mistakes what the gospels say with what Jesus did. The gospels say he had 12 disciples but no gospel ever lists all 12 names. Some gospels list as few as 7 names and the most names are 10. That leaves plenty of room for women to have been named as disciples and for their names to have been edited out of the gospels
column67: as much as any other scholar
column68: is aware of.   "Jesus established a solid...reputation for attracting... prostitutes..." (p. 201) Search as you will
column70: you won't find the word "prostitute" in any of them. Sinners
column72: no.   "In Mark's account of the passion..while being nailed to the cross..." (p. 219). Jesus is never nailed to the cross in any version
column73: much less Mark. There is a reference to the hands in Luke (24:39) and in John (20:25) they mention nails
column74: but not in Mark. Mark's version says nothing about being nailed to the cross.  "...all our accounts agree that Jesus was crucified..." (p. 222). Actually that's not true. There are several accounts that indicate that Jesus was hung from a tree (e.g.
column77: and 13:29; Galatians 3:13; 1 Peter 2:24; Polycarp's letter to the Phillipians
column78: etc). I'm not saying that's what happened
column79: but it's simply not true that "all our accounts" say he was crucified.   I could go on
column80: but you get the point. And I've only selected the obvious errors here.  Bottom line - this book was an excellent idea
column81: but the execution was flawed and the enormous number of errors precludes me from recommending it.

column1: Steven Pinker lost me as a buyer of his thesis with the very second sentence of his book:   "For you and I belong to a species with a remarkable ability: we can shape events in other's brains with exquisite precision".  It you take that for granted
column2: Pinker's book will seem compelling and not especially controversial. Steven Pinker clearly takes it for granted
column3: perhaps because he can't conceive of how we could possibly communicate effectively and coherently if it were not true.   Consider the following
column4: which I think perfectly encapsulates the world view Pinker can't conceive of
column5: by Ogden Nash:  Caught in a mesh of living veins
column6: In cell of padded bone
column7: He loneliest is when he pretends That he is not alone.  We'd free the incarcerate race of man That such a doom endures Could only you unlock my skull
column8: Or I creep into yours.  To my way of thinking
column9: it is the very fact that we *can't* "shape events in other's brains with exquisite precision" - or with any reliable certainty at all
column10: that describes the human condition. The frisson created by precisely that ambiguity underpins all communication; it is the source of irony
column11: tragedy
column12: comedy
column13: invention and imagination. Any theory of language which denies that fundamental contingency of human communication (as this one does) is going to have to prove it
column14: and displacing that onus is a heavy task indeed.  Pinker's psycho-linguistics makes precisely that denial
column15: by holding that all human communication - every language - shares an inate
column16: evolutionary programmed Universal Grammar
column17: precisely because Pinker can't conceive how else human communication could be possible.  I'm no academic
column18: and certainly I have no background in linguistics. Given that this theory - which is from the same tradition as Noam Chomsky's - has been the ascendancy amongst academic linguistics for the best part of the last thirty years
column19: Steven Pinker being one of the leading "normal scientists" within the paradigm (if I should be so bold as to use that word)
column20: and that The Language Instinct is considered fairly widely to be his magnum opus
column21: I was expecting to have my naive relativistic assumptions carefully and systematically dissected
column22: then annihilated
column23: one by one.  So imagine my surprise to find that in the place of carefully drawn arguments and compelling statistical data
column24: one finds a tissue of anecdotal arguments carefully selected to fit the theory
column25: arguments from authority ("Chomsky is one of the ten most cited writers in all of the humanities")
column26: dubious suppositions in place of statistical data (the "it is difficult to imagine the following grammatical construction being used" sort of thing)
column27: begged questions
column28: non sequiturs
column29: and Roger Penrose-style irrelevant scientific waffle - especially as regards evolution - and a decided absence of any consideration of competing theories of linguistics - and straw men versions of those which do rate a mentioned.   In short
column30: Steven Pinker employs just about every illegitimate arguing technique in the book. His theory completely fails to account for metaphor (metaphor is barely mentioned in the book)
column31: nor the incremental development of language
column32: the evolution of different languages with different grammars and vocabularies. At times Pinker is forced to argue that the grammar of our language is sometimes different from the words we actually speak and write
column33: containing unspoken "inaudible symbols" representing a word or phrase which has been moved elsewhere in the sentence
column34: so the sentence "The car was put in the garage"
column35: according to Pinker's Universal Grammar should technically be rendered as: "was put the car in the garage"
column36: and the construction we use can only be explained by movement of "The car" and the insertion in its place of an inaudible "trace":  "[The car] was put [trace] in the garage".  Now
column37: again I am no technical linguist
column38: but this has all the hallmarks of pure bull manure to me.  Finally
column39: Pinker is at pains to point out that Universal Grammar is only ever applicable to oral language: written language didn't arise for centuries after oral grammar "evolved" as a phenotype.  But this hardly helps Pinker
column40: since (as he himself points out
column41: with reference to a transcript of the Watergate Tapes) when people talk in ordinary conversation they almost *never* use complete grammatical sentences: they interrupt themselves
column42: they rely on physical gestures
column43: they break off in mid stream and start a new thought
column44: they don't punctuate (there's no unequivocal punctuation in spoken English)
column45: all the time.   As is fashionable amongst the "reductivist" and "evolutionary" set these days (a set I would otherwise
column46: in general terms
column47: consider myself in agreement with)
column48: relativist arguments are scorned. But Pinker's paradigm implies that
column49: provided we are competent in constructing our own sentences
column50: we should all understand each other perfectly
column51: all the time: there should be no ambiguity; no room for miscontrual; no possibility for evolution in ideas or language. It is difficult to see how anyone could believe such a thing. But neither the structure of language and grammar nor its practical use needs to be perfect for effective communication *at some level* to be possible
column52: and surely that is all that is needed. The beauty of the contingent view of language
column53: which Pinker seems unable to appreciate
column54: is how it can account for the missed margin of communication which might explain the everyday cultural and interpretative problems we all face
column55: and the figurative and metaphorical power we all find at our disposal. Ogden Nash's dilemma is our dilemma
column56: however much Steven Pinker might wish it were otherwise.  An earlier reviewer has mentioned Geoffrey Sampson's "the Language Instinct Debate" as a compelling antidote to Pinker's world view. Having recently read it (on the strength of that recommendation)
column57: I would firmly agree. In perhaps an ill-advisedly grumpy tone
column58: Sampson - whose position at the University of Sussex inevitably means his academic profile is lower than Pinker's or Chomsky's - systematically and convincingly annihilates many of the arguments (such as they are) in Pinker's work.  Olly Buxton

column1: If only you knew what chiropractic was really about. It's not just about getting your back "cracked" when your in pain. There are hundreds
column2: if not thousands of applications of chiropractic to the human body. One of the biggest secrets of chiropractic is it's proven success to help women conceive children -- yes
column3: you heard right. While attending Palmer College (my first year -- 2004) I came across the book: Soup for the Chiropractic Soul. As I read
column4: I was amazed at some of the wonderful stories of people healed through chiropractic. None more though
column5: than the several stories of woman conceiving after years of trying without success with other "help". Chiropractic is often seen as a last resort (this is starting to change). You see
column6: the nervous system controls the entire body and how it responds to stimulus (temp regulation
column7: hormone regulation ...) and if in any way the electrical messages sent from the brain to organs are disturbed by what chiropractors call a subluxation (less than a luxation -- a small dislocation in the spinal column) you can have problems (in this case conceiving -- you know that conditions have to be optimal to conceive). The nerves which innervate the reproductive system (found passing through the lumbars L2
column8: L3) must stay clear of interference (because of subluxations)
column9: otherwise disfunction of the body can occur. Still don't believe -- that's your prerogative
column10: but I've got a 20 month old daughter that tells me otherwise (we tried for years to conceive before giving chiropractic a try -- and in only two months she was pregnant). I'm one of the biggest skeptics out there -- I need to see something work before I believe in it -- Well
column11: I'm convinced; chiropractic works. Check out the soup for the soul on chiropractic
column12: you'll hardly believe it -- but I swear it's true.    Chiro200

column1: Man oh man...I love documentaries and character studies.  Crumb
column2: Capturing the Friedmans
column3: The Thin Blue Line etc...  But THIS...my god
column4: the mind boggles at the level of pretentiousness of the folks who claim to "love" or "get" this horrible mess.  Over an hour and a half of two crazy women who are essentially shut-ins rambling on about nothing at all in what looks like an abandoned shack surrounded by vermin and garbage a foot deep.  The two women in question are "Big Edie" and "Little Edie"
column5: the aunt and cousin of Jackie O respectively.   Let me sum up the whole 100 minutes for you;  Little Edie: I hate it here. I had to leave New York to come here and take care of my mother. Big Edie: I was fine. I used to have a lovely singing voice. Little Edie: But I missed out on my big chance to make it. Big Edie: Oh well. You missed out. Little Edie: I miss New York. I hate it here. Big Edie: Did you feed the cats? Little Edie; YES!!! I fed them!!! Big Edie: I used to have a lovely singing voice.   Now imagine this being repeated over and over again for 100 minutes.   Do yourself a favor; Before you let anyone talk you into seeing this piece of dreck just go sit on skid row for 2 hours and listen to the rambling of the hobos and mental patients.  You'll save the money and get some fresh air at the same time.   Horrible. Just plain horrible

column1: I'm a sucker for these "social satire" type novels

column8: some "evil" young child who is a hamster-murderer?  Which children attend therapy?  Could a child have some awful disorder that would make him or her do this?  Obviously

column1: First
column2: I know this review looks too long
column3: but it might help you out. So please
column4: read on.  I read a few of the "chapters" (exercise sections) of this book and found it to be a little too conversational. Sure
column5: we all value a charming and witty instruction book to a dry academic one
column6: but I still think she brings nothing new to this genre of book.    It seems like she could easily have gotten all of these ideas from other writing books
column7: seminars and articles
column8: and frankly
column9: most of them are better written than this one. You've probably encountered most of the ideas put forth in this book
column10: beginning with an intro akin to:    "Oh
column11: we all say we're going to write
column12: but we never get around to it. Well never
column13: fear
column14: because [insert generic writing guide book title] is here to kick your rear in gear!"    Something like that.     There are really so many different types of books
column15: kits
column16: articles
column17: memoirs
column18: classes and manifestos on the subject of writing
column19: exercises
column20: inspiration and so forth. (Just do a search on Amazon for Writing Instruction or Writing for Publication.)  I really can't recommend this book
column21: though.      Unfortunately
column22: the author also thinks it's cute or somehow necessary to write quite a few words in ALLCAPS to add emphatic notice to the concept. Personally
column23: I think that WRITING like THIS every few PAGES looks unprofessional and can be quite IRRITATING. This stylistic flaw alone makes me wonder whether she's a very credible source. Is font manipulation creative? Sure
column24: to an extent
column25: but "all-caps" serves no purpose
column26: and it's easy to do and banal.     I think that this work misses a point about writing: it requires self-discipline as well as inspiration and talent. It's easy and sometimes fun to get caught up in books like these
column27: but really
column28: if you just read a varity of nonfiction
column29: novels and periodicals for a few hours each week you can begin to understand observational skills
column30: and you won't need these silly little exercises.  You'll be inspired by what you read
column31: and how the articles or whatever you read remind you of your own experiences.    So
column32: the point is
column33: if you feel that you need to spend money on a book like this
column34: perhaps you don't have the ability to discipline yourself into a steady routine of journaling and writing. Buying a book like this one will allow you to read some tips and eventually forget about it. After brief excitement and productivity
column35: you'll be back to square one; with no self-discipline
column36: you'll never apply this book to your life week-by-week as you should. It will collect dust next to your yoga books.  I offer this criticism not to sound nasty
column37: but to make you think about what you are buying.   It's simple to buy a Men's Fitness magazine
column38: for instance
column39: but it won't help you unless you actually work out routinely. Same thing.   I guess the bottom line is that this book is okay for a casual read
column40: but look it over in a bookstore first to see if you really want to pay the price of owning it.   I give it about 2.4 stars.

column1: I was initially very excited to see this book was available.  The Komsomolets was the advanced technology "Mike" class submarine.  Designed with a titanium hull and advanced hull design
column2: the submarine was a worry for the US Navy in the closing days of the Soviet Union.  However in 1989
column3: a fire broke out on board while in the Norwegian sea
column4: and this drove the submarine to the surface.  The fire spread and the submarine floundered and eventually sank
column5: with considerable loss of life.  The present book's author
column6: D. A. Romanov
column7: was one of the designers of the submarine.  As such
column8: he is ideally placed to discuss the technical issues and aspects that lead to this tragedy.  Unfortunately
column9: a better title for this book might be "Lost in Translation".  It is immediately clear that the translator has no knowledge of submarines
column10: and the translation appears to be almost a literal word for word version
column11: with little regard for idiomatic phrasing. The result is an extremely awkward
column12: and in many cases unintelligible book.  Two examples: "The supply of oxygen in these compartments was provided by the periodic opening of the corresponding valves in the oxygenated collector of the electro-laser in the electromechanical air regenerating system located in the second compartment."  A little further on the same page: "In accordance with the RBZh-PL-82 (appendix 15)
column13: the watchstander of the compartment must control the content of the oxygen in the atmosphere of the compartment no less than six times a day by use of a portable apparatus
column14: independent from the condition of the automatic means of control." These border on some of the best technobabble since Star Trek: The Next Generation.   The official investigation by the Soviet Navy of the Komsomolets accident basically exonerated the crew and the leadership
column15: instead blaming the accident on numerous "design pecularities" and "technical imperfections" of the submarine.  Romanov's thesis is that crew training and readiness were woefully inadequate
column16: and the failure to routinely monitor oxygen systems led to a fire that started in compartment seven (the aftermost compartment at the stern).  The failure to control the fire by promptly discharging Freon -based extinguishing materials into compartment seven led to the fire spreading forward
column17: and smoke spreading through the ventilation system. Confusion reigns in the few minutes after the fire develops
column18: and precious time is lost in attempting to clarify the situation aft. Romanov systematically goes through the accident timeline and testimony and points out step by step how the crew and officers lost several chances to control and contain the fire and save the submarine. He defends the design of the submarine and condemns the poor casualty training and especially the lack of officer leadership in the disaster. Even when the decision was made to surface the submarine and discharge life rafts from special canisters built into the hull
column19: the lack of training and preparedness conspires to kill additional men in the icy waters.  The deployment canister is designed to rapidly discharge the rafts into the water by having the bottom of the canister drop away and release the rafts. This operation is totally misunderstood
column20: and instead the crew tries to lift the 200 lb rafts out of the top of the canisters.  Romanov also devotes a section near the end (Assault of the Pundits) to answering specific criticisms leveled at the submarine design.  I suspect that there may be a decent and intriguing story struggling to get out of this book; unfortunately
column21: it didn't make it!    I was extremely disappointed in this book overall.  As noted above
column22: significant sections of it are excruciatingly difficult to read and understand.  The language is extremely stilted
column23: reminiscent of Cold War Tass press releases. There are a number of rather complicated block diagrams of key ship's systems throughout the book; these are labeled in Russian and there is no accompanying explanatory text.  The diagram titles are minimally helpful (e.g. sources of smoke and gas in compartments two and seven).  As such
column24: they just fill space and do not aid the reader at all in understanding the technical arguments. The book does have some photos
column25: although many were taken underwater after the sinking and are extreme close-ups.  Without some sort of context
column26: it is next to impossible to say why any particular photo is shown and what the reader should take from the picture.  Unless you are an extremely hard-core Russian submarine fan
column27: I cannot in good conscience recommend this book to you.

Suzanne Somers apparently has no use for modern medical science. Especially as a survivor of breast cancer (although of a very early stage) she is putting her life in grave danger by taking hormones. Recent studies have shown that women who were taking HRT for protection from heart problems actually had MORE problems than normal menopausal women. This is an unbelievably destructive
column2: horribly dangerous book for people to take seriously. Being skinny is NOT more important than being alive. If you want to get the real scoop on hormones
column3: talk to a doctor at an academic medical center (in other words
column4: one that isn't going to mislead the public for personal financial gain) and see what she or he has to say. Chances are excellent that you'll be told to avoid them at all cost. Look at it this way: are you going to put your very life in the hands of Suzanne Somers? I'm sure she's a very nice person; it's just that she has no medical training whatsoever. *** writing from an NCI-designated Comprehensive Cancer Center**

column1: The last known living thylacine - the proper name for what is often popularly (and mistakenly) called the Tasmanian tiger - died in a Hobart city zoo in 1936. It was already an old beast
column2: and the Great Depression had worsened its condition through neglectful care. Two months before it died
column3: the Tasmanian parliament gave the species full protection - a delayed counter-response to earlier Tasmanian and Australian policies that for decades put a bounty on its head. But the change in policy came too late. In all the years since 1936
column4: there has not been a single piece of solid evidence the species still exists.  Most experts guess that a few thylacines lived on in the wild for some years after the mid-30s before succumbing to the problems of low population numbers. But many Tasmanians
column5: and a few experts
column6: continue to believe the animal still survives in the wilds of Tasmania. There are a number of reasons for this. Thirty percent of the island is a wildlife preserve. There have been over a hundred reliable sightings of the animal in recent years. And the creatures were nocturnal and shy
column7: even when populations were abundant.  If the thylacine does survive
column8: it would be a remarkable story
column9: for it was a remarkable beast. The largest marsupial predator in modern times
column10: the thylacine took its popular name from the stripes that covered the back half of its elongated frame. Without those stripes
column11: a thylacine would have had some resemblance to a long
column12: skinny dog or wolf
column13: except for two obvious features: its enormous jaw
column14: which the thylacine was able to open to an angle of nearly ninety degrees
column15: and its sloping back
column16: which was somewhat similar to a hyena's (another dog-like creature that is not related to the canines). But whatever resemblance existed between thylacines and the family of canines was superficial -- a matter of convergent evolution
column17: not relatedness. The thylacine was a marsupial
column18: with its pups born and partially raised in a poach.  Most eyewitness accounts said thylacines were neither fast nor ambush predators. The creature's sloping gait
column19: that so resembled a hyena's
column20: was built for endurance not speed. A thylacine would give chase to its prey over long distances
column21: tiring it out
column22: before catching up with it and pinning it down with the enormous jaw and sharp teeth. The preferred prey seems to have been kangaroos
column23: wallabies
column24: wombats
column25: and
column26: a few years after the arrival of white settlers in 1803
column27: sheep. The thylacine's taste for sheep
column28: however
column29: would end up spelling its doom as settlers - many of whom went to Tasmania to raise sheep - grew to hate the beast.  David Owen
column30: a Tasmanian novelist
column31: and the author of "Tasmanian Tiger"
column32: argues that the thylacine's reputation for eating sheep was probably undeserved or at least exaggerated. Feral dogs also inhabited Tasmania
column33: and in some cases were known to attack and eat sheep. But whoever the culprit
column34: the "tiger" - as the thylacine was known locally - was blamed by most Tasmanians and bounties were put on its head. As a result
column35: by the early twentieth century
column36: the writing was on the wall for the beast. From 1878 to 1896
column37: more than 3
column38: 400 tiger skins were tanned and made into waistcoats. In 1902
column39: 119 thylacines were presented for the bounty. In 1906
column40: just 58. In 1909
column41: the last year any tigers were presented for bounty
column42: only two were given up. The population had been decimated. It was now only a matter of time.  Owen's book is fairly dry
column43: considering the rich nature of the subject matter. David Quammen
column44: in his "The Song of the Dodo"
column45: has a far more interesting section on the thylacine
column46: filled with fascinating facts and a strong narrative
column47: covering almost all the ground Owen does in much less space. Perhaps because he is a novelist
column48: Owen has little new to add. He has read the necessary books and source material
column49: but unlike Quammen
column50: and many others who have studied thylacines
column51: he has no scientific background or interest. Quammen put the extinction of the thylacine in perspective by showing its similarities to other extinctions elsewhere in the world; Owen simply portrays it as a sad story in the history of Tasmania.  Owen does add one interesting twist to the story by telling of the project to reconstruct a thylacine using the DNA from a dead fetus preserved in alcohol for several decades. Most scientists think it's an impossible scientific feat to pull off
column52: but Owen interviews a couple of bright-eyed
column53: true believers who think otherwise. The project has found sponsors and some small progress has been made. But with Australia still losing species
column54: counter-arguments have been voiced that the money - which will run into the millions of dollars per thylacine
column55: assuming they are ever successfully cloned - could be better spent saving creatures that still exist.  The same general argument can be made for the money spent on this book. "Tasmanian Tiger" is a dull study on an interesting subject. Owen is an experienced novelist
column56: but you wouldn't know it from reading this book. The narrative never gets going. For a much better book
column57: one with a superb section on thylacines
column58: read David Quammen's "The Song of the Dodo: Island Biogeography in an Age of Extinctions."

column1: Bdd acting
column2: bad directing
column3: bad plot
column4: bad script.  An okay way to spend a couple of hours if you like the genre and keep your expectations low.  No way in the world is this a "modern classic
column5: though.    Contrary to what Hollywood thinks, and contrary to what many in the audience may claim, many people DO get their history from the movies (just read a couple pages worth of reviews on any such film listed on Amazon), and that alone would take at least one star off of this film.  Sure, you sometimes have to use a little poetic license to dramatize real people and events in a film, but when you start to resort to outright fiction to give a different impression than the facts would, you've failed.  If you're going to tell a fictional story about four kids who grow up to take over organized crime in Prohibition America, then go all the way and don't use real historical figures as characters.    The even more unforgivable sin that this film commits is that it doesn't even attempt to demythologize organized crime.  According to this thing, these four guys were working class heroes!  Meyer Lansky always prided himself on never having personally taken a life himself -- but like Frank in Scarface
column6:
he just had somebody else do it for him.  Gotti and his ilk love this sort of crap, because even if they don't see themselves this way, they at least want the rest of us to see them this way.    If they had at least tried to show the true nature of these people, rather than glamorize them as antiheroes, this could have been a good film.  As it is, it almost seems as if the script was written by a ten-year-old who dreams of someday growing up to be just like Lucky.    Somehow, I doubt the people who Luciano and company killed, raped, robbed, extorted and terrorized, etc. would find this a fair treatment of the times

column1: Looking for a bit of sea adventure?  Fancy a run with some real life salts who face whatever the hurricane ravaged winter seas throw at them?  Well don't go looking to Redmond O'Hanlon's "Trawler".  O'Hanlon takes two potentially fascinating subjects - trawler fishing and the biology behind the creatures of the seas - and blends them into a putrid stew of nothingness.  This is a very difficult book to read. Physically difficult! Aye!  O'Hanlon's pointless
column2: manic use of exclamation and emphasis - EMPHASIS! Aye! - lends nothing to the story but then there is so little story
column3: it's really no loss.  "Trawler" dredges the bottom of literary technique and hauls up nothing but stream of consciousness drivel.  I found the book a total waste of time and will certainly never read another piece of work by O'Hanlon.  Aye!  I won't!  Never!

column1: If you have read about the Civil War in depth you will find this book maddening. The stories lurch between naming the regiments in a battle line to skipping over large portions of each battle. There seems to be no rhyme or reason in the approach to the information. I suppose I expected a battlefield book that would give me a topographical feel for the battle where in reality the bulk of the book is a synopsis of larger events and in some cases the battles themselves.  Another problem I had with the book is the general point of view that the Yankees were a bunch of bumbling drunkards who by happenstance were successful and the Confederates
column2: especially Lee
column3: were brilliant
column4: noble leaders who at critical moments the fates intervened to ruin their otherwise perfect battle plans. I literally had to reread the last page of the Gettysburg chapter four times to finally come to the conclusion that the author states the Lee won the battle!

column1: Note: This review reveals plot points.  This shouldn't matter too much since my advice to you is - don't read this novel.  Okay
column2: I realize that this is a `beach novel' and that it isn't meant to be particularly insightful
column3: realistic
column4: or memorable - but come' on
column5: even beach novels should meet some kind of standard.    Short Straw is just plain dumb.  It wouldn't be so bad if the characters in the novel were supposed to be stupid (I'm a big fan of novels featuring dumb criminals) but much is made about how smart these characters are; despite all the evidence to the contrary.  Case in point:  The Santa Fe police department arrest a man for murdering his wife and her lover and the DA is ready to go to trial on the case
column6: but no one thought it was necessary to interrogate the alleged killer and to check out his alleged alibi.    Are we supposed to believe that the Santa Fe police department is that inept?  I could be wrong here but I think the police would interrogate the man repeatedly for hours
column7: grilling him about his movements that day and following up on any inconsistencies in his story.  They would sort through his phone bills
column8: business records
column9: and computer files
column10: and interview his friends
column11: neighbours
column12: and associates.  It's ridiculous to think that in a case like this the DA wouldn't even know where the defendant was on the day of the murder.  But that's only one example in a long list of grievances.  For example....  1.	Why does Big Bear tell Ed that he left the worksite to buy an auto part (effectively putting hole in his alibi)?  He doesn't object to lying to Ed about his innocence
column13: so why tell the truth on this point
column14: especially when he has to know it will affect his alibi.  Why doesn't Ed (who is a brilliant legal mind) realize until later the significance of this fact?  Answer:  The author wants Ed to get Big Bear off
column15: but then have an epiphany later when he remembers what Big Bear said about the auto part store.  It will be in this moment that Ed realizes
column16: for the first time
column17: that his client is guilty after all.  2.	Why doesn't the DA make any effort to  effectively cross examine the sole alibi witness in the case?  Surely the witness couldn't have been watching Big Bear all the time (didn't he have to go to the bathroom or make a sandwich or something?)  Answer:  The author wants Ed to get Big Bear off and then have an epiphany later
column18: realizing that his client was actually guilty (see point 1).  If the DA did his job and actually cross examined the witness
column19: this might not happen.  3.	Why does Barbara steal Ed's money AND try to have him killed?  If she was going to have him killed
column20: it would have made a lot more sense for her not to go running off with his money
column21: casting suspicion on herself.  Answer:  If Barbara had Ed killed she would inherit his fortune
column22: get the life insurance money
column23: and the novel would end on page 3.  4.	If Barbara is so smart
column24: why does she use the PI's cell phone to call the spa where she plans to hide out
column25: when the call can obviously be traced?  For that matter
column26: why does she use her own name at all the hotels she booked in Mexico?  Answer:  The author needs the PI's to keep finding her so that she can keep giving them the slip.  Much of the novel is spent having Barbara escape and hide somewhere (but not very well).  The PI's then find her
column27: only to have her slip through their fingers again and again.     5.	Why does Barbara change her appearance?  It would have made more sense for her to have plastic surgery at the beginning of the novel.   Once her plan to steal Ed's money falls apart
column28: she returns to the States
column29: waiting for an opportunity to kill Ed or have him killed
column30: so she can claim the insurance money.  There's no need for her to change her appearance until it is time to disappear.  There is no point in disappearing until she has the money (or if she has reason to believe the police will arrest her - which she doesn't).  If Ed is murdered and she gets away with it (presumably that's the plan)
column31: there is no need to disappear at all.   Answer:  The author has planned a scene later in the novel where Ed enters a bar and doesn't recognize his own wife
column32: but she sees him.  In order for this scene to work
column33: Barbara can't look the same can she?  6.	If Barbara is so smart
column34: why does she keep the gun she used to kill the couple in the hotel?  Answer:  It's the only evidence that can tie her to the crime.  If she gets rid of it
column35: Barbara will get away with murder.  We can't have that now
column36: can we?  7.	For the love of God
column37: what did Ed see in this woman in the first place?  He says that he loved her but there is no evidence of that (he doesn't seem heart broken) and given that he is supposed to be a reasonably intelligent man; couldn't he tell that she was a cold blooded self absorbed sociopath?    Answer:  I think the author was just too lazy to delve into any emotional issues or provide any insight into their relationship.  The bottom line is; this could have been a decent novel if Woods had put some effort into it.  If he asked himself these types of questions while he was writing the manuscript (and trust me - there are more) he could have come up with a stronger plot that made sense.    I realize I have been ranting (this is a long review) but for whatever reason
column38: this novel really frustrated me.  Mostly because I know Woods could have made it a good novel if he wanted to.  He just couldn't be bothered.

column1: [...]  R. Kent Hughes provides us with another entry into the already very crowded market for Christian books that are a mile wide and an inch deep.  He covers a tremendous variety of topics in an incredibly superficial fashion.  The book reads more like a PowerPoint presentation with  occasional witty anecdotes from the presenter.    My disappointment with this book set in with the reading of the second chapter entitled "Purity."   Now there's a topic that an entire book can be written on
column2: but the author gives us a mere eleven pages
column3: using the famous example of King David and his adulterous relationship with Bathsheba to present us with a five-point sermon on what David did wrong.  He begins the chapter with the usual rant about how the church is no different from the world in regards to sexual sin (true enough).  He then tells us about what David did wrong
column4: and to conclude we get seven subdisciplines to practice in order to keep pure: "accountability"
column5: "prayer"
column6: "memorization" (of scripture)
column7: "mind" (don't look at pornography)
column8: "hedges" (keep away from women)
column9: "reality" (you are a sexual being)
column10: "divine awareness" (practicing the presence of God).   Each of these subdisciplines gets a short explanation
column11: never exceeding 300 words in length
column12: and  "reality"
column13: the shortest of the seven
column14: is explained in mere 52 words.  Brevity can be a wonderful thing
column15: but there are times when it can come off sounding rather superficial.    The problem is that all these subdisciplines will not work if a person has emotional and personal issues that need to be overcome first. Any man can partake of these seven practices and still fall into temptation with the greatest of ease
column16: as long as there exists issues in the heart that have never been fully dealt with.  Instead of dealing with the deeper issues regarding sexual sin
column17: we get pat answers to apply to a wounded psyche
column18: which is like applying band-aids to someone who is suffering from internal bleeding.   It's not always pride that causes a man to fall.    Another problem is the loose fashion in which Hughes uses the term "discipline."  For me discipline is a nearly synomous term with training
column19: and in the Christian walk
column20: there are just a few key disicplines that bring the greatest benefit.  But Hughes brings up many
column21: many "disciplines" that just aren't true disciplines.  "Mind" and "reality" from the purity chapter are just two examples
column22: and even purity itself.  Purity in the Christian sense is the abscense of sin
column23: but not doing something isn't exactly what I would call a discpline.     Another mistake is the egalitarian nature in which Hughes presents all his various discplines.  No prioritization or hierarchy is given
column24: he presents them in such a way that they all seem equally important.  But those who are succesfully living the Christian life only practice a few key displines
column25: some of which are more practical than spiritual
column26: like time management and goal setting.  In my own study of spiritual discplines
column27: I've found there are three areas that are the most crucial: personal devotions
column28: self-examination and spiritual direction.  While Hughes has some things to say concerning devotions
column29: there isn't much
column30: if anything concerning the other two.        Hughes also discusses the discipline of "church."  A very interesting topic
column31: and one where he tells us that the church is "the grandest institution that the world has ever known."  But this statement demonstrates that Hughes has bought into the lie that the church is an "institution."  So are prisons and mental hospitals.  The church was not founded to be a grand institution
column32: but to be a life transforming force on this earth.  The fact that we have institutionalized the church to the point of irrelevance is why Christianity is becoming a passing fad in so much of the Western world.    As it is with the church so should it be with Christian books: they to need to help be agents of change and transformation
column33: not just a list of do's and don'ts.  Sadly Hughes' book is more along the lines of a moral dictionary.  Such a book might be helpful for a brand new believer who wants a type of encyclopedia of all the different aspects of Christian culture
column34: but there isn't much meat there for more advanced believers to chew on.  But even a new believer might be quickly overwhelmed with all the various disciplines that Hughes brings forth.   If you are looking for a book that will act as agent of transformation
column35: I highly recommend any of the books John Eldredge has written
column36: especially "Wild at Heart." and "Waking the Dead."  One of the best books about true inner transformation is John and Paula Sanford's "The Transformation of Inner Man."  And for a book about discipline as a means of transformation
column37: I highly recommend Foster's classic "Celebration of Discipline."  And of course the best book of all in regards to transformation is any good translation of the Holy Bible.    Personally
column38: I really like Pastor Hughes and think very highly of him.  I even agree with most of the points he makes in his book
column39: but this is not one of his better efforts
column40: to put it mildly.  So upon returning this book
column41: I purchased a different one that Hughes can rightly be proud of: The Holy Bible: English Standard Version.  Hughes served as a member of the ESV Translation Oversight Committee.    "Superficiality is the curse of our age"  - Richard Foste

column1: I've read a few books of all kinds.  "Modern Pace Handicapping" is one of the worst
column2: frankly
column3: which makes it definitely the worst racing-related book I've ever read.  It's particularly sad when it is supposed to be teaching you something and not just narrating a story.  I understand the concept of pace handicapping
column4: but the nuts and bolts hardly fit together in this work.  I'm surprised I got any theory out of this book at all.  It is truly one of the most poorly written/edited/formatted/arranged books I've run across.  It is shocking this book gets so many rave reviews.  "MPH" is so badly written I can only assume the people giving it 4+ stars are already well-versed in pace handicapping and skipped over all the incomprehensible stuff and the myriad mistakes and horrible copies.  If I wanted to spend more time I could give specific examples by leafing any given page in the book.  However
column5: I'll just sum up by saying this book was riddled with:  -typos; -chopped-off paragraphs (turn the page - what happened?); -confusing mish-mash of decimal system proper
column6: and using decimal notation to represent FIFTHS (i.e.
column7: 1:35.3 = 1:35-3/5 in one section
column8: and in another it represents exactly what it looks like to an engineer like myself - 1:35-3/10); -many extremely poor (completely illegible
column9: high-bleed) copies of old race charts; -poor math-checking - both of equation form and of results in examples; -disconnected charts to text (text discussion on page X
column10: charts were on page X-5
column11: etc); -poor explanation of either general theory
column12: methods or examples - especially - WHY SHOULD I PICK THIS OR THAT RACE AS A TYPICAL PACELINE?  Author acts as if it is so obvious and simply states "this should be the paceline" too many times.  I could probably go on; I always manage to find a new glitch when I recommence reading.  There are so many categories of problems that I cannot keep track of them all.  I'm not sure if "Modern Pace Handicapping" is so poorly edited and explained that I find it hard to pick UP (as opposed to "hard to put down!")
column13: or if I can really say the narrative style itself is so dry as to have made me take 2 years to read it on casual time.  (Not finished yet - a few more chapters
column14: which may mean another 6 months.)  I have started and finished a couple other books on casual time in that period!  It is almost with dread that I attempt again.  I give it a 2 only because I could actually get the general idea from MPH.  I think I could handle calculations
column15: but I'm still confused as to why a particular race in the past-performances is good to use as a predictor for the future race analysis.  The Andrew Beyer books are based on a different concept
column16: but despite involving math and what could be a dry subject
column17: they were definitely better written and MUCH better edited (and as with this subject
column18: I knew little about it when beginning but was curious)

column1: Warner Bros is putting out a series of "Signature Collections".  They are nothing of the sort.  They are studio collections. The word signature implies the best of the best. A signature collection of Hitch's work would not include several of these titles. The rarely seen Foreign Correspondent and I Confess. The failed comedy Mr. & Mrs. Smith. The experimental Dial M for Murder and The Wrong Man.  The middling Stage Fright. Only Strangers on a Train and North By Northwest are signature Hitchcock.  Where are Psycho
column2: Vertigo
column3: The Birds
column4: Rear Window
column5: Notorious
column6: Shadow of a Doubt
column7: Rebecca
column8: The 39 Steps
column9: The Lady Vanishes and
column10: purhaps even
column11: The Lodger?  A signature collection would include all or most of these titles with North by Northwest and Strangers on a Train.  Of course this would oblidge the different studios to cooperate with each other. God forbid. Warner Bros is developing a reputation for shortchanging and lying to its customers.  You're much better off buying your favorite Hitchcock titles individually new or used

column1: After reading "The Kite Runner" - a deeply involving and heart wrenching story of friendship
column2: loyalty and forgiveness amidst the backdrop of life in Afghanistan during the Russian war and the Taliban rule
column3: I set out expecting more of the same from the Swallows of Kabul.  The latter was quite disapointing.    The Swallows of Kabul focusses on 4 main characters struggling to maintain their dignity and humanity amidst the violence
column4: cruelty and desolation of their surroundings.  The dismal context of this story is properly set up.  Enough time is spent in illustrating the violence and suppression of human rights by the Taliban and the desperation of the Afghan people is clearly communicated. Unfortunately
column5: the novel reads like a short story.  Proper character development is not established
column6: so the reader ends up having little or no sympathy for its key characters who want for more redeeming traits.    The novel is successful in  painting a truly depressing picture of Afghanistan
column7: making us thank our lucky stars for being far removed from such a place.  But if you're looking for an inspiring tale of how the human spirit triumphs over such dismal circumstances
column8: then I wouldn't recommend this book for you.  I was glad to have turned the last page and put this book down

column1: Out of the Furnace was the assigned "text" for the first half of a 3-unit American History (after the Civil War) class. As a responsible and voracious reader
column2: I bought and began reading the book. I found the style conclusory and turgid--this happened
column3: that happened
column4: something else happened--without any real character development to differentiate between and among the characters and clarify their relationships. As another reviewer observed
column5: names kept changing and keeping the people sorted out was nearly impossible. Facts and emotions were asserted without textual basis or amplification
column6: making it difficult for this reader to get interested in the book. For example
column7: one plant was deemed "more dangerous" than the others--What does this mean? How was this known?  The cover lines on this book read "Long out of print" and I would say
column8: "with good reason." Because the book was produced in 1941 by a writer describing life two generations earlier
column9: there is not the detail and immediacy the reader gets from "Grapes of Wrath
column10: for example, for which Steinbeck did actual site-visit research. Needless to say, the direct" writing of "Furnace" makes it
column11: as another reviewer noted
column12: stultifying reading.  Further I seriously question the assignment of a novel written so long after the events "described
column13:
as the ONLY assigned text for this period in a history class. A variety of first-person reports (letters or other documents), statistical descriptions of wages, housing conditions, hours worked/injury rates, profit statements of the corporations, plus photographs of the living/working conditions would be more effective inconveying the same message.  I will confess I did not finish the book. Having determined that it was, in my opinion, unreadable, I dropped the class 
 I was very excited when I finally received this CD because of all of the great reviews. I listened to the first song- it was good. I listen to the third- it was okay. By the time I reached the very end, I realized all of the songs sounded the same except for one.  The music is mostly composed of the traditional rock guitar with a combination of techno sounds. The melodies have been slightly changed, and some have a slower tempo than the originals. I don't mind any of these things. The problem I had was with their lack of a variety of different instruments and styles. All of the songs are semi-hard rock with techno sounds from late 80's music (I can't stand those cheesy saxophone sounds).   I wish they added a few vocalists to the music, used a combination of styles, and not try to fill every second with a barrage of sounds. I suggest you buy a couple songs, but not waste your money on buying the whole CD

column17: but this novel is another matter.  Humanity has balkanized into a number of factions
column18: with the Shapers and Mechanists being the most powerful.  The Shapers have reshaped their bodies genetically.  This includes such drastic things as replacing all the E. Coli in their intestines with enzymes.  The Mechanists are like the Borg of Star Trek
column19: they use mechanical prosthetics to enhance themselves.  If you think the Mechanists are the cleaner of the two
column20: think again.  Cockroaches and bacteria are prevalent in Mechanist environments.  Every five years the Mechanists need to have the bacterial growth scraped and UV-burned off their skin.  That's one thing prevalent throughout his writings
column21: this sort of creepiness.  Expect more of it.  However
column22: don't let the war make you think this is some majestic good vs. evil epic space war.  Battles are mostly low key.  There is lot's of narration and dialog.  Sterling self-claims his crammed prose.  No kidding.  Adjectives rule supreme in this novel; as many as possible are crammed into each sentence.  If one would do a histogram of adjectives
column23: this novel would be on the far right tail of the bell curve.  Here's an excerpt: " He always wore his spacesuit
column24: [something something]
column25: and [multiple length modifiers] body odor came through its [multiple adjectives] collar with [multiple adjectives] pungency."  Sentences like this go on and on and on and on and on and on and on throughout the novel.  And there's no shortage of hyphenated words
column26: like long-fermented
column27: eye-watering.  On one page
column28: there were no less than 11 hyphenated words
column29: plus one triple one.  Similar to the prosthetics of the Borg
column30: the sentences themselves seem interchangeable.  Here's another excerpt of a dialogue: "What was your brigade? I'm no Cataclyst. I have your weapon here. Constantine pulled a ... vial from his ... jacket ..." You may as well interchange your own sentences: `The tree fell in the forest; it made no sound' or `the space ship went into orbit; it's boots were muddy.'  Give it a try. It'll make as much sense.  There are times when the novel seems profound.  I would find myself backtracking at times to understand some point
column31: and I would go back 5
column32: then 10
column33: then 20 pages to try to understand something and would just give up and go back to where I was.  It's hard to say you read this novel
column34: it's more like your eyes glance over the words
column35: and on occasion you absorb some of it.  Since the novel fluctuates from the profound to the mundane an average of 2-1/2 stars seemed appropriate

column1: A Virtuous Woman is a book by Kaye Gibbons and is about a woman named Ruby Pitt who meets a guy named Jack Stokes one day when he spots her sitting at a picnic table. It was actually really hard for me to keep reading each page as i went on.It just wasnt a story that kept me wanting more!and that is why i gave it only 2 stars. i didnt even want to finish the book and that is why i think it took me so long to read it.It really dissapointed me seeing as how i loved Kaye Gibbons first novel

column1: Recently I got into a conversation with the guy next to me on the plane about some of the memorable books we had each read in the past few years.  Unfortunately
column2: I had to recall `Confidence'-easily the worst book I've read in years.  To describe it as disappointing is to go easy on Ms. Kanter.  It is far beyond that
column3: and altogether abominable and embarrassing.  That such a prestigious business school like Harvard can tenure a professor who writes such insipid pablum boggles the mind.  Let's start with the central (and only) idea of the book--that winning begets winning and losing begets losing.  This of course strikes most people as fairly straightforward and unworthy of a book's worth of elaboration.  Yet Ms. Kanter tumbles all over herself to spell out the details: why this is the case (as if someone with an ounce of inferential ability couldn't figure it out in a couple of minutes)
column4: how it affects team morale
column5: how it self-perpetuates
column6: etc...  And worst of all
column7: endless
column8: endless
column9: endless examples that do nothing or very little to elucidate; rather
column10: they simply restate what has just been said.  And they restate and restate and restate.  Tautological (I think the word was invented in anticipation of this book)
column11: boring
column12: tedious
column13: insipid
column14: stupid
column15: unthoughtful
column16: unenergetic
column17: disengaged
column18: disrespectful.  All these adjectives apply forcefully to the book.  Most of all
column19: though
column20: it is utterly uninventive and cliched.  Turn to any page and you'll find such gems of penetrating insight as (forgive me
column21: but these are so funny I have to quote at length):   "Winning feels good
column22: and good moods are contagious.  Success makes it easier to view events in a positive light
column23: to generate optimism.  It produces energy and promotes morale.  It is easier to aim high and expect to reach the target."  (P. 29)  "Overcoming obstacles
column24: leaping over hurdles
column25: and recovering from fumbles can strengthen a team that has the discipline not to panic under pressure." (P. 71)  "Once the 'loser' label gets slapped on
column26: those suffering losses are set up to fail.  They find it harder to get support
column27: harder to get opportunities." (P. 115)  "Various turnaround tasks operate on different clocks.  Bold strokes are fast and can be done by one powerful person; long marches to change culture and behavior take more time and the commitment of many people.  Execution is play by play
column28: game by game
column29: while strategy is season by season..." (P. 178)  "People embodying the pathologies of the past can always be replaced
column30: but eliminating the bad does not automatically produce the good.  It takes a major effort on the part of leaders to foster confidence that a demoralized company or group is capable of working together and succeeding at it.  Restoring people's (sic) confidence in one another requires four kinds of action..." (P. 241)  "Confidence is an expectation of a positive outcome
column31: but what happens when outcomes are negative?  The dividing line between winning streaks and losing streaks is the choice of behavior in response to setbacks...  That decision to build rather than retreat
column32: to rally rather than get discouraged
column33: involves viewing setbacks through an optimistic lens
column34: as an opportunity to learn and move on." (P. 357)  And it just goes on and on
column35: mercilessly and cluelessly.   The wisest
column36: most incisive business people read
column37: study and think about far more than just sports and business.  I would recommend Ms. Kanter first enroll in a decent freshman-level literature or history seminar.  There she can learn to write and
column38: with some effort on her part and perhaps a bit of luck
column39: to formulate some imaginative approaches to problem-solving.  Beyond this bilge
column40: I have had the good fortune to come across many books that have helped address confidence.  These are: selected essays by Montaigne and Emerson
column41: `Hamlet'
column42: Whitman's "Song Of Myself"
column43: David Herbert Donald's biography `Lincoln'
column44: `Emotional Intelligence'
column45: `Flow'
column46: and Jack Welch's `Winning'.  `Confidence' inspires confidence only in the realization that you (no matter who you are) are at least intelligent enough to be the "Ernest L. Arbuckle Professor" at Harvard Business School

column1: Bev Harris
column2: Black Box Voting: Ballot Tampering in the Twenty-First Century (Plan Nine Publishing
column3: 2003)  The first thing that needs said about Black Box Voting is that Bev Harris has some things to say that people certainly need to hear. And since the release of this book
column4: things certainly haven't gotten better; electronic voting machines of the type Harris talks about in this book continue to proliferate
column5: and politicians continue to use the system to their own ends. (Anyone shocked by the recent Rolling Stone article about the theft of the 2004 election simply wasn't paying attention; those of us in Ohio were well aware of Ken Blackwell's underhanded tactics throughout 2004.) There's a lot that the average American can learn from this book. However
column6: it has one massive flaw that will keep it from ever being effective: its presentation of those facts.  Technical books
column7: as a rule
column8: should not be written by non-technical people. Harris makes some mistakes that are especially confusing given that she does seem to know

column1: On one hand
column2: this book makes useful points and divorce and its impact on children and offers better alternatives. The problem with it is that most of the evidence is anecdotal. I don't think a lot of the problems the people in the book had were due to divorce
column3: but to the way their parents handled the divorce. Many of them either leaned on their children too much for support or they went from giving their children attention and affection to ignoring them in favour of work and other mates. A lot of the problems could have been lessened with more care. Especially in the case of the fellow who had a congenital heart defect. He needed attention and help
column4: he didn't need to be shunted off to the side. I'm also reading about attachment issues and how they can impact a person from the time they are a baby to an adult. If a person has to divorce
column5: they should ask themselves if it is the right thing to do and if all other options have been exausted. Forcing people to stay together in a stagnating marriage seems a bit cruel to me
column6: like in the case of the intact family she used as an example.  Also
column7: I do not agree with her stating that children don't notice the tention and fighting in their family. They do. Children notice more than people give them credit for. Like so many experts she paints with too broad a brush. She uses too many generalizations. It lessens the impact of her argument. But
column8: a lot of the advice she gives to the system could be used to make divorce easier on parents and children. Divorce isn't going away anytime soon
column9: but
column10: with responsibility and care perhaps it can be easier on children. It is hard for children to adapt to changes. I suggest looking at the advice she offers
column11: but question her methods and conclusions
